objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will explore and experiment with art materials and techniques to generate and develop artistic ideas.

expectations.expectationDescription: Engage in exploration (e.g., noticing cause and effect relationships), and imaginative play with materials (e.g., paper, markers, clay, crayons).
Engage collaboratively (e.g., using manipulative for construction, adding to a group collage) in creative art-making in response to an artistic problem.
Through experimentation, build skills in various media and approaches to art-making (e.g., using the elements of modern art, applying artistic ideas from diverse cultures).
Observe safe practices with art materials, tools, and equipment.
Create art that represents natural and constructed environments.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will develop an understanding of presenting artistic work and create a portfolio.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify reasons for saving and displaying objects, artifacts, and artwork.
Explain the purpose of a portfolio collection (e.g., keeping artworks safe, reviewing artworks later, deciding which artworks are best).
Explain what an art museum is and distinguish how an art museum is different from other buildings.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will learn to perceive, analyze, and interpret artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify various types of art (e.g., drawing, painting, sculpture, architecture).
Describe what an image represents.
Interpret identifying subject matter and describing relevant details.
Explain reasons for selecting a preferred artwork.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will connect their personal experiences and knowledge to the art they create and experience.

expectations.expectationDescription: Create art that tells a story about a life experience.
Identify the purpose of an artwork.

sections.sectionDescription: Students will engage in exploration and imaginative play with various art materials such as paper, markers, clay, and crayons.
Students will notice cause and effect relationships through play and exploration with different art materials.
Students will engage collaboratively in creative art-making activities such as using manipulatives for construction and adding to a group collage.
Students will build skills in various media and approaches to art-making through experimentation.
Students will observe safe practices with art materials, tools, and equipment.
Students will create art that represents natural and constructed environments.
Students will identify reasons for saving and displaying objects, artifacts, and artwork.
Students will explain the purpose of a portfolio collection, including keeping artworks safe, reviewing artworks later, and deciding which artworks are best.
Students will explain what an art museum is and distinguish how an art museum is different from other buildings.
Students will identify various types of art such as drawing, painting, sculpture, and architecture.
Students will describe what an image represents.
Students will interpret art by identifying subject matter and describing relevant details.
Students will explain reasons for selecting a preferred artwork.
Students will create art that tells a story about a life experience.
Students will identify the purpose of an artwork.

Students will review and expand upon previous lessons, practicing skills and concepts learned throughout the year. This period will also include project-based learning and preparing for a final portfolio presentation.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will learn about computing devices, hardware, software, and basic troubleshooting.

expectations.expectationDescription: With teacher guidance, select and operate an appropriate device to perform a task.
Use appropriate terminology in identifying and describing the function of common physical components of computing systems.
Discuss basic hardware and software problems.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will understand cybersecurity, network communication, and organization.

expectations.expectationDescription: Explain that a password helps protect the privacy of information.
With teacher guidance, define computer networks and how they can be used to connect people to other people, places, information, and ideas.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will learn about data collection, storage, visualization, transformation, inference, and models.

expectations.expectationDescription: With teacher guidance, collect and transform data using digital devices; Display data for communication in various visual formats.
Recognize that data can be collected and stored on different computing devices over time and retrieved later.
Discuss patterns in data to make inferences or predictions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will learn about algorithms, variables, control, modularity, and program development.

expectations.expectationDescription: With teacher assistance, model daily processes by following algorithms (sets of step-by-step instructions) to complete tasks.
With teacher assistance, model the way programs store and manipulate data by using numbers or other symbols to represent information.
With teacher assistance, identify programs with sequences and simple loops, to express ideas or address a problem.
With teacher assistance, solve a problem by breaking it down into smaller parts.
With teacher assistance, develop plans that describe a programâ€™s sequence of events, goals, and expected outcomes.
With teacher assistance, identify attribution (credit) when using the ideas and creations of others while developing programs.
With teacher assistance, debug (identify and fix) errors in an algorithm or program that includes sequences and simple loops.
With teacher assistance, using correct terminology, describe steps taken and choices made during program development.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will learn about the cultural, social, and ethical impacts of computing technology.

expectations.expectationDescription: Discuss how people lived and worked before and after the implementation or adoption of new computing technology.
Work respectfully and responsibly with others online.
Keep login information private, and log off of devices appropriately.

sections.sectionDescription: Introduce students to various computing devices. Guide them in selecting and operating a device to perform simple tasks, such as using a tablet to draw or a computer to play an educational game.
Teach students the names and functions of common physical components such as the monitor, keyboard, mouse, and CPU. Use hands-on activities to help them identify and describe these parts.
Discuss common hardware and software problems. Use simple examples to show how to address minor issues, like restarting a frozen computer or checking if a device is plugged in.
Explain the importance of passwords in protecting information. Demonstrate how to create a strong password and discuss why it should be kept private.
Define computer networks and explain how they connect people and information. Use simple analogies and activities to show how networks work.
Guide students in collecting data using digital devices. Show how to transform data and display it in various visual formats, such as charts or graphs.
Teach students that data can be stored on different devices and retrieved later. Use examples like saving a document on a computer or a photo on a tablet.
Discuss how to look for patterns in data to make simple inferences or predictions. Use activities like identifying weather patterns or favorite classroom activities.
Introduce algorithms as sets of step-by-step instructions. Help students model simple daily tasks, like getting ready for school, using algorithms.
Show how programs use numbers or symbols to represent information. Use activities like counting objects or using symbols to represent different items.
Identify programs with sequences and simple loops. Use block-based coding tools to create simple programs that express ideas or solve problems.
Teach students how to solve problems by breaking them down into smaller, more manageable parts. Use examples like organizing a classroom activity.
Help students develop plans for simple programs, including the sequence of events, goals, and expected outcomes. Use storyboards or flowcharts to visualize the plan.
Teach students about the importance of giving credit when using the ideas and creations of others. Use examples from digital art or written work.
Show students how to identify and fix errors in simple programs. Use block-based coding tools to demonstrate debugging techniques.
Teach students the correct terminology to describe the steps taken and choices made during program development. Use discussions and presentations to reinforce learning.
Discuss how computing technology has changed the way people live and work. Use historical examples to show the evolution of technology.
Teach students how to work respectfully and responsibly with others online. Discuss online etiquette and the importance of positive digital interactions.
Show students how to keep their login information private and log off devices appropriately. Use role-playing activities to practice these skills.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students leverage technology to set personal learning goals, utilize appropriate technology, and reflect on the learning process.

expectations.expectationDescription: With guidance, consider and set personal learning goals and utilize appropriate technology to demonstrate knowledge and reflect on the learning process.
With guidance, learn about technologies that can be used to connect to others and demonstrate the ability to link purpose with resource(s) to enhance and customize their learning.
With guidance, recognize feedback from both people and features embedded in digital tools, and use age-appropriate technology to share learning.
With guidance, learn to recognize commonalities and fundamental structures across digital tools and begin to transfer learning between tools or learning environments.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students recognize the rights, responsibilities, and opportunities of living, learning, and working in an interconnected digital world.

expectations.expectationDescription: With guidance, discuss and develop their digital identity through responsible use of technology.
With guidance, engage in positive and safe behavior when using devices and working online with others.
With guidance, begin to develop an understanding of ownership, sharing of information, and how to respect the work of others.
With guidance, demonstrate the importance of keeping their information private.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students critically curate a variety of resources using digital tools to construct knowledge and make meaningful learning experiences for themselves and others.

expectations.expectationDescription: With guidance, use provided digital tools and resources to find information on topics of interest.
With guidance, become familiar with age-appropriate criteria for evaluating digital content.
With guidance, use a variety of provided tools to organize information and make connections to their learning.
With guidance, explore real-world issues and share their ideas about them with others.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students use a variety of technologies within a design process to identify and solve problems by creating new, useful or imaginative solutions.

expectations.expectationDescription: With guidance, ask questions, suggest solutions, test ideas to solve problems, and share their learning.
With guidance, use age-appropriate digital and/or non-digital tools to describe the steps in a design process.
With guidance, use a design process to develop ideas or creations, test their design, and redesign as necessary.
Demonstrate perseverance when working to complete a challenging task.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop and employ strategies for understanding and solving problems in ways that leverage the power of technological methods to develop and test solutions.

expectations.expectationDescription: With guidance, identify a problem and select appropriate technology tools to explore and find solutions.
With guidance, analyze age-appropriate data and look for similarities in order to identify patterns and categories.
With guidance, break a problem into parts and identify ways to solve the problem.
Discuss and develop an understanding of how technology is used to make a task easier or repeatable and can identify real-world examples.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students communicate clearly and express themselves creatively for a variety of purposes using the platforms, tools, styles, formats and digital media appropriate to their goals.

expectations.expectationDescription: With guidance, use a variety of tools for creating something new and communicating with others.
With guidance, create original works using digital tools and resources.
With guidance, create digital artifacts to share ideas in multiple formats.
With guidance, select the appropriate technology for sharing their ideas with intended audiences.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students use digital tools to broaden their perspectives and enrich their learning by collaborating with others and working effectively in teams locally and globally.

expectations.expectationDescription: With guidance, use digital tools to work with other learners and get to know people within their local community and beyond.
With guidance, use technology to communicate with others and to look at problems from different perspectives.
With guidance, take on various team roles and use age-appropriate technology to complete projects.
With guidance, use age-appropriate technology to work together to demonstrate an understanding of local or global issues and suggest possible solutions.

sections.sectionDescription: Introduce students to the course structure, objectives, and expectations. Discuss the importance of technology in learning.
Guide students to set personal learning goals using technology and reflect on their learning process.
Introduce students to technologies for connecting with others and linking purposes with resources to enhance learning.
Teach students how to recognize and use feedback from digital tools and people to share their learning.
Help students recognize common structures in digital tools and transfer their learning between different environments.
Discuss the concept of digital identity and responsible use of technology.
Teach students about positive and safe behavior when using devices and working online.
Introduce the concept of ownership and sharing of information and respecting others' work.
Emphasize the importance of keeping personal information private.
Guide students to use digital tools to find information on topics of interest.
Teach students age-appropriate criteria for evaluating digital content.
Show students how to use various tools to organize information and make connections to their learning.
Encourage students to explore real-world issues and share their ideas.
Introduce the design process and guide students to ask questions, suggest solutions, and test ideas to solve problems.
Use age-appropriate tools to describe the steps in a design process.
Guide students through developing ideas, testing their designs, and making necessary redesigns.
Encourage perseverance in completing challenging tasks.
Help students identify problems and select appropriate technology tools to explore solutions.
Teach students to analyze data and identify patterns and categories.
Guide students to break problems into parts and identify ways to solve them.
Discuss how technology makes tasks easier or repeatable and identify real-world examples.
Guide students to use various tools to create something new and communicate with others.
Teach students to create original works using digital tools.
Guide students to create digital artifacts to share their ideas in multiple formats.
Teach students to select appropriate technology for sharing their ideas with intended audiences.
Introduce digital tools for collaborating with others locally and globally.
Teach students to use technology to communicate with others and look at problems from different perspectives.
Guide students to take on various team roles and use technology to complete projects.
Use technology to work together and understand local or global issues and suggest solutions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Know number names and the count sequence.

expectations.expectationDescription: Count to 100 by ones and by tens.
Count forward from a given number other than one, within the known sequence (e.g., 'Starting at the number 5, count up to 11.').
Write numbers from 0 to 20. Represent a number of objects with a written numeral 0 to 20 (with 0 representing a count of no objects).

Understand the relationship between numbers and quantities; connect counting to cardinality. (a) When counting objects, say the number names in the standard order, pairing each object with one and only one number name and each number name with one and only one object (one to one correspondence). (b) Understand that the last number name said tells the number of objects counted. The number of objects is the same regardless of their arrangement or the order in which they were counted (cardinality). (c) Understand that each successive number name refers to a quantity that is one larger (hierarchical inclusion).

Count to answer questions about â€œHow many?â€ when 20 or fewer objects are arranged in a line, a rectangular array, or a circle, or as many as 10 things in a scattered configuration; given a number from 1 to 20, count out that many objects.
Identify whether the number of objects in one group is greater than, less than, or equal to the number of objects in another group. (Include groups with up to ten objects.)
Compare two numbers between 0 and 10 presented as written numerals.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Understand addition as putting together and adding to, and understand subtraction as taking apart and taking from.

expectations.expectationDescription: Represent addition and subtraction concretely.
Solve addition and subtraction word problems and add and subtract within 10.
Decompose numbers less than or equal to 10 into pairs in more than one way.
For any number from 1 to 9, find the number that makes 10 when added to the given number.
Fluently add and subtract within 5.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Number and Operations in Base Ten (NBT)
objectives.objectiveDescription: Work with numbers 11 to 19 to gain foundations for place value.

expectations.expectationDescription: Compose and decompose numbers from 11 to 19 into ten ones and additional ones.
Demonstrate understanding of addition and subtraction within 10 using place value.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Describe and compare measurable attributes.

expectations.expectationDescription: Describe measurable attributes of a single object.
Directly compare two objects with a measurable attribute in common to see which object has 'more of' or 'less of' the attribute, and describe the difference.
Classify objects into given categories; count the number in each category and sort the categories by count.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Identify and describe shapes.

expectations.expectationDescription: Describe objects in the environment using names of shapes, and describe the relative positions of these objects using terms such as above, below, beside, in front of, behind, and next to.
Correctly name shapes regardless of their orientation or overall size.
Identify shapes as two-dimensional or three-dimensional.

Analyze and compare two-dimensional and three-dimensional shapes, in different sizes and orientations, using informal language to describe their similarities, differences, parts, and other attributes.
Model shapes in the world by building shapes from components and drawing shapes.
Use simple shapes to form composite shapes.
Make sense of problems and persevere in solving them.
Reason abstractly and quantitatively.
Construct viable arguments and critique the reasoning of others.
Model with mathematics.
Use appropriate tools strategically.
Attend to precision.
Look for and make use of structure.
Look for and express regularity in repeated reasoning.

sections.sectionTitle: Count to 100 by ones and by tens
sections.sectionDescription: Introduce students to counting to 100 by ones and by tens through songs, visual aids, and interactive counting exercises.

sections.sectionTitle: Count forward from a given number
sections.sectionDescription: Practice counting forward from numbers other than one using number lines and counting activities.
Teach students to write numbers from 0 to 20 and represent objects with these numbers through writing exercises and object counting.

sections.sectionTitle: Understand the relationship between numbers and quantities
sections.sectionDescription: Explore the relationship between numbers and quantities through hands-on activities and counting games to illustrate one-to-one correspondence and cardinality.
Use different configurations of objects to teach students to count and answer questions about quantities, reinforcing counting skills.

sections.sectionTitle: Identify greater than, less than, or equal to
sections.sectionDescription: Engage students in activities to compare groups of objects and determine which group has more, less, or the same number of objects.
Teach students to compare written numerals between 0 and 10 through matching games and numeral comparisons.
Introduce students to the concepts of addition and subtraction using physical objects and visual aids to represent joining and separating groups.

sections.sectionTitle: Solve addition and subtraction word problems
sections.sectionDescription: Engage students with simple word problems involving addition and subtraction within 10, using manipulatives and drawings to solve problems.
Teach students to break down numbers less than or equal to 10 into pairs in different ways through hands-on activities and number games.
Practice finding the number that adds to a given number to make 10, using ten-frames and interactive exercises.
Develop fluency in addition and subtraction within 5 through timed activities, games, and repetitive practice.
Introduce the concept of place value by composing and decomposing numbers from 11 to 19 into ten ones and additional ones using visual aids and manipulatives.

outline.title: Addition and Subtraction with Place Value

sections.sectionTitle: Understand addition and subtraction with place value
sections.sectionDescription: Teach students to demonstrate addition and subtraction within 10 using place value concepts, focusing on the ones place.
Introduce students to different measurable attributes such as length, weight, and height through hands-on measurement activities.

sections.sectionTitle: Compare two objects with measurable attributes
sections.sectionDescription: Teach students to compare two objects with a common measurable attribute and describe which has more or less of that attribute.
Engage students in sorting objects into different categories, counting the number of objects in each category, and sorting categories by count.
Introduce students to the names of shapes and use positional terms such as above, below, beside, in front of, behind, and next to, to describe objects in the environment.
Teach students to correctly name shapes regardless of their orientation or overall size through shape identification activities.

sections.sectionTitle: Identify shapes as two-dimensional or three-dimensional
sections.sectionDescription: Introduce students to the differences between two-dimensional and three-dimensional shapes through visual aids and shape sorting activities.
Engage students in activities to analyze and compare two-dimensional and three-dimensional shapes, using informal language to describe their similarities and differences.

sections.sectionTitle: Model shapes by building and drawing
sections.sectionDescription: Teach students to model shapes in the world by building shapes from components and drawing shapes.

sections.sectionTitle: Use simple shapes to form composite shapes
sections.sectionDescription: Engage students in using simple shapes to form composite shapes through hands-on activities and shape composition games.

sections.sectionTitle: Make sense of problems and persevere in solving them
sections.sectionDescription: Develop students' problem-solving skills by presenting them with various mathematical problems and encouraging perseverance in finding solutions.
Encourage students to reason abstractly and quantitatively by exploring different mathematical concepts and their applications.

sections.sectionTitle: Construct viable arguments and critique reasoning
sections.sectionDescription: Teach students to construct viable arguments and critique the reasoning of others through group discussions and problem-solving activities.
Introduce students to modeling with mathematics by using mathematical concepts to solve real-world problems and represent scenarios.
Teach students to use appropriate mathematical tools strategically, including manipulatives, calculators, and other resources.
Develop students' precision in mathematics by focusing on accurate calculations, clear communication, and attention to detail.

sections.sectionTitle: Look for and make use of structure
sections.sectionDescription: Encourage students to look for and make use of mathematical structures, patterns, and relationships in problem-solving.

sections.sectionTitle: Look for and express regularity in repeated reasoning
sections.sectionDescription: Teach students to recognize and express regularity in repeated reasoning by identifying patterns and making generalizations.
Review all concepts covered under Counting and Cardinality, ensuring students have a solid understanding of counting, writing numbers, and comparing quantities.
Review addition and subtraction concepts, ensuring students can solve problems and understand the relationships between numbers.

outline.title: Review: Number and Operations in Base Ten

sections.sectionTitle: Review Number and Operations in Base Ten
sections.sectionDescription: Revisit place value concepts and ensure students can compose and decompose numbers effectively.
Review measurable attributes and data classification concepts, ensuring students can describe, compare, and sort objects.
Revisit shape identification, description, and modeling concepts, ensuring students can recognize and analyze different shapes.

sections.sSID: K.MP.1, K.MP.2, K.MP.3, K.MP.4, K.MP.5, K.MP.6, K.MP.7, K.MP.8
sections.sectionDescription: Review all Standards for Mathematical Practice, ensuring students can apply these practices in problem-solving and reasoning.
Conduct a comprehensive review of all concepts covered throughout the year and administer final assessments to evaluate student understanding and proficiency.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Sensemaking in science occurs with the integration of three essential dimensions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Ask questions and define problems.
Develop and use models.
Plan and carry out investigations.
Analyze and interpret data.
Use mathematics and computational thinking.
Construct explanations and design solutions.
Engage in argument from evidence.
Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information.
Patterns.
Cause and effect.
Structure and function.
Systems and system models.
Stability and change.
Scale, proportion, and quantity.
Energy and matter.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Core Ideas for Knowing Science.

expectations.expectationDescription: All matter in the Universe is made of very small particles.
Objects can affect other objects at a distance.
Changing the movement of an object requires a net force to be acting on it.
The total amount of energy in a closed system is always the same but can be transferred from one energy store to another during an event.
The composition of the Earth and its atmosphere and the natural and human processes occurring within them shape the Earthâ€™s surface and its climate.
The Earth and our solar system are a very small part of one of many galaxies within the Universe.
Organisms are organized on a cellular basis and have a finite life span.
Organisms require a supply of energy and materials for which they often depend on, or compete with, other organisms.
Genetic information is passed down from one generation of organisms to another.
The unity and diversity of organisms, living and extinct, is the result of evolution.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students explore how their senses can detect light, sound, and vibration and how technology can be used to extend their senses.

expectations.expectationDescription: Investigate how senses can detect light, sound, and vibrations even when they come from far away; use the collected evidence to develop and support an explanation.
Design and evaluate a tool that helps people extend their senses.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop an understanding of patterns to understand changes in local weather, seasonal cycles, and daylight.

expectations.expectationDescription: Observe, record, and ask questions about temperature, precipitation, and other weather data to identify patterns or changes in local weather.
Observe, describe, ask questions, and predict seasonal weather patterns; and how those patterns impact plants and animals (including humans).
Observe and ask questions about patterns of the motion

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop an understanding that the world is comprised of living and non-living things. They investigate the relationship between structure and function in living things; plants and animals use specialized parts to help them meet their needs and survive.

expectations.expectationDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information about how organisms use different body parts for survival.
Observe, ask questions, and explain how specialized structures found on a variety of plants and animals (including humans) help them sense and respond to their environment.
Observe, ask questions, and explain the differences between the characteristics of living and non-living things.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students explore how their senses can detect light, sound, and vibration and how technology can be used to extend their senses.

expectations.expectationDescription: People use their senses to learn about the world around them. Their eyes detect light, their ears detect sound, and they can feel vibrations by touch.
People use their senses to learn about the world around them. Their eyes detect light, their ears detect sound, and they can feel vibrations by touch.
People also use a variety of devices to communicate (send and receive information) over long distances.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Elements of Earth and Space Science Standards
objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop an understanding of patterns to understand changes in local weather, seasonal cycles, and daylight.

expectations.expectationDescription: Weather is the combination of sunlight, wind, snow or rain, and temperature in a particular region at a particular time.
Weather is the combination of sunlight, wind, snow or rain, and temperature in a particular region at a particular time.
Patterns of the motion of the sun, moon, and stars in the sky can be observed, described, and predicted.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop an understanding that the world is comprised of living and non-living things. They investigate the relationship between structure and function in living things; plants and animals use specialized parts to help them meet their needs and survive.

expectations.expectationDescription: All organisms have external parts. Different animals use their body parts in different ways to see, hear, grasp objects, protect themselves, move from place to place, and seek, find, and take in food, water, and air.

All organisms have external parts. Different animals use their body parts in different ways to see, hear, grasp objects, protect themselves, move from place to place, and seek, find, and take in food, water, and air.
Animals have body parts that capture and convey different kinds of information needed for growth and survivalâ€”for example, eyes for light, ears for sounds, and skin for temperature or touch.
There is a wide variety of living things, including plants and animals. They are distinguished from non-living things by their ability to move, reproduce, and react to certain stimuli.

sections.sectionDescription: Introduce students to the concept of science and its importance. Discuss the three dimensions of science: asking questions, developing models, and carrying out investigations.
Teach students how to ask scientific questions and define problems. Engage them in activities that involve forming questions about the natural world.
Introduce students to the concept of models in science. Show examples of different types of models and engage students in creating simple models.
Teach students how to plan and conduct scientific investigations. Engage them in simple experiments to practice these skills.
Show students how to analyze and interpret data collected from experiments. Use examples and activities to illustrate these concepts.
Discuss the role of mathematics in science. Engage students in activities that involve basic mathematical computations and problem-solving.
Teach students how to construct scientific explanations and design solutions to problems. Use real-world examples to demonstrate these skills.
Show students how to use evidence to support scientific arguments. Engage them in discussions and activities that involve evaluating evidence.
Teach students how to obtain, evaluate, and communicate scientific information. Use various media and tools to practice these skills.
Discuss the concept of patterns in nature and science. Engage students in identifying and analyzing patterns through activities and observations.
Introduce the idea of cause and effect in scientific phenomena. Use experiments and examples to show how causes lead to specific effects.
Teach students about the relationship between structure and function in living and non-living things. Use examples from biology and engineering.
Discuss the concept of systems and how models are used to represent them. Engage students in creating and analyzing models of simple systems.
Introduce the concepts of stability and change in science. Use examples from ecology and geology to illustrate these ideas.
Teach students about the importance of scale, proportion, and quantity in scientific observations and models. Use activities to practice measuring and comparing.
Discuss the concepts of energy and matter and their interactions. Use experiments to demonstrate the principles of energy transfer and conservation.
Teach students that all matter is made of very small particles. Use activities to explore the properties of different materials.
Explain how energy can be transferred between different stores. Conduct experiments to show energy conservation in closed systems.
Discuss how objects can affect each other from a distance. Use magnets and other examples to illustrate these concepts.
Teach students about the relationship between force and motion. Use experiments to show how forces can change the movement of objects.
Explain the composition of the Earth and its atmosphere. Discuss how natural and human processes shape the Earth's surface and climate.
Teach students about the solar system and our place in the universe. Use models and observations to explore the components of the solar system.
Introduce the concept of cells as the basic units of life. Discuss the life span and organization of organisms.
Teach students how organisms require energy and materials to survive. Discuss the interdependence and competition among organisms.
Explain how genetic information is passed from one generation to the next. Use examples to illustrate heredity and inheritance.
Discuss the concepts of evolution and the diversity of life. Use fossil records and living organisms to show the results of evolution.
Teach students how their senses can detect light, sound, and vibrations. Conduct experiments to collect evidence and develop explanations.
Discuss how technology can extend human senses. Engage students in designing and evaluating tools that help people sense their environment.

outline.title: Earth and Space Science: Weather and Patterns

sections.sectionDescription: Teach students how to observe, record, and ask questions about weather. Identify patterns in local weather data and discuss changes.
Discuss seasonal weather patterns and their impact on plants and animals. Use observations to predict and explain these patterns.

outline.title: Earth and Space Science: Motion and Patterns

sections.sectionDescription: Observe and ask questions about the patterns of motion of celestial bodies. Discuss how these patterns can be predicted and explained.
Teach students how different body parts help organisms survive. Use examples from various animals and plants to illustrate these functions.
Discuss how specialized structures help organisms sense and respond to their environment. Engage students in observing and explaining these structures.

outline.title: Life Science: Characteristics of Living Things

sections.sectionDescription: Explain the differences between living and non-living things. Use observations and questions to help students understand these characteristics.

outline.title: Elements of Physical Science: Light, Sound, and Vibration

sections.sectionDescription: Discuss how senses detect light, sound, and vibrations. Explore how technology extends these senses through practical examples.

outline.title: Elements of Earth and Space Science: Weather

sections.sectionDescription: Teach students about the elements of weather, including sunlight, wind, precipitation, and temperature. Discuss how these elements interact to create weather.
Discuss the impact of seasonal changes on weather. Use activities to help students observe and describe these changes.

outline.title: Elements of Earth and Space Science: Celestial Patterns

sections.sectionDescription: Observe and describe the patterns of motion of the sun, moon, and stars. Teach students how these patterns can be predicted and explained.

outline.title: Elements of Life Science: Living Organisms

sections.sectionDescription: Discuss how different animals use their body parts in various ways to survive. Use examples to show the diversity of functions.
Teach students how different organisms use their external parts for different purposes. Engage them in observing and describing these parts.

outline.title: Elements of Life Science: Sensory Organs

sections.sectionDescription: Discuss how animals have body parts that capture and convey information for survival. Use examples like eyes, ears, and skin to illustrate these concepts.

outline.title: Elements of Life Science: Characteristics of Living Things

sections.sectionDescription: Explain the wide variety of living things and their distinguishing characteristics. Discuss how living things are different from non-living things.
Review the three dimensions of science: asking questions, developing models, and carrying out investigations. Use activities and discussions to reinforce these concepts.
Review the core ideas of knowing science, including matter, energy, forces, Earth systems, and life science. Use activities to reinforce these concepts.
Review the crosscutting concepts such as patterns, cause and effect, and structure and function. Use examples and activities to reinforce these ideas.
Conduct a final review of all topics covered throughout the course. Use assessments to evaluate students' understanding and mastery of the concepts.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Generate and Conceptualize Artistic Ideas

expectations.expectationDescription: Engage collaboratively (e.g., pairs, small groups, whole group) in exploration and imaginative play with materials (e.g., puppets, model towns, paper murals).
Use careful observation in preparation for making a work of art.
Explore uses of materials, tools, approaches (e.g., using elements of modern art, applying artistic ideas from diverse cultures) to create works of art or design.
Demonstrate safe and proper procedures for using materials, tools, and equipment while making art.
Identify and classify uses of everyday objects through drawings, diagrams, sculptures, or other visual means.

Patterns of the motion of the sun, moon, and stars in the sky can be observed, described, and predicted.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students recognize and understand computing devices, hardware, and software.

expectations.expectationDescription: Recognize that users have different needs and preferences for technology by selecting and operating appropriate devices.
Understand how computing systems use both hardware (device) and software (program/app) to process information.
Explain basic hardware (device) and software (program/app) problems using accurate terminology and use basic troubleshooting strategies.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students understand the concepts related to networks, the internet, cybersecurity, and communication.

expectations.expectationDescription: Explain what passwords are and why we use them, and use strong passwords to protect devices and information from unauthorized access.
Discuss how computer networks can be used to connect people to other people, places, information, and ideas.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students collect, store, analyze, visualize, and interpret data using digital devices.

expectations.expectationDescription: Collect and transform data using digital devices; Display data for communication in various visual formats.
Store, copy, search, retrieve, modify, and delete information using a computing device and define the information stored as data.
Describe patterns in data to make inferences or predictions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students understand algorithms, variables, control, modularity, program development, and debugging.

expectations.expectationDescription: Model daily processes by creating and following algorithms.
Model the way programs store and manipulate data by using numbers or other symbols to represent information.
Develop programs with sequences and simple loops to express ideas or address a problem.
Decompose (break down) the steps needed to solve a problem into a precise sequence of instructions.
Develop plans that describe a programâ€™s sequence of events, goals, and expected outcomes.
Give attribution (credit) when using the ideas and creations of others while developing programs.
Debug (identify and fix) errors in an algorithm or program that includes sequences and simple loops.
Using correct terminology, describe steps taken and choices made during the iterative process of program development.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students understand the cultural, social, and ethical implications of computing.

expectations.expectationDescription: Compare how people live and work before and after the implementation or adoption of new computing technology.
Work respectfully and responsibly with others online.
Keep login information private, and log off of devices appropriately.

sections.sectionDescription: Introduce students to various computing devices, their uses, and importance in daily life.
Discuss different needs and preferences for technology and demonstrate how to select and operate appropriate devices.
Explain how hardware and software work together to process information.
Teach students how to identify and describe basic hardware and software problems and introduce basic troubleshooting strategies.
Introduce the concept of networks and how they connect people and devices.
Explain the importance of passwords, how to create strong passwords, and their role in protecting devices and information.
Discuss how computer networks facilitate communication and information exchange.
Teach students how to collect and transform data using digital devices and display data in various visual formats.
Explain how to store, copy, search, retrieve, modify, and delete information using computing devices.
Describe how to identify patterns in data to make inferences or predictions.
Introduce the concept of algorithms and demonstrate how to model daily processes by creating and following algorithms.
Explain how programs use variables to store and manipulate data.
Develop programs with sequences and simple loops to express ideas or address problems.
Teach students how to break down steps needed to solve a problem into a precise sequence of instructions.
Develop plans that describe a programâ€™s sequence of events, goals, and expected outcomes.
Discuss the importance of giving credit when using the ideas and creations of others in program development.
Teach students how to debug programs by identifying and fixing errors in algorithms that include sequences and simple loops.
Describe the steps taken and choices made during the iterative process of program development using correct terminology.
Understand the cultural, social, and ethical implications of computing.
Compare how people live and work before and after the implementation of new computing technologies.
Discuss the importance of working respectfully and responsibly with others online.
Teach students how to keep login information private and the importance of logging off devices appropriately.
Review the concepts of computing systems, including hardware, software, and troubleshooting.
Review the concepts related to networks, internet communication, and cybersecurity.
Review data collection, storage, analysis, and visualization techniques.
Review the basics of algorithms, variables, control structures, modularity, and program development.
Review the cultural, social, and ethical implications of computing technology.
Expand on basic troubleshooting strategies to cover more complex hardware and software issues.
Dive deeper into network communication and explore more complex network structures and protocols.
Teach students how to create advanced data visualizations and interpret complex data sets.
Explore more advanced programming control structures, such as nested loops and conditionals.
Develop plans for more complex programs, focusing on sequence of events, goals, and expected outcomes.
Review advanced topics in computing systems, networks, data analysis, and programming.
Begin planning a capstone project that integrates all learned concepts. Students will outline their project goals, timeline, and expected outcomes.
Students begin the development phase of their capstone projects, applying algorithms, programming, and data analysis skills.
Students test and debug their capstone projects, ensuring functionality and correctness.
Students finalize their capstone projects, preparing them for presentation.
Students present their capstone projects, demonstrating their understanding and application of computing concepts.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students leverage technology to take an active role in choosing, achieving, and demonstrating competency in their learning goals, informed by the learning sciences.

expectations.expectationDescription: Consider and set personal learning goals, utilize appropriate technology to demonstrate knowledge, and reflect on the learning process.
Learn about technologies that can be used to connect to others and enhance learning.
Recognize feedback from people and digital tools, and use technology to share learning.
Learn to recognize commonalities and fundamental structures across digital tools and transfer learning between tools or learning environments.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students recognize the rights, responsibilities, and opportunities of living, learning, and working in an interconnected digital world, and they act and model in ways that are safe, legal, and ethical.

expectations.expectationDescription: Discuss and develop digital identity through responsible use of technology.
Engage in positive and safe behavior when using devices and working online with others.
Develop understanding of ownership, sharing of information, and respect for others' work.
Demonstrate the importance of keeping information private.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students critically curate a variety of resources using digital tools to construct knowledge, produce creative artifacts, and make meaningful learning experiences for themselves and others.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use digital tools and resources to find information on topics of interest.
Become familiar with criteria for evaluating digital content.
Use a variety of tools to organize information and make connections to learning.
Explore real-world issues and share ideas about them with others.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students use a variety of technologies within a design process to identify and solve problems by creating new, useful, or imaginative solutions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Ask questions, suggest solutions, test ideas to solve problems, and share learning.
Use age-appropriate tools to describe the steps in a design process.
Use a design process to develop ideas or creations, test their design, and redesign as necessary.
Demonstrate perseverance when working to complete a challenging task.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop and employ strategies for understanding and solving problems in ways that leverage the power of technological methods to develop and test solutions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify a problem and select appropriate technology tools to explore and find solutions.
Analyze data and look for similarities to identify patterns and categories.
Break a problem into parts and identify ways to solve the problem.
Discuss how technology is used to make a task easier or repeatable and identify real-world examples.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students communicate clearly and express themselves creatively for a variety of purposes using the platforms, tools, styles, formats, and digital media appropriate to their goals.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use a variety of tools for creating something new and communicating with others.
Create original works using digital tools and resources.
Create digital artifacts to share ideas in multiple formats.
Select appropriate technology for sharing ideas with intended audiences.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students use digital tools to broaden their perspectives and enrich their learning by collaborating with others and working effectively in teams locally and globally.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use digital tools to work with other learners and get to know people within their local community and beyond.
Use technology to communicate with others and to look at problems from different perspectives.
Take on various team roles and use age-appropriate technology to complete projects.
Use age-appropriate technology to work together to demonstrate an understanding of local or global issues and suggest possible solutions.
