objectives.objectiveDescription: Represent and solve problems involving addition and subtraction.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use addition and subtraction within 100 to solve one- and two-step word problems. Represent a word problem as an equation with a symbol for the unknown.
Fluently add and subtract within 20. By the end of Grade 2, know from memory all sums of two one-digit numbers.

Determine whether a group of objects (up to 20) has an odd or even number of members. Use addition to find the total number of objects arranged in rectangular arrays (with up to 5 rows and 5 columns). Write an equation to express the total as a sum of equal addends.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Number and Operations in Base Ten (NBT)
objectives.objectiveDescription: Understand place value and use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.

expectations.expectationDescription: Understand that the three digits of a three-digit number represent groups of hundreds, tens, and ones. Count within 1000; skip count by 5's, 10's and 100's. Read and write numbers up to 1000 using base-ten numerals, number names, and expanded form. Compare two three-digit numbers based on meanings of the hundreds, tens, and ones digits.

Fluently add and subtract within 100 using strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction. Add up to three two-digit numbers using strategies based on place value and properties of operations. Demonstrate understanding of addition and subtraction within 1000, connecting objects or drawings to strategies based on place value (including multiples of 10), properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction. Mentally add 10 or 100 to a given number in the range of 100 and 900, and mentally subtract 10 or 100 from a given number in the range of 100 and 900.
Explain why addition and subtraction strategies work, using place value and the properties of operations.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Measure and estimate lengths in standard units; relate addition and subtraction to length; work with time and money; represent and interpret data.

expectations.expectationDescription: Measure the length of an object by selecting and using appropriate tools. Measure the length of an object twice, using different standard length units for the two measurements; describe how the two measurements relate to the size of the unit chosen. Estimate lengths using units of inches, feet, centimeters, and meters. Measure to determine how much longer one object is than another, expressing the length difference in terms of a standard length unit.

Use addition and subtraction within 100 to solve word problems involving lengths that are given in the same unit. Represent whole numbers as lengths from 0 on a number line diagram with equally spaced points corresponding to the numbers 0, 1, 2, â€¦, and represent whole-number sums and differences within 100 on a number line diagram.

Tell and write time from analog and digital clocks to the nearest five minutes, using a.m. and p.m. Solve word problems involving collections of money, including dollar bills, quarters, dimes, nickels, and pennies. Record the total using $ and Â¢ appropriately.

Generate measurement data by measuring lengths of several objects to the nearest whole unit, or by making repeated measurements of the same object. Show the measurements by making a line plot, where the horizontal scale is marked off in whole-number units. Draw a picture graph and a bar graph (with single-unit scale) to represent a data set with up to four categories. Solve simple put-together, take-apart, and compare problems using information presented in the graph.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify and describe specified attributes of two-dimensional and three-dimensional shapes, according to the number and shape of faces, number of angles, and the number of sides and/or vertices. Draw two-dimensional shapes based on the specified attributes. Partition a rectangle into rows and columns of same-size rectangles and count to find the total number of rectangles. Partition circles and rectangles into two, three, or four equal shares, describe the shares using the words halves, thirds, fourths, half of, third of, fourth of, and describe the whole as two halves, three thirds, or four fourths. Recognize that equal shares of identical wholes need not have the same shape.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Develop mathematical practices by making sense of problems, reasoning abstractly, constructing arguments, modeling with mathematics, using appropriate tools strategically, attending to precision, looking for and making use of structure, and expressing regularity in repeated reasoning.

expectations.expectationDescription: Make sense of problems and persevere in solving them.
Reason abstractly and quantitatively.
Construct viable arguments and critique the reasoning of others.
Model with mathematics.
Use appropriate tools strategically.
Attend to precision.
Look for and make use of structure.
Look for and express regularity in repeated reasoning.

outline.title: Introduction to Operations and Algebraic Thinking

sections.sectionDescription: Introduction to basic addition and subtraction within 100 through one- and two-step word problems. Learn to represent word problems as equations using symbols for unknowns.
Practice and memorize all sums of two one-digit numbers, aiming for fluency in addition and subtraction within 20.
Determine whether groups of objects (up to 20) are odd or even. Use addition to find totals of objects arranged in rectangular arrays.
Learn that three-digit numbers represent groups of hundreds, tens, and ones. Practice counting, reading, writing, and comparing numbers up to 1000.
Use strategies based on place value and properties of operations to add and subtract within 100. Connect strategies to drawings and objects.
Explain why addition and subtraction strategies work using place value and properties of operations.
Measure objects using appropriate tools. Compare measurements using different units and estimate lengths using inches, feet, centimeters, and meters.
Use addition and subtraction to solve word problems involving lengths. Represent numbers on a number line and solve sums and differences within 100.
Tell and write time to the nearest five minutes. Solve word problems involving collections of money, using dollars and cents correctly.
Generate data by measuring lengths and display it using line plots, picture graphs, and bar graphs. Solve problems using the information presented in graphs.
Identify and describe two-dimensional and three-dimensional shapes based on their attributes. Draw shapes and partition them into equal shares, understanding terms like halves, thirds, and fourths.
Develop skills to make sense of problems and persevere in solving them.
Learn to reason abstractly and quantitatively.
Develop the ability to construct viable arguments and critique the reasoning of others.
Use mathematics to model real-world situations.
Learn to use appropriate tools strategically in mathematical contexts.
Develop precision in mathematical calculations and communication.
Recognize and use mathematical structure in various contexts.
Look for and express regularity in repeated reasoning.

outline.title: Review of Operations and Algebraic Thinking

sections.sectionDescription: Review all objectives and expectations related to Operations and Algebraic Thinking covered in previous weeks.

outline.title: Review of Number and Operations in Base Ten

sections.sectionDescription: Review all objectives and expectations related to Number and Operations in Base Ten covered in previous weeks.
Review all objectives and expectations related to Measurement and Data covered in previous weeks.
Review all objectives and expectations related to Geometry covered in previous weeks.
Review all objectives and expectations related to Mathematical Practices covered in previous weeks.
Conduct a cumulative review of all topics covered in the first half of the year.
Students work on a project that integrates various mathematical concepts learned throughout the year.
Solve more complex one- and two-step word problems involving addition and subtraction within 100.
Explore advanced place value concepts and their applications in addition and subtraction.
Solve more complex measurement problems and represent them on number lines and graphs.
Explore advanced geometric concepts and their applications.
Develop advanced problem-solving strategies and perseverance.
Practice advanced reasoning skills in abstract and quantitative contexts.
Construct and critique more complex mathematical arguments.
Create and analyze more complex mathematical models.
Use advanced tools strategically to solve complex problems.
Focus on precision in more complex mathematical contexts.
Identify and use complex mathematical structures.
Express regularity in more complex repeated reasoning contexts.
Conduct a comprehensive review of all topics covered throughout the year.
Conduct final assessments and reflect on learning outcomes and progress.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Sensemaking in science occurs with the integration of three essential dimensions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Ask questions and define problems.
Develop and use models.
Plan and carry out investigations.
Analyze and interpret data.
Use mathematics and computational thinking.
Construct explanations and design solutions.
Engage in argument from evidence.
Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Core Ideas for Knowing Science and Using Science.

expectations.expectationDescription: Physical Science
Earth and Space Science
Life Science

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop an understanding of observable properties of matter and how changes in energy (heating or cooling) can affect matter or materials.

expectations.expectationDescription: Plan and carry out an investigation to determine that matter has mass, takes up space, and is recognized by its observable properties; use the collected evidence to develop and support an explanation.
Plan and carry out investigations to gather evidence to support an explanation on how heating or cooling can cause a phase change in matter.
Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information about ways heat energy can cause change in objects or materials.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop an understanding that life on Earth depends on energy from the Sun or energy from other organisms to survive.

expectations.expectationDescription: Obtain, analyze, and communicate evidence that organisms need a source of energy, air, water, and certain temperature conditions to survive.
Develop a model representing how life on Earth depends on energy from the Sun and energy from other organisms.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop an understanding of the distribution and role of water and wind in weather, shaping the land, and where organisms live.

expectations.expectationDescription: Observe and investigate how wind and water change the shape of the land resulting in a variety of landforms.
Develop and use models to represent that water can exist in different states and is found in oceans, glaciers, lakes, rivers, ponds, and the atmosphere.
Analyze patterns in weather conditions of various regions of the world and design, test, and refine solutions to protect humans from severe weather conditions.
Construct an argument from evidence regarding positive and negative changes in water and land systems that impact humans and the environment.
Observe and explain the Sunâ€™s position at different times during a twenty-four-hour period and changes in the apparent shape of the Moon from one night to another.

Plan and carry out an investigation to determine that matter has mass, takes up space, and is recognized by its observable properties; use the collected evidence to develop and support an explanation.
Plan and carry out investigations to gather evidence to support an explanation on how heating or cooling can cause a phase change in matter.
Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information about ways heat energy can cause change in objects or materials.
Obtain, analyze, and communicate evidence that organisms need a source of energy, air, water, and certain temperature conditions to survive.
Develop a model representing how life on Earth depends on energy from the Sun and energy from other organisms.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Elements of Earth and Space Science Standards

expectations.expectationDescription: Observe and investigate how wind and water change the shape of the land resulting in a variety of landforms.
Develop and use models to represent that water can exist in different states and is found in oceans, glaciers, lakes, rivers, ponds, and the atmosphere.
Analyze patterns in weather conditions of various regions of the world and design, test, and refine solutions to protect humans from severe weather conditions.
Construct an argument from evidence regarding positive and negative changes in water and land systems that impact humans and the environment.
Observe and explain the Sunâ€™s position at different times during a twenty-four-hour period and changes in the apparent shape of the Moon from one night to another.

sections.sectionDescription: Introduction to the importance of asking scientific questions and defining problems in scientific investigation. Activities include identifying scientific questions and discussing real-world problems.
Learn about different types of scientific models and their uses. Students will create simple models to represent scientific concepts.
Focus on designing and conducting scientific investigations. Students will learn to plan experiments, make observations, and collect data.
Students will practice analyzing and interpreting data from their investigations. Emphasis on identifying patterns and drawing conclusions.
Introduction to the role of mathematics and computational thinking in science. Activities include using math to analyze data and solving problems computationally.
Learn to construct scientific explanations and design solutions based on evidence. Students will work on creating explanations for their observations.
Practice engaging in scientific argumentation using evidence. Students will debate scientific concepts and support their arguments with data.
Focus on obtaining, evaluating, and communicating scientific information. Activities include researching scientific topics and presenting findings.
Introduction to physical science concepts including matter, energy, and forces. Students will explore basic physical science principles.
Introduction to Earth and space science. Topics include Earth's systems, the solar system, and the universe.
Introduction to life science. Students will learn about living organisms, ecosystems, and the flow of energy in biological systems.
Investigate the properties of matter. Students will plan and conduct investigations to determine that matter has mass and takes up space.
Explore how heating and cooling can cause phase changes in matter. Students will conduct experiments to observe phase changes.
Learn about the effects of heat energy on objects and materials. Activities include experiments to observe heat-induced changes.
Investigate the energy needs of organisms. Students will obtain and analyze evidence showing that organisms need energy, air, water, and appropriate temperatures to survive.
Develop models representing energy flow in ecosystems. Focus on how life on Earth depends on energy from the Sun and other organisms.
Observe and investigate the impact of wind and water on landforms. Students will explore how these elements shape the Earth's surface.
Develop and use models to understand the different states and distribution of water on Earth. Activities include mapping water sources and their states.
Analyze weather patterns and design solutions to protect against severe weather. Students will study weather data and test protective measures.

sections.sectionTitle: Impact of Water and Land Systems
sections.sectionDescription: Construct arguments regarding the impact of changes in water and land systems. Focus on positive and negative effects on humans and the environment.
Observe and explain the Sunâ€™s position and the Moonâ€™s phases. Students will track and analyze changes over a 24-hour period and from night to night.
Review and reinforce concepts of matter having mass and occupying space. Students will conduct investigations and use evidence to support explanations.
Review how heating and cooling cause phase changes in matter. Students will revisit experiments and gather further evidence.
Reinforce concepts related to heat energy causing changes in objects. Students will communicate their findings and understandings.
Review the energy needs of organisms. Students will analyze and communicate their understanding of organisms' requirements for survival.
Revisit models representing energy flow in ecosystems. Students will refine their models and understand the dependence on the Sun and other organisms.

outline.title: Elements of Earth and Space Science Standards

sections.sectionTitle: Wind and Water Shaping Land Review
sections.sectionDescription: Review how wind and water change landforms. Students will investigate further and communicate their findings.

outline.title: Elements of Earth and Space Science Standards

sections.sectionDescription: Review models representing water's states and distribution. Students will update and improve their models based on new data.

outline.title: Elements of Earth and Space Science Standards

sections.sectionDescription: Reinforce understanding of weather patterns and protective solutions. Students will analyze further data and refine their solutions.

outline.title: Elements of Earth and Space Science Standards

sections.sectionTitle: Impact of Water and Land Systems Review
sections.sectionDescription: Review and construct further arguments on the impact of water and land systems. Emphasis on evidence-based reasoning.

outline.title: Elements of Earth and Space Science Standards

sections.sectionDescription: Reinforce observations and explanations of the Sun's position and Moon's phases. Students will continue tracking and analyzing changes.
Comprehensive review of the Three Dimensions of Science. Students will revisit key concepts and integrate their knowledge.
Comprehensive review of Core Ideas. Students will reinforce their understanding of physical, Earth, and life sciences.
Comprehensive review of Physical Science Standards. Students will revisit investigations and apply their knowledge to new contexts.
Comprehensive review of Life Science Standards. Focus on understanding energy flow and survival needs of organisms.

sections.sectionTitle: Earth and Space Science Standards Review
sections.sectionDescription: Comprehensive review of Earth and Space Science Standards. Students will integrate their knowledge of weather, landforms, and celestial observations.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will create imaginative artwork and investigate personal ideas through the artmaking process.

expectations.expectationDescription: Create an imaginative artwork (e.g., a work that responds to a story or invented fantasy) and add details.
Investigate personal ideas through the artmaking process.
Create artwork using a variety of artistic processes, materials, and approaches (e.g., elements and principles of modern art, applying artistic ideas from diverse cultures).
Demonstrate an understanding of the safe and proficient use of materials, tools, and equipment for a variety of artistic processes.
Individually or collaboratively construct representations, diagrams, or maps of places that are part of everyday life.
Elaborate visual information by adding details to an artwork.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will select, analyze, interpret, develop, refine, and present artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Investigate and discuss possibilities and limitations of spaces for exhibiting work.
Identify appropriate exhibit space and prepare works of art for presentation and write an artistic statement.
Identify and explain how and where different cultures record and illustrate stories and preserve history through art.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will perceive, analyze, interpret, and evaluate artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use art-specific vocabulary to speculate about processes an artist used to create a work of art.
Determine messages communicated by an image.
Interpret art by referring to contextual information and analyzing relevant subject matter, elements, and principles, and use of media.
Distinguish your preference for an artwork from your evaluation of that artwork.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will synthesize knowledge and personal experiences to make art and relate artistic ideas and works with societal, cultural, and historical context to deepen understanding.

expectations.expectationDescription: Develop a work of art based on observations of surroundings.
Recognize that responses to art change depending on knowledge of the time and place in which it was made.

sections.sectionDescription: Introduce students to the concept of imaginative artwork. Discuss how stories and fantasies can inspire art. Have students start creating their own imaginative artwork, focusing on initial ideas and basic details.
Guide students in exploring their personal ideas through the artmaking process. Encourage brainstorming and sketching of ideas that reflect their interests and experiences.
Introduce students to different artistic processes, materials, and approaches. Have students create artworks using various techniques and materials, emphasizing modern art elements and principles.

outline.title: Safe and Proficient Use of Materials

sections.sectionDescription: Teach students about the safe and proficient use of materials, tools, and equipment. Demonstrate proper handling techniques and safety protocols in the art classroom.
Engage students in collaborative art projects where they construct representations, diagrams, or maps of everyday life places. Encourage teamwork and shared creative input.
Focus on elaborating visual information by adding details to students' artworks. Teach techniques for enhancing and refining their pieces with additional elements and textures.

sections.sectionTitle: Possibilities and Limitations of Exhibit Spaces
sections.sectionDescription: Discuss various spaces for exhibiting artwork, including their possibilities and limitations. Have students investigate different venues and present their findings.
Guide students in preparing their artworks for presentation. Teach them how to choose appropriate exhibit spaces, prepare and mount their pieces, and write artistic statements.
Explore how different cultures record and illustrate stories and preserve history through art. Have students identify and explain these practices from various cultures.
Teach students art-specific vocabulary to help them speculate about the processes artists use to create their works. Conduct exercises where students describe and discuss various artworks.
Help students learn to determine messages communicated by images. Use various artworks to practice interpreting and discussing the conveyed messages.

Teach students to interpret art by referring to contextual information and analyzing relevant subject matter, elements, principles, and use of media. Have them apply these skills to specific artworks.
Guide students in distinguishing their preferences for an artwork from their evaluation of it. Conduct discussions and exercises where they critically assess various pieces.
Encourage students to develop artworks based on observations of their surroundings. Have them take notes and sketches from their environment and create art inspired by these observations.
Discuss how responses to art can change based on knowledge of the time and place in which it was made. Analyze historical and cultural contexts to deepen students' understanding of artworks.
Review the objectives and expectations of the 'Creating' section. Have students practice creating imaginative artworks and exploring personal ideas.
Review the objectives and expectations of the 'Presenting' section. Have students practice selecting, analyzing, and presenting their artworks.
Review the objectives and expectations of the 'Responding' section. Have students practice perceiving, analyzing, interpreting, and evaluating artistic works.
Review the objectives and expectations of the 'Connecting' section. Have students practice synthesizing knowledge and personal experiences to make art.
Advance students' skills in creating detailed imaginative artwork. Focus on more complex ideas and intricate details.
Deepen the exploration of personal ideas through more complex and refined artmaking processes.
Expand on different artistic processes, materials, and approaches. Encourage students to experiment with advanced techniques.
Reinforce safe and proficient use of materials, tools, and equipment with more advanced art projects.
Engage students in more complex collaborative art projects, focusing on detailed representations and creative teamwork.
Focus on adding intricate and advanced details to students' artworks, enhancing their visual storytelling.
Investigate more advanced possibilities and limitations of exhibit spaces, encouraging creative solutions.
Guide students in preparing more sophisticated artworks for presentation, including advanced artistic statements.
Deepen the analysis of how different cultures record and illustrate stories and preserve history through art.
Expand students' art-specific vocabulary to discuss more complex artistic processes and techniques.
Practice interpreting more complex messages communicated by images, using advanced analysis techniques.
Teach advanced skills in contextual analysis of artworks, focusing on deeper subject matter and principles.
Guide students in advanced evaluation techniques, distinguishing preferences from critical assessments.
Encourage students to create more advanced artworks based on detailed observations of their surroundings.
Deepen the discussion on how responses to art change based on historical and cultural knowledge.
Assist students in preparing their final art projects, incorporating all the skills and knowledge acquired throughout the course.
Have students present their final projects, discussing their creative process, techniques used, and the messages behind their artworks.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will understand the components and interactions within computing systems.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify how internal and external parts of computing devices function to form a system within a single device and hardware that connects to the device to extend capability.
Recognize that hardware (devices) and software (programs/apps) communicate in a special language that the computing system can understand.
Recognize that hardware (devices) can only accomplish the specific tasks the software (programs/apps) is designed to accomplish.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will understand the concepts of networks and the internet, including cybersecurity.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify real-world cybersecurity problems and how personal information can be protected.
Model how information flows in a physical or wireless path to travel to be sent and received through a physical or wireless path.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will understand data collection, storage, and analysis techniques.

expectations.expectationDescription: Select tools from a specified list to collect, organize, and present data visually to highlight relationships and support a claim.
Recognize different file extensions.
Use a computational tool to draw conclusions, make predictions, and answer questions utilizing a specified data set.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will understand basic algorithms and programming concepts.

expectations.expectationDescription: Recognize and compare multiple algorithms for the same task and determine which are effective.
Create programs that use variables to store and modify data.
Decompose problems into smaller, manageable subproblems to facilitate the program development process.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will understand the social and ethical implications of computing.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify computing technologies that have changed the world.
With teacher guidance, brainstorm ways to improve the accessibility and usability of technology products for the diverse needs and wants of users.

sections.sectionDescription: Introducing students to the components and interactions within computing systems.
Exploring how hardware and software communicate using a special language.
Understanding that hardware can only accomplish specific tasks designed by software.
Exploring basic concepts of networks and the internet.
Identifying real-world cybersecurity problems and protection methods.
Modeling how information flows in physical or wireless paths.
Selecting tools to collect, organize, and present data visually.
Understanding and recognizing different file extensions.
Utilizing computational tools to draw conclusions, make predictions, and answer questions.
Recognizing and comparing multiple algorithms for effectiveness.
Creating programs that use variables to store and modify data.

outline.title: Problem Decomposition and Impacts of Computing

sections.sectionDescription: Breaking down problems into smaller, manageable subproblems to facilitate program development.
Identifying computing technologies that have had a significant impact on the world.
Brainstorming ways to enhance the accessibility and usability of technology products.
Reviewing concepts and expectations covered in weeks 1-4.
Reviewing concepts and expectations covered in weeks 5-8.
Reviewing concepts and expectations covered in weeks 9-12.
Reviewing concepts and expectations covered in weeks 13-16.
Reviewing concepts and expectations covered in weeks 17-20.
Exploring advanced topics in computing systems based on student interests and understanding.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students leverage technology to actively pursue and achieve their learning goals.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students, with guidance, will identify and use digital learning tools or resources to set learning goals.
Students reflect on learning experiences to improve future performance.
Students extend their learning environment to include online collaborative spaces and customize their environments through choice in learning and expression.
Students seek feedback and create artifacts using age-appropriate digital tools to demonstrate learning.
Students transfer digital skills to different tools or learning environments and apply prior knowledge to understand new technologies.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students understand and practice safe, legal, and ethical behavior in the digital world.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students understand the components of digital identities and explore privacy settings for various platforms.
Students demonstrate appropriate use of technology and communicate thoughtfully and respectfully online.
Students identify and discuss laws and rules related to intellectual property, including copyright and fair use.
Students understand personal data, privacy policies, and make informed decisions about technology use.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students critically evaluate and curate digital resources to construct knowledge and solve problems.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students employ appropriate research techniques and gather information from multiple digital sources to build knowledge.
Students evaluate sources for accuracy, perspective, credibility, and relevance using multiple criteria.
Students use digital tools to collect, organize, and make connections between information from various resources.
Students explore real-world problems, collaborate with others, and propose solutions using technology.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students use technology to identify and solve problems through the design process.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students explore and engage in a design process to generate and test ideas, developing innovative products.
Students use digital and/or non-digital tools to plan, manage, and engage in a design process.
Students design and create prototypes, engage in trial and error, and reflect on the design process.
Students demonstrate perseverance when working with open-ended problems, seeking feedback and evaluating solutions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students use technology to understand and solve problems efficiently.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students identify problems that can be solved efficiently through the use of technology and algorithmic thinking.
Students use digital tools to represent and organize data, analyze patterns, and propose solutions.
Students break down problems, identify key information, and propose solutions using digital tools.
Students understand and explore basic concepts related to automation, patterns, and algorithmic thinking.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students communicate effectively and creatively using digital media and tools.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students recognize and utilize features of creation or communication tools to produce and publish information.
Students create original works, repurpose and remix content responsibly, and communicate ideas visually, graphically, and/or auditorily.
Students consider the intended audience when creating and publishing digital artifacts, following basic copyright guidelines.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students collaborate effectively with others locally and globally using digital tools.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students use digital tools to work with other learners from diverse backgrounds and cultures, using communication tools to break down barriers.
Students use technology to connect with peers, experts, and community members to explore different perspectives.
Students take on various team roles, contribute knowledge, and participate in online collaborative projects.
Students use digital resources to collaborate with authentic audiences, examine global issues, and propose solutions.

sections.sectionDescription: In this section, students will explore various digital learning tools and resources available to them. They will learn how to identify and select appropriate tools to set their learning goals.
Students will reflect on their past learning experiences, identifying strengths and areas for improvement. They will develop strategies to enhance their future performance.
Students will explore online collaborative spaces and learn to customize their learning environments. They will practice collaborating with peers and sharing ideas.
Students will have the opportunity to customize their learning environments based on their interests and preferences. They will exercise choice in learning and expression.
Students will learn the importance of seeking feedback to improve their work. They will create artifacts using digital tools and seek feedback from peers and teachers.
Students will demonstrate their learning by creating digital artifacts that showcase their understanding of concepts. They will utilize age-appropriate digital tools for this purpose.
Students will apply their prior knowledge of digital skills to understand and utilize new technologies. They will practice transferring skills learned in one tool or environment to another.
Students will explore different digital tools and learning environments, adapting their skills to effectively use these technologies for various purposes.
Students will explore the components of digital identities, including online profiles and presence. They will learn about the importance of managing their digital footprint.
Students will examine privacy settings for various online platforms and learn strategies to protect their personal information online.
Students will discuss the importance of practicing ethical behavior online, including respectful communication and responsible use of technology.
Students will learn effective communication strategies for online interactions, emphasizing empathy, and understanding diverse perspectives.
Students will explore laws and rules related to intellectual property, including copyright and fair use. They will learn how to respect the rights of content creators.
Students will discuss the concepts of copyright and fair use, understanding their implications for using digital content ethically.
Students will explore personal data and privacy policies associated with various online platforms. They will learn how to make informed decisions about sharing personal information.
Students will develop critical thinking skills to evaluate privacy policies and make informed decisions about their online activities.
Students will learn research techniques to gather information from multiple digital sources. They will practice evaluating the credibility and relevance of sources.
Students will use gathered information to construct knowledge on various topics. They will organize information using digital tools.
Students will develop criteria to evaluate sources for accuracy, perspective, and credibility. They will apply these criteria to assess the reliability of digital resources.
Students will engage in critical thinking exercises to analyze information from multiple sources. They will identify biases and evaluate conflicting viewpoints.
Students will explore various digital tools for organizing information, such as note-taking apps and mind mapping software. They will learn to use these tools to manage and structure their research.
Students will practice organizing and categorizing information using digital tools. They will develop effective strategies for storing and retrieving information.
Students will learn to identify real-world problems that can be addressed through the design process. They will analyze challenges and brainstorm potential solutions.

Students will explore the design thinking process, including stages such as empathizing, defining, ideating, prototyping, and testing. They will apply this process to solve problems using digital tools.
Students will learn to plan design projects, setting objectives, timelines, and resource requirements. They will develop project management skills using digital tools.
Students will collaborate with peers on design projects, assigning roles and responsibilities. They will use digital platforms to communicate and coordinate their efforts.
Students will design and create prototypes of their solutions using digital and/or non-digital tools. They will refine their prototypes based on feedback and testing.
Students will conduct user testing to gather feedback on their prototypes. They will analyze the results and make revisions to improve their designs.
Students will reflect on their design process, identifying successes and areas for improvement. They will iterate on their designs based on self-assessment and peer feedback.
Students will develop a mindset of continuous improvement, seeking opportunities to refine their designs and solutions. They will embrace feedback as a tool for growth.
Students will learn about algorithms as sequences of instructions used to solve problems. They will analyze simple algorithms and predict their outcomes.
Students will apply algorithmic thinking to solve problems in various contexts. They will break down complex tasks into smaller steps and develop algorithms to solve them.
Students will learn techniques for representing and organizing data using digital tools. They will explore different data formats and visualization methods.
Students will analyze patterns and trends in data sets, using digital tools to identify correlations and insights. They will draw conclusions based on their analysis.
Students will practice problem decomposition, breaking down complex problems into smaller, more manageable subproblems. They will identify patterns and similarities among subproblems.
Students will identify key information required to solve a problem. They will learn to distinguish between relevant and irrelevant data.
Students will learn about automation and its role in solving problems efficiently. They will explore examples of automation in everyday life and its impact on society.
Students will examine patterns in data and processes, identifying opportunities for automation. They will understand how algorithms can be used to automate tasks.
Students will explore features of creation tools such as graphics software, video editors, and presentation tools. They will learn to utilize these features to produce engaging content.
Students will learn principles of effective communication, including audience awareness, clarity, and creativity. They will practice applying these principles in digital media.
Students will create original digital works such as videos, presentations, or artworks. They will explore techniques for generating ideas and expressing themselves creatively.
Students will learn about responsible content use, including copyright laws and fair use guidelines. They will practice citing sources and giving credit for reused content.
Students will explore techniques for repurposing digital content, such as remixing videos or adapting images. They will learn to transform existing content into new, creative works.
Students will discuss ethical considerations when remixing content, including respecting original creators' rights and permissions. They will learn to remix content responsibly and ethically.
Students will learn techniques for visual communication, including graphic design principles and visual storytelling. They will create visual content to effectively convey ideas and messages.
Students will consider their audience when creating visual content, tailoring their designs to meet audience needs and preferences. They will practice audience-centric communication strategies.

Students will explore digital collaboration tools such as video conferencing platforms, online project management tools, and shared document editors. They will learn to use these tools for global collaboration.

Students will learn strategies for effective cross-cultural communication, considering cultural differences and sensitivities. They will practice communicating respectfully with peers from diverse backgrounds.
Students will connect with peers from different regions and cultures, building global networks for collaboration and learning. They will exchange ideas and perspectives on global issues.

Students will participate in virtual exchange programs, engaging in collaborative projects with peers from around the world. They will explore cultural similarities and differences through shared experiences.

Students will collaborate with global peers on team projects, applying project management principles to coordinate tasks and deadlines. They will use digital tools for communication and task tracking.
Students will develop skills for effective teamwork, including leadership, conflict resolution, and task delegation. They will learn to work collaboratively in multicultural teams.
Students will engage with authentic audiences, such as experts, community members, or public audiences. They will present their work and receive feedback from diverse perspectives.

Students will prepare and deliver public presentations, sharing their ideas and solutions with a wider audience. They will practice effective communication techniques to engage and inform their audience.
Students will explore global issues such as climate change, poverty, or human rights. They will research these issues and analyze their causes and impacts on local and global communities.
Students will brainstorm potential solutions to global challenges, considering different perspectives and approaches. They will develop innovative solutions using technology and collaboration.
Students will review objectives and expectations related to the Empowered Learner strand from Weeks 1 to 7. They will reflect on their progress and identify areas for improvement.

Students will review objectives and expectations related to the Digital Citizen strand from Weeks 1 to 7. They will discuss ethical behavior online and strategies for safe and responsible technology use.

Students will review objectives and expectations related to the Knowledge Constructor strand from Weeks 1 to 7. They will practice evaluating sources and constructing knowledge from digital resources.
Students will review objectives and expectations related to the Innovative Designer strand from Weeks 8 to 14. They will reflect on their design process and iterate on their prototypes.
Students will review objectives and expectations related to the Computational Thinker strand from Weeks 8 to 14. They will revisit algorithms, data representation, and problem-solving techniques.

Students will review objectives and expectations related to the Creative Communicator strand from Weeks 15 to 21. They will reflect on their communication skills and explore new ways to express ideas digitally.

Students will review objectives and expectations related to the Global Collaborator strand from Weeks 15 to 21. They will reflect on their global collaboration experiences and consider the impact of their work on a global scale.
Students will identify social issues affecting their communities or the world at large. They will research these issues and consider how technology can be used to address them.
Students will brainstorm and design innovative solutions to social problems using technology. They will consider the needs of diverse stakeholders and the potential impact of their solutions.
Students will develop detailed plans for their social impact projects, outlining objectives, timelines, and resource requirements. They will consider factors such as feasibility and sustainability.
Students will create prototypes of their social impact solutions, testing their functionality and usability. They will iterate on their designs based on feedback and testing results.
Students will implement their social impact projects, following their project plans and refining their prototypes. They will collaborate with stakeholders and gather feedback throughout the process.
Students will evaluate the effectiveness of their social impact projects, assessing their impact on target communities or populations. They will identify strengths and areas for improvement.

Students will prepare presentations to share their social impact projects with peers, educators, and community members. They will effectively communicate the goals, process, and outcomes of their projects.
Students will advocate for their social impact causes, raising awareness and mobilizing support. They will use digital platforms and communication tools to reach a wider audience.

Students will reflect on their social impact projects, considering their achievements, challenges, and lessons learned. They will celebrate their accomplishments and the positive impact of their work.

Students will celebrate the conclusion of the course, reflecting on their overall learning journey and growth as empowered digital citizens. They will share highlights from their favorite activities and projects.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Grade 3 expectations in this domain are limited to whole number multiplication through 10 x 10 and whole number division with both quotients and divisors less than or equal to 10.

expectations.expectationDescription: Interpret products of whole numbers as the total number of objects in equal groups.
Interpret whole number quotients of whole numbers.
Use multiplication and division within 100 to solve word problems in various situations.
Determine the unknown whole number in a multiplication or division equation relating three whole numbers.
Apply properties of operations as strategies to multiply and divide.
Understand division as an unknown-factor problem.
Fluently multiply and divide within 100.
Solve two-step word problems using the four operations.
Identify patterns in the addition table and the multiplication table and explain them using properties of operations.
Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Number and Operations in Base Ten (NBT)
objectives.objectiveDescription: A range of algorithms may be used.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use place value understanding to round whole numbers.
Fluently add and subtract within 1000.
Multiply one-digit whole numbers by multiples of 10.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Grade 3 expectations are limited to fractions with denominators: 2,3,4,6,8.

expectations.expectationDescription: Understand fractions as numbers.
Represent fractions on a number line diagram.
Explain equivalence of fractions in special cases, and compare fractions by reasoning about their size.
Tell and write time to the nearest minute and measure time intervals in minutes.
Measure and estimate liquid volumes and masses of objects using metric units.
Create and interpret scaled picture graphs and scaled bar graphs.
Generate measurement data by measuring lengths and show the data by making a line plot.
Understand concepts of area and perimeter.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

expectations.expectationDescription: Understand that shapes in different categories may share attributes.
Partition shapes into parts with equal areas.
Make sense of problems and persevere in solving them.
Reason abstractly and quantitatively.
Construct viable arguments and critique the reasoning of others.
Model with mathematics.
Use appropriate tools strategically.
Attend to precision.
Look for and make use of structure.
Look for and express regularity in repeated reasoning.

sections.sectionDescription: Students will apply multiplication and division within 100 to solve word problems in various situations. They will also determine the unknown whole number in multiplication or division equations relating three whole numbers.
This section focuses on applying properties of operations as strategies to multiply and divide.
Students will practice fluently multiplying and dividing within 100.
In this section, students will solve two-step word problems using the four operations.
Students will identify patterns in the addition table and the multiplication table and explain them using properties of operations.

outline.title: Reasonableness of Answers and Division Concepts

sections.sectionDescription: This section focuses on assessing the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies.
Students will understand division as an unknown-factor problem.

outline.title: Introduction to Number and Operations in Base Ten (NBT)

sections.sectionDescription: In this section, students will use place value understanding to round whole numbers.
Students will practice fluently adding and subtracting within 1000.

sections.sectionTitle: Multiplying One-Digit Numbers by Multiples of 10
sections.sectionDescription: This section focuses on multiplying one-digit whole numbers by multiples of 10.

outline.title: Introduction to Number and Operations â€“ Fractions (NF)

sections.sectionDescription: In this section, students will understand fractions as numbers.
Students will represent fractions on a number line diagram.
This section focuses on explaining equivalence of fractions in special cases.
Students will compare fractions by reasoning about their size.
In this section, students will tell and write time to the nearest minute and measure time intervals in minutes.
Students will measure and estimate liquid volumes and masses of objects using metric units.
This section focuses on creating and interpreting scaled picture graphs and scaled bar graphs.
Students will generate measurement data by measuring lengths and show the data by making a line plot.
In this section, students will understand concepts of area and perimeter.
This section focuses on understanding that shapes in different categories may share attributes.
Students will learn to partition shapes into parts with equal areas.
In this section, students will make sense of problems and persevere in solving them.
Students will reason abstractly and quantitatively, and construct viable arguments and critique the reasoning of others.
This section focuses on modeling real-world situations with mathematics.
Students will attend to precision in mathematical communication.

sections.sectionDescription: In this section, students will use appropriate tools strategically to solve mathematical problems.
Students will look for and make use of structure in mathematical problems.
This week will be dedicated to reviewing the objectives covered in Operations and Algebraic Thinking (OA).

sections.sectionDescription: This week will be dedicated to reviewing the objectives covered in Number and Operations in Base Ten (NBT).

sections.sectionDescription: This week will be dedicated to reviewing the objectives covered in Number and Operations â€“ Fractions (NF).

sections.sectionDescription: This week will be dedicated to continued review of the objectives covered in Operations and Algebraic Thinking (OA).

outline.title: Final Review and Preparation for Assessments

sections.sectionDescription: This week will be dedicated to a comprehensive review of all objectives covered throughout the course.
This week will involve assessing students' understanding of all objectives covered in the course.
Students will receive targeted remediation based on their assessment results to address any areas of weakness.
Students will plan and design a project incorporating concepts from all areas covered in the course.
Students will implement their project plans, applying mathematical concepts and skills learned throughout the course.
Students will present their projects to the class, demonstrating their understanding and application of mathematical concepts.
Students will reflect on their project experience and provide feedback on their peers' presentations.
This week will focus on integrating technology tools to further explore and apply mathematical concepts.
Students will explore real-world applications of the mathematical concepts they have learned, connecting theory to practice.
This week will be dedicated to reflecting on the course as a whole, celebrating achievements, and setting goals for future learning.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Sensemaking in science occurs with the integration of three essential dimensions.

expectations.expectationDescription: ask questions and define problems
develop and use models
plan and carry out investigations
analyze and interpret data
use mathematics and computational thinking
construct explanations and design solutions
engage in argument from evidence
obtain, evaluate, and communicate information

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop an understanding of crosscutting concepts in science.

expectations.expectationDescription: patterns
cause and effect
structure and function
systems and system models
stability and change
scale, proportion, and quantity
energy and matter

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop an understanding of core ideas in science.

expectations.expectationDescription: Physical Science
Earth and Space Science
Life Science

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop an understanding of physical science standards.

expectations.expectationDescription: Ask questions and investigate the relationship between light, objects, and the human eye.
Plan and carry out an investigation to explore how sound waves affect objects at varying distances.
Develop and use models to describe how light and sound waves transfer energy.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop an understanding of earth and space science standards.

expectations.expectationDescription: Construct an explanation describing how the Sun is the primary source of energy impacting Earth systems.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop an understanding of life science standards.

expectations.expectationDescription: Develop and use models to explain that plants and animals (including humans) have internal and external structures that serve various functions that aid in growth, survival, behavior, and reproduction.
Plan and carry out investigations to demonstrate ways plants and animals react to stimuli.
Develop and use system models to describe the flow of energy from the Sun to and among living organisms.
Construct an argument from evidence that organisms are interdependent.

outline.title: Introduction to Science and Asking Questions

sections.sectionDescription: Introduction to the three dimensions of science and the importance of integrating them for sensemaking.
Learn how to ask scientific questions and define problems to investigate.
Understand how to develop and use models to represent scientific phenomena.
Learn how to plan and conduct scientific investigations.
Learn techniques for analyzing and interpreting scientific data.
Apply mathematical concepts and computational thinking in scientific contexts.
Learn how to construct scientific explanations and design solutions to problems.
Practice engaging in scientific arguments using evidence.
Learn how to obtain, evaluate, and communicate scientific information effectively.
Develop an understanding of crosscutting concepts that link different domains of science.
Identify and analyze patterns in scientific phenomena.
Understand the cause and effect relationships in scientific processes.
Learn about the relationship between structure and function in various systems.
Understand systems and how models can represent system behaviors.
Explore the concepts of stability and change in scientific systems.
Learn about the significance of scale, proportion, and quantity in scientific contexts.
Understand the concepts of energy and matter and their roles in scientific processes.
Introduction to the core ideas in physical science, earth and space science, and life science.
Develop an understanding of the fundamental concepts in physical science.
Develop an understanding of the fundamental concepts in earth and space science.
Develop an understanding of the fundamental concepts in life science.
Introduction to physical science standards and their applications.

outline.title: Light, Objects, and the Human Eye

sections.sectionDescription: Investigate the relationship between light, objects, and the human eye.
Explore how sound waves affect objects at varying distances.
Describe how light and sound waves transfer energy.
Introduction to earth and space science standards and their significance.

outline.title: Sun as the Primary Energy Source

sections.sectionDescription: Explain how the Sun is the primary source of energy impacting Earth systems.
Introduction to life science standards and their applications.

outline.title: Internal and External Structures in Organisms

sections.sectionDescription: Explain how internal and external structures serve various functions in organisms.
Demonstrate how plants and animals react to various stimuli.
Describe the flow of energy from the Sun to and among living organisms.
Construct an argument from evidence that organisms are interdependent.

sections.sectionTitle: Review of Three Dimensions of Science
sections.sectionDescription: Review the integration of the three dimensions of science and key concepts covered so far.
Review crosscutting concepts and their application in different scientific contexts.

sections.sectionTitle: Review of Core Ideas in Science
sections.sectionDescription: Review the core ideas in physical science, earth and space science, and life science.
Review the physical science standards and key concepts.

sections.sectionTitle: Review of Earth and Space Science Standards
sections.sectionDescription: Review the earth and space science standards and key concepts.
Review the life science standards and key concepts.
Comprehensive review of all science standards covered throughout the course.
Comprehensive review of all science standards covered throughout the course.
Comprehensive review of all science standards covered throughout the course.
Comprehensive review of all science standards covered throughout the course.
Final review of all topics and preparation for end-of-course assessment.
Conduct final assessments to evaluate students' understanding of all standards.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Generate and Conceptualize Artistic Ideas

expectations.expectationDescription: Independently brainstorm multiple approaches to solve a creative art or design problem.
Collaboratively set goals and create artwork that is meaningful and has purpose to the makers (e.g., individual works with a similar purpose or group work with shared goals).
Develop technical skills and explore art-making approaches (e.g., using elements and principles of modern art, applying artistic norms of diverse cultures).
When making works of art, utilize and care for materials, tools, and equipment, and practice safe and responsible digital posting/sharing with awareness of image ownership.
Describe and visually represent regional constructed environments (e.g., school, playground, park, street, store).
Revise artwork in progress on the basis of insights gained through peer discussion.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Select, Analyze, and Interpret Artistic Work for Performance

expectations.expectationDescription: Analyze how past, present, and emerging technologies have impacted the presentation of artwork (e.g., photographic/digital reproductions, posters, postcards, printouts, photocopies).

Analyze the various considerations for presenting and protecting art (e.g., the work of indigenous peoples in archeological sites or museums, indoor or outdoor public art in various settings, other art in temporary or permanent forms both in physical or digital formats).
Compare purposes of exhibiting art in virtual museums, art museums, art galleries, community art centers, or other venues (e.g., school lobbies, bulletin boards, local businesses).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Perceive and Analyze Artistic Work

expectations.expectationDescription: Use art-specific vocabulary compare responses to a work of art before and after working in similar media.
Analyze components (e.g., elements and principles in modern art, visual traditions of indigenous peoples) in imagery that convey messages.

Interpret art by referring to contextual information and analyzing relevant subject matter, use of media, and elements and principles, or artistic norms of the culture within which the artwork is made.
Evaluate an artwork based on given criteria (e.g., realism, usefulness, expressiveness, formal excellence, craftsmanship).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Synthesize and Relate Knowledge and Personal Experiences to Make Art

expectations.expectationDescription: Create a work of art that reflects community or cultural traditions.
Through observation, infer information about time, place, and culture in which a work of art was created (e.g., examining genre scenes, cityscapes, portraits from different eras).

sections.sectionDescription: Introduce students to brainstorming techniques for solving creative art or design problems independently.
Guide students in setting collaborative goals and creating meaningful artwork with shared purposes.
Teach students technical skills and art-making approaches, incorporating elements and principles of modern art and diverse cultures.

outline.title: Using and Caring for Art Materials

sections.sectionDescription: Instruct students on the proper use and care of art materials, tools, and equipment, and the importance of responsible digital sharing.
Help students describe and visually represent regional constructed environments such as schools, playgrounds, and parks.
Facilitate peer discussions and guide students in revising their artwork based on feedback received.

outline.title: Impact of Technology on Art Presentation

sections.sectionDescription: Analyze how past, present, and emerging technologies have influenced the presentation of artwork.
Discuss the various considerations for presenting and protecting art, including the work of indigenous peoples and public art.
Compare the purposes of exhibiting art in different venues such as virtual museums, galleries, and community centers.
Introduce art-specific vocabulary and compare responses to artwork before and after working in similar media.
Analyze components in imagery, such as elements and principles of modern art, to understand the messages conveyed.
Interpret art by analyzing contextual information, subject matter, media use, and cultural artistic norms.
Evaluate artworks based on given criteria such as realism, usefulness, expressiveness, and craftsmanship.
Create artworks that reflect community or cultural traditions, incorporating observed elements.
Through observation, infer information about the time, place, and culture in which a work of art was created.

Review the development of technical skills and exploration of different art-making approaches.
Review proper use and care of materials and tools, and discuss digital posting/sharing responsibilities.

Review the process of revising artwork based on peer feedback.
Review how different technologies have impacted the presentation of art.

Review the interpretation of art using contextual information and cultural norms.
Review the criteria for evaluating different artworks.

Review the process of inferring information about time, place, and culture from artworks.
