objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will understand computing devices, their internal and external parts, and how they connect to form systems.

expectations.expectationDescription: With teacher guidance, model how internal and external parts of computing connect multiple devices in a computing system.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will understand the basic unit of data in computing, the relationship between hardware and software, and troubleshooting strategies.

expectations.expectationDescription: Recognize that bits serve as the basic unit of data in computing systems and can represent a variety of information.
Recognize that a single piece of hardware can accomplish different tasks depending on its software.
Develop and apply simple troubleshooting strategies to solve simple hardware and software problems.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will understand cybersecurity, network communication, organization, and data transmission.

expectations.expectationDescription: Discuss real-world cybersecurity problems and how personal information can be protected.
Model how information is decomposed, transmitted as packets through multiple devices over networks, and reassembled at the destination.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will understand data collection, storage, inference, and modeling.

expectations.expectationDescription: Select tools to collect, organize, and present data visually to highlight relationships and support a claim.
Recognize different file extensions and the different amounts of storage required for each type.
Use a computational tool to manipulate data to draw conclusions, make predictions, and answer questions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will understand algorithms, variables, control structures, modularity, program development, and intellectual property.

expectations.expectationDescription: Compare and refine multiple algorithms for the same task and determine which is the most effective.
Create programs that use variables to store and modify data.
Create programs that include sequences, events, loops, and/or conditionals.
Decompose problems into smaller, manageable subproblems to facilitate the program development process.
Use an iterative process to plan the development of a program by including others' perspectives and considering user preferences.
Observe intellectual property rights and give appropriate attribution when creating or remixing programs.
Test and debug a program/app or algorithm to ensure it runs as intended.
With teacher guidance, students take on varying roles when collaborating with peers during the design, implementation, and review stages of program development.
Describe choices made during program development using code comments, presentations, and/or demonstrations.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will understand the cultural, social, and ethical impacts of computing.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify and discuss computing technologies that have changed the world.
Brainstorm ways to improve the accessibility and usability of technology products for the diverse needs and wants of users.
Seek opportunities for local and national collaboration to facilitate communication and innovation.
Use material that is publicly available and/or permissible to use.

sections.sectionDescription: Introduce students to computing devices, their internal and external parts, and how they form systems. Discuss the basic components and their functions.
With teacher guidance, model how internal and external parts of computing connect multiple devices in a computing system. Include hands-on activities.
Explain that bits serve as the basic unit of data in computing systems and can represent a variety of information. Use visual aids and examples.
Discuss how a single piece of hardware can accomplish different tasks depending on its software. Provide real-world examples.
Develop and apply simple troubleshooting strategies to solve hardware and software problems. Conduct troubleshooting simulations.
Introduce students to network communication, organization, and data transmission. Discuss the basics of how networks operate.
Discuss real-world cybersecurity problems and how personal information can be protected. Provide examples of good cybersecurity practices.
Model how information is decomposed, transmitted as packets through multiple devices over networks, and reassembled at the destination. Use demonstrations.
Teach students to select tools to collect, organize, and present data visually to highlight relationships and support a claim. Use data collection projects.
Recognize different file extensions and the different amounts of storage required for each type. Provide examples of various file types and their uses.
Use a computational tool to manipulate data to draw conclusions, make predictions, and answer questions. Implement small projects to practice these skills.
Compare and refine multiple algorithms for the same task and determine which is the most effective. Discuss what makes an algorithm effective.
Create programs that use variables to store and modify data. Provide coding exercises to practice using variables.
Create programs that include sequences, events, loops, and/or conditionals. Use coding exercises to demonstrate these concepts.
Decompose problems into smaller, manageable subproblems to facilitate the program development process. Provide examples of problem decomposition.
Use an iterative process to plan the development of a program by including others' perspectives and considering user preferences. Conduct group projects.
Observe intellectual property rights and give appropriate attribution when creating or remixing programs. Discuss the importance of intellectual property.
Test and debug a program/app or algorithm to ensure it runs as intended. Conduct debugging exercises.
With teacher guidance, students take on varying roles when collaborating with peers during the design, implementation, and review stages of program development. Conduct collaborative coding projects.
Describe choices made during program development using code comments, presentations, and/or demonstrations. Provide examples of good documentation practices.
Identify and discuss computing technologies that have changed the world. Provide historical and modern examples.
Brainstorm ways to improve the accessibility and usability of technology products for the diverse needs and wants of users. Conduct group discussions and projects.
Seek opportunities for local and national collaboration to facilitate communication and innovation. Discuss the benefits of collaboration in computing.
Use material that is publicly available and/or permissible to use. Discuss the importance of using legal resources and provide examples.
Review and reinforce the concepts covered in Weeks 1-6. Use quizzes, discussions, and practical exercises.
Review and reinforce the concepts covered in Weeks 7-12. Use quizzes, discussions, and practical exercises.
Review and reinforce the concepts covered in Weeks 13-18. Use quizzes, discussions, and practical exercises.
Review and reinforce the concepts covered in Weeks 19-24. Use quizzes, discussions, and practical exercises.
Start a collaborative project that incorporates elements from multiple objectives. Focus on planning and initial development.
Continue working on the collaborative project, focusing on development and iteration. Encourage peer feedback and collaboration.
Finalize the collaborative project, focusing on testing, debugging, and documentation. Prepare for project presentations.
Students present their collaborative projects, demonstrating their learning and development process. Encourage questions and feedback.
Review and reinforce key concepts from the entire course. Use comprehensive quizzes, discussions, and practical exercises.
Prepare students for the final assessment by reviewing key topics and practicing test-taking strategies.
Conduct the final assessment covering all course objectives. Ensure students understand the format and expectations.
Reflect on the course, discuss what was learned, and gather student feedback. Celebrate achievements and discuss future learning opportunities.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students leverage technology to take an active role in choosing, achieving, and demonstrating competency in their learning goals, informed by the learning sciences.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students, with guidance, will identify, and use digital learning tools or resources to set learning goals.
Students reflect on learning experiences for the purpose of improving future performance.
Students, with guidance, extend their learning environment to include online collaborative spaces, such as collaborative documents, sites, or video conferencing.
Students seek digital or human feedback by utilizing built-in features within digital tools and online programs. (Spell check, grammar check, comments, etc.)
Students transfer digital skills to other devices or programs (e.g., how to format text across multiple applications, restarting devices or programs).
Students understand the components of digital identities and digital footprints.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students recognize the rights, responsibilities, and opportunities of living, learning, and working in an interconnected digital world, and they act and model in ways that are safe, legal, and ethical.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students demonstrate appropriate use of technology and explain the importance of responsible technology use.
Students communicate thoughtfully, respectfully, and authentically in all digital interactions.
Students, with guidance, identify, explore, and discuss laws and rules that apply to print and digital content (e.g., copyright law, fair use guidelines, Creative Commons licenses).

Students demonstrate an understanding of their responsibility to keep their personal data private (e.g., creating strong passwords and keeping phone number, address, parentâ€™s name, birth date private).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students critically curate a variety of resources using digital tools to construct knowledge, produce creative artifacts, and make meaningful learning experiences for themselves and others.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students demonstrate an understanding of the functionality of a search engine, then gather, organize, and summarize information from multiple digital learning tools and resources to build knowledge of a topic.
Students use multiple criteria to differentiate between relevant and irrelevant information found with digital tools and resources.
Students use digital tools to collect and organize information based on relationships and themes.
Students work collaboratively using technology to identify and analyze a solution to a problem.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students use a variety of technologies within a design process to identify and solve problems by creating new, useful or imaginative solutions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students, with guidance, explore and engage in a design process for generating and testing ideas and developing innovative products to solve problems.
Students use digital and/or non-digital tools to organize the design process (e.g., brainstorm, graphic organizer, storyboard).
Students design and create prototypes and engage in trial and error to refine them.
Students apply effort and persistence when solving open-ended problems.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop and employ strategies for understanding and solving problems in ways that leverage the power of technological methods to develop and test solutions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students identify problems that can be solved more efficiently through the use of technology and algorithmic thinking.
Students, with guidance, collect data from a variety of sources and analyze data using digital tools to identify patterns and/or draw conclusions.
Students, with guidance, break complex problems into a series of smaller, more manageable problems.
Students define an algorithm as a sequence of instructions or rules to follow.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students communicate clearly and express themselves creatively for a variety of purposes using the platforms, tools, styles, formats, and digital media appropriate to their goals.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students identify appropriate digital learning tools and resources to produce and publish information to communicate with others.
Students combine existing and new digital assets to create new products.
Students create digital visualizations (e.g., infographics, word clouds, data maps), models (e.g., concept maps, flowcharts), and simulations.
Students, with guidance, select a digital tool that most effectively conveys a message for the targeted audience.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students use digital tools to broaden their perspectives and enrich their learning by collaborating with others and working effectively in teams locally and globally.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students, with guidance, use synchronous and asynchronous communication tools to connect with others from diverse cultures and geographic areas.
Students utilize a variety of synchronous and asynchronous tools to communicate and learn from others.
Students engage in online collaborative projects with students in other classrooms and schools.
Students use digital resources to collaborate with authentic audiences to further learning, examine a global issue, and/or develop solutions.

sections.sectionDescription: Review the key concepts and skills learned in the Creative Communicator and Global Collaborator standards.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use the four operations with whole numbers to solve problems.

expectations.expectationDescription: Represent verbal statements of multiplicative comparisons as multiplication equations. Interpret a multiplication equation as a comparison (e.g., 35 is the number of objects in 5 groups, each containing 7 objects, and is also the number of objects in 7 groups, each containing 5 objects).

Multiply or divide within 1000 to solve word problems involving multiplicative comparison (e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem, distinguishing multiplicative comparison from additive comparison).

Solve multistep word problems using the four operations, including problems in which remainders must be interpreted. Understand how the remainder is a fraction of the divisor. Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Number and Operations in Base Ten (NBT)
objectives.objectiveDescription: Generalize place value understanding for multi-digit whole numbers.

expectations.expectationDescription: Apply concepts of place value, multiplication, and division to understand that in a multi-digit whole number, a digit in one place represents ten times what it represents in the place to its right.

Read and write multi-digit whole numbers using base-ten numerals, number names, and expanded form. Compare two multi-digit numbers based on meanings of the digits in each place, using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.
Use place value understanding to round multi-digit whole numbers to any place.
Fluently add and subtract multi-digit whole numbers using a standard algorithm.

Multiply a whole number of up to four digits by a one-digit whole number, and multiply two two-digit numbers, using strategies based on place value and the properties of operations. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.
Demonstrate understanding of division by finding whole-number quotients and remainders with up to four-digit dividends and one-digit divisors.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Extend understanding of fraction equivalence and ordering.

expectations.expectationDescription: Explain why a fraction a/b is equivalent to a fraction (n x a)/(n x b) by using visual fraction models, with attention to how the number and size of the parts differ even though the two fractions themselves are the same size. Use this principle to understand and generate equivalent fractions.
Compare two fractions with different numerators and different denominators (e.g., by creating common denominators or numerators and by comparing to a benchmark fraction).
Understand a fraction a/b with a > 1 as a sum of unit fractions (1/b).
Build fractions from unit fractions.
Understand decimal notation for fractions, and compare decimal fractions.
Use decimal notation for fractions with denominators 10 (tenths) or 100 (hundredths), and locate these decimals on a number line.
Compare two decimals to hundredths by reasoning about their size.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Solve problems involving measurement and conversion of measurements from a larger unit to a smaller unit.

expectations.expectationDescription: Know relative sizes of measurement units within one system of units. Within a single system of measurement, express measurements in a larger unit in terms of a smaller unit and in a smaller unit in terms of a larger unit.

Use the four operations to solve word problems and problems in real-world context involving distances, intervals of time, liquid volumes, masses of objects, and money, including decimals and problems involving fractions with like denominators, and problems that require expressing measurements given in a larger unit in terms of a smaller unit.
Apply the area and perimeter formulas for rectangles in mathematical problems and problems in real-world contexts including problems with unknown side lengths.
Make a line plot to display a data set of measurements in fractions of a unit. Solve problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions by using information presented in line plots.
Recognize angles as geometric shapes that are formed wherever two rays share a common endpoint, and understand concepts of angle measurement.
Measure angles in whole-number degrees using a protractor. Sketch angles of specified measure.
Understand angle measures as additive. Solve addition and subtraction problems to find unknown angles on a diagram within mathematical problems as well as problems in real-world contexts.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Draw and identify lines and angles, and classify shapes by properties of their lines and angles.

expectations.expectationDescription: Draw points, lines, line segments, rays, angles (right, acute, obtuse), and perpendicular and parallel lines. Identify these in two-dimensional figures.
Classify two-dimensional figures based on the presence or absence of parallel or perpendicular lines, or the presence or absence of angles of a specified size.

Recognize a line of symmetry for a two-dimensional figure as a line across the figure such that the figure can be folded along the line into matching parts. Identify line-symmetric figures and draw lines of symmetry.
Make sense of problems and persevere in solving them.
Reason abstractly and quantitatively.
Construct viable arguments and critique the reasoning of others.
Model with mathematics.
Use appropriate tools strategically.
Attend to precision.
Look for and make use of structure.
Look for and express regularity in repeated reasoning.

sections.sectionDescription: Introduce and explain multiplicative comparisons. Students will learn to represent verbal statements of multiplicative comparisons as multiplication equations.
Students will solve word problems involving multiplicative comparisons, using drawings and equations to represent the problems.
Students will solve multi-step word problems using the four operations, interpreting remainders and representing problems with equations.

Students will recognize a line of symmetry for a two-dimensional figure and identify line-symmetric figures and draw lines of symmetry.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Sensemaking in science occurs with the integration of three essential dimensions.

expectations.expectationDescription: ask questions and define problems
develop and use models
plan and carry out investigations
analyze and interpret data
use mathematics and computational thinking
construct explanations and design solutions
engage in argument from evidence
obtain, evaluate, and communicate information

objectives.objectiveDescription: Core Ideas for Knowing Science

expectations.expectationDescription: Physical Science
Earth and Space Science
Life Science

objectives.objectiveDescription: Core Ideas for Using Science

expectations.expectationDescription: Scientists explain phenomena using evidence obtained from observations and or scientific investigations. Evidence may lead to developing models and or theories to make sense of phenomena. As new evidence is discovered, models and theories can be revised.
The knowledge produced by science is used in engineering and technologies to solve problems and/or create products.
Applications of science often have both positive and negative ethical, social, economic, and/or political implications.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop an understanding of how Earthâ€™s resources can be transformed into different forms of energy. Students develop a better understanding of electricity and magnetism.

expectations.expectationDescription: Develop and use a model to demonstrate how a system transfers energy from one object to another even when the objects are not touching.
Develop and use a model that explains how energy is moved from place to place through electric currents.
Develop and use a model to demonstrate magnetic forces.
Engage in argument from evidence on the use and impact of renewable and nonrenewable resources to generate electricity.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop an understanding of the diversity of past and present organisms, factors impacting organism diversity, and evidence of change of organisms over time.

expectations.expectationDescription: Analyze and interpret environmental data to demonstrate that species either adapt and survive or go extinct over time.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop an understanding of the different Earth systems and how they interact with each other. They understand how geological systems change and shape Earth and the evidence that is used to understand these changes. They also understand how weather, climate, and human interactions can impact the environment.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use models to explain seismic waves and their effect on the Earth.
Plan and carry out an investigation to explore and explain the interactions between Earthâ€™s major systems and the impact on Earthâ€™s surface materials and processes.
Develop and/or revise a model using various rock types, fossil location, and landforms to show evidence that Earthâ€™s surface has changed over time.
Collect, analyze, and interpret data to explain weather and climate patterns.
Construct and support an evidence-based argument about the availability of water and its impact on life.
Define problem(s) and design solution(s) to minimize the effects of natural hazards.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Develop and use models to demonstrate concepts related to physical science.

expectations.expectationDescription: Energy is transferred from one object, which is an energy source or resource, to another.
Energy is present whenever there are moving objects, sound, light, or heat.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Analyze and interpret data related to life science concepts.

expectations.expectationDescription: When the environment changes, some organisms survive and reproduce, others move to new locations, yet others move into the transformed environment, and some die.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Elements of Earth and Space Science Standards
objectives.objectiveDescription: Develop and use models to demonstrate concepts related to earth and space science.

expectations.expectationDescription: Earthquakes cause seismic waves, which are waves of motion in Earthâ€™s crust.
Energy originates from the sun and from Earthâ€™s interior.

outline.title: Introduction to Three Dimensions of Science

sections.sectionDescription: Students will learn how to formulate scientific questions and define problems that can be investigated.
Students will understand the role of models in science and practice creating and using them.
Students will learn how to design and conduct scientific investigations.
Students will practice analyzing data from investigations and interpreting the results.
Students will explore how mathematics and computational tools are used in scientific inquiry.
Students will learn to construct scientific explanations and design solutions based on evidence.
Students will practice constructing and defending scientific arguments using evidence.
Students will develop skills to obtain, evaluate, and effectively communicate scientific information.
Students will be introduced to core concepts in physical science.
Students will explore fundamental ideas in earth and space science.
Students will study key principles and concepts in life science.
Students will learn how scientists use evidence to explain natural phenomena.
Students will explore how scientific knowledge is applied in engineering and technology.
Students will discuss the broader implications of scientific applications on society.
Students will develop models to demonstrate how energy is transferred in systems.
Students will explore how energy is moved through electric currents.
Students will use models to demonstrate and understand magnetic forces.
Students will engage in arguments about the use and impact of different resources to generate electricity.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Generate and Conceptualize Artistic Ideas

expectations.expectationDescription: Combine ideas to generate an innovative idea for art making.
Identify and demonstrate diverse methods of artistic investigation (e.g., researching subject matter, techniques, the work of other artists) to choose an approach for beginning a work of art.
Develop skills in multiple art-making techniques and experiment with approaches (e.g., using elements and principles of modern art, applying artistic norms of diverse cultures through practice).
Demonstrate quality craftsmanship through care and use of materials, tools, and equipment.
Describe and visually document places and/or objects of personal significance.
Create an artistic statement using art vocabulary to describe personal choices in art-making.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Select, Analyze, and Interpret Artistic Work for Performance

expectations.expectationDescription: Define the roles and responsibilities of museum professionals (e.g., museum educator, curator, security guard, conservator, docent, exhibition designer). Explain the skills and knowledge needed in maintaining and presenting objects, artifacts, and artwork.

Develop a logical argument for safe and effective use of materials and techniques for preparing and presenting artwork (e.g., debating or writing about the care and transportation of personal artwork, care of family heirlooms, unprotected Native American petroglyphs).
Cite evidence about how an exhibition in a museum or other venue (e.g., school lobby, bulletin board, local business) presents ideas and provides information about a specific concept or topic.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Perceive and Analyze Artistic Work

expectations.expectationDescription: Use art-specific vocabulary to compare how artworks made in different cultures reflect the times and places in which they were made.

Identify and analyze cultural associations suggested by visual imagery (e.g., skulls and skeletons used in Day of the Dead festivals, dancing dragons used in Chinese New Year celebrations, broken chain as symbol of freedom).
Distinguish between relevant and non-relevant contextual information (e.g., artistâ€™s life and times) to support an interpretation of the mood, message, or meaning of that artwork.
Recognize differences in criteria used to evaluate works of art depending on styles (e.g., Cubist, Anasazi, Harlem Renaissance), genres (e.g., portrait, still life, landscape), and media.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Synthesize and Relate Knowledge and Personal Experiences to Make Art

expectations.expectationDescription: Create a work of art that reflects or is inspired by the natural and/or built environment in a new way.

Identify how art is used to inform or change beliefs, values, or behaviors of an individual or society (e.g., religious art can illustrate a groupâ€™s beliefs, community murals can reflect concerns of the neighborhood, an advertising image can be persuasive).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students leverage technology to take an active role in choosing, achieving, and demonstrating competency in their learning goals, informed by the learning sciences.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students, in collaboration with an educator, develop learning goals, select the technology tools to achieve them, and reflect on and revise the learning process as needed to achieve goals.
Students, in collaboration with an educator, build a network of experts and peers to customize their environments to enhance their learning, in accordance with school policy.
Students, in collaboration with an educator, examine feedback from both people and the features embedded in digital tools, and use age-appropriate technology to share learning.
Students explore age-appropriate technologies and begin to transfer their learning to different tools or learning environments.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students recognize the rights, responsibilities, and opportunities of living, learning, and working in an interconnected digital world, and they act and model in ways that are safe, legal, and ethical.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students demonstrate an understanding of the role a digital identity plays in the digital world and learn the permanence of their decisions when interacting online.
Students, in collaboration with an educator, identify and practice safe, legal, and ethical behavior when using technology and interacting online.

Students, in collaboration with an educator, examine, use, and demonstrate respect for intellectual property including copyright, permission, and fair use, with both print and digital media when using and sharing the work of others.
Students, in collaboration with an educator, demonstrate an understanding of what personal data is, how to keep it private, and how it might be shared online.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students critically curate a variety of resources using digital tools to construct knowledge, produce creative artifacts, and make meaningful learning experiences for themselves and others.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students, in collaboration with an educator, employ appropriate research techniques to locate digital resources that will help them in their learning process.
Students, in collaboration with an educator, learn how to evaluate sources for accuracy, perspective, credibility, and relevance.
Students, in collaboration with an educator, use a variety of strategies to collect and organize information and make meaningful connections between resources.
Students, in collaboration with an educator, explore real-world problems and issues and collaborate with others to find answers or solutions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students use a variety of technologies within a design process to identify and solve problems by creating new, useful or imaginative solutions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students, in collaboration with an educator, explore and practice a design process by generating ideas to solve a problem by planning, creating and testing innovative products that are shared with others.
Students, in collaboration with an educator, use digital and/or non-digital tools to plan and manage a design process.
Students, in collaboration with an educator, engage in a cyclical design process to develop, test and refine prototypes and reflect on the role that trial and error plays.
Students demonstrate perseverance when working with open-ended problems.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop and employ strategies for understanding and solving problems in ways that leverage the power of technological methods to develop and test solutions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students, in collaboration with an educator, identify, explore or solve problems by selecting technology for data analysis, modeling, and algorithmic thinking.
Students, in collaboration with an educator, select effective technology to represent and organize data.
Students, in collaboration with an educator, break down problems into smaller parts, identify key information, and propose solutions.
Students understand and explore basic concepts related to automation, patterns, and algorithmic thinking.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students communicate clearly and express themselves creatively for a variety of purposes using the platforms, tools, styles, formats and digital media appropriate to their goals.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students, in collaboration with an educator, recognize and utilize the features and functions of a variety of creation or communication tools.
Students, in collaboration with an educator, create original works and learn strategies for responsibly repurposing and remixing to create new artifacts.
Students, in collaboration with an educator, create digital artifacts using digital tools to communicate ideas visually, graphically, and/or auditorily.
Students, in collaboration with an educator, learn about and consider the intended audience when creating and publishing digital artifacts and presentations.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students use digital tools to broaden their perspectives and enrich their learning by collaborating with others and working effectively in teams locally and globally.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students, in collaboration with an educator, use digital tools to work with other learners, including those from a variety of backgrounds and cultures.

Students, in collaboration with an educator, take on various assigned team roles, contributing their knowledge of technology and content to complete a project or solve a problem.
Students, in collaboration with an educator, work with others, using technology to explore local and global issues and identify possible solutions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Sensemaking in science occurs with the integration of three essential dimensions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Ask questions and define problems.
Develop and use models.
Plan and carry out investigations.
Analyze and interpret data.
Use mathematics and computational thinking.
Construct explanations and design solutions.
Engage in argument from evidence.
Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Core Ideas for Knowing Science

expectations.expectationDescription: Physical Science
Earth and Space Science
Life Science

objectives.objectiveDescription: Core Ideas for Using Science

expectations.expectationDescription: Scientists explain phenomena using evidence obtained from observations and/or scientific investigations. Evidence may lead to developing models and/or theories to make sense of phenomena. As new evidence is discovered, models and theories can be revised.
The knowledge produced by science is used in engineering and technologies to solve problems and/or create products.
Applications of science often have both positive and negative ethical, social, economic, and/or political implications.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop an understanding that changes can occur to matter/objects on Earth or in space, but both energy and matter follow the pattern of being conserved during those changes.

expectations.expectationDescription: Analyze and interpret data to explain that matter of any type can be subdivided into particles too small to see and, in a closed system, if properties change or chemical reactions occur, the amount of matter stays the same.
Plan and carry out investigations to demonstrate that some substances combine to form new substances with different properties and others can be mixed without taking on new properties.
Construct an explanation using evidence to demonstrate that objects can affect other objects even when they are not touching.
Obtain, analyze, and communicate evidence of the effects that balanced and unbalanced forces have on the motion of objects.
Define problems and design solutions pertaining to force and motion.
Analyze and interpret data to determine how and where energy is transferred when objects move.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop an understanding of the how gravitational forces in space cause observable patterns due to the position of Earth, Sun, Moon, and stars.

expectations.expectationDescription: Develop, revise, and use models based on evidence to construct explanations about the movement of the Earth and Moon within our solar system.
Obtain, analyze, and communicate evidence to support an explanation that the gravitational force of Earth on objects is directed toward the planetâ€™s center.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop an understanding of patterns and how genetic information is passed from generation to generation. They also develop the understanding of how genetic information and environmental features impact the survival of an organism.

expectations.expectationDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information about patterns between the offspring of plants, and the offspring of animals (including humans); construct an explanation of how genetic information is passed from one generation to the next.
Construct an explanation based on evidence that the changes in an environment can affect the development of the traits in a population of organisms.
Obtain, evaluate, and communicate evidence about how natural and human-caused changes to habitats or climate can impact populations.
Construct an argument based on evidence that inherited characteristics can be affected by behavior and/or environmental conditions.

Construct an explanation using evidence to demonstrate that objects can affect other objects even when they are not touching.

Analyze and interpret data to determine how and where energy is transferred when objects move.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Elements of Earth and Space Science Standards

expectations.expectationDescription: Develop, revise, and use models based on evidence to construct explanations about the movement of the Earth and Moon within our solar system.
Obtain, analyze, and communicate evidence to support an explanation that the gravitational force of Earth on objects is directed toward the planetâ€™s center.

Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information about patterns between the offspring of plants, and the offspring of animals (including humans); construct an explanation of how genetic information is passed from one generation to the next.
Construct an explanation based on evidence that the changes in an environment can affect the development of the traits in a population of organisms.
Obtain, evaluate, and communicate evidence about how natural and human-caused changes to habitats or climate can impact populations.
Construct an argument based on evidence that inherited characteristics can be affected by behavior and/or environmental conditions.

outline.title: Introduction to Three Dimensions of Science

sections.sectionDescription: Introduction to the three essential dimensions of science: asking questions, developing models, and conducting investigations.
Students learn how to ask scientific questions and define problems that can be investigated.
Students learn how to create and use models to represent scientific concepts.
Students plan and carry out scientific investigations to gather data and answer questions.
Students learn how to analyze and interpret data collected from their investigations.
Students use mathematics and computational thinking to analyze data and solve scientific problems.
Students construct scientific explanations and design solutions based on evidence.
Students learn to engage in argument from evidence to support their scientific claims.
Students obtain, evaluate, and communicate scientific information effectively.
Introduction to physical science concepts including matter, energy, and forces.
Introduction to earth and space science concepts including planetary motion and space exploration.
Introduction to life science concepts including ecosystems, genetics, and biodiversity.
How scientists use evidence and models to explain natural phenomena.
How scientific knowledge is applied in engineering and technology to solve problems.
Exploring the ethical, social, economic, and political implications of scientific applications.
Understanding matter, its properties, and the conservation of matter and energy.
Investigating chemical reactions and the formation of new substances.
Exploring how forces affect the motion of objects, even when not in contact.
Understanding the effects of balanced and unbalanced forces on motion.

sections.sectionTitle: Design Solutions for Force and Motion
sections.sectionDescription: Designing solutions to problems related to force and motion.
Analyzing how and where energy is transferred when objects move.
Understanding the gravitational forces in space and their impact on Earth, Moon, and stars.
Exploring how gravitational force directs objects toward the planetâ€™s center.
Studying how genetic information is passed from generation to generation.
Exploring how environmental changes affect the traits of organisms.
Investigating the effects of natural and human-caused changes to habitats and climate.

sections.sectionTitle: Behavioral and Environmental Impact on Inherited Traits
sections.sectionDescription: Understanding how behavior and environmental conditions can affect inherited traits.

sections.sectionTitle: Review of Three Dimensions of Science
sections.sectionDescription: Review and reinforce the concepts covered in the three dimensions of science.

sections.sectionTitle: Review of Core Ideas for Knowing Science
sections.sectionDescription: Review and reinforce the core ideas for knowing science.

sections.sectionTitle: Review of Core Ideas for Using Science
sections.sectionDescription: Review and reinforce the core ideas for using science.

sections.sectionTitle: Review of Earth and Space Science Standards
sections.sectionDescription: Review and reinforce the earth and space science standards.
Review and reinforce the life science standards.

sections.sectionTitle: Review of Elements of Physical Science Standards
sections.sectionDescription: Review and reinforce the elements of physical science standards.

sections.sectionTitle: Review of Elements of Earth and Space Science Standards
sections.sectionDescription: Review and reinforce the elements of earth and space science standards.

sections.sectionTitle: Review of Elements of Life Science Standards
sections.sectionDescription: Review and reinforce the elements of life science standards.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Generate and Conceptualize Artistic Ideas

expectations.expectationDescription: Combine ideas to generate an innovative idea for art making.
Identify and demonstrate diverse methods of artistic investigation (e.g., researching subject matter, techniques, the work of other artists) to choose an approach for beginning a work of art.
Develop skills in multiple art-making techniques and experiment with approaches (e.g., using elements and principles of modern art, applying artistic norms of diverse cultures through practice).
Demonstrate quality craftmanship through care and use of materials, tools, and equipment.
Describe and visually document places and/or objects of personal significance.
Create an artistic statement using art vocabulary to describe personal choices in art-making.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Select, Analyze, and Interpret Artistic Work for Performance

expectations.expectationDescription: Define the roles and responsibilities of museum professionals (e.g., museum educator, curator, security guard, conservator, docent, exhibition designer). Explain the skills and knowledge needed in maintaining and presenting objects, artifacts, and artwork.

Develop a logical argument for safe and effective use of materials and techniques for preparing and presenting artwork (e.g., debating or writing about the care and transportation of personal artwork, care of family heirlooms, unprotected Native American petroglyphs).
Cite evidence about how an exhibition in a museum or other venue (e.g., school lobby, bulletin board, local business) presents ideas and provides information about a specific concept or topic.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Perceive and Analyze Artistic Work

expectations.expectationDescription: Use art-specific vocabulary to compare how artworks made in different cultures reflect the times and places in which they were made.

Identify and analyze cultural associations suggested by visual imagery (e.g., skulls and skeletons used in Day of the Dead festivals, dancing dragons used in Chinese New Year celebrations, broken chain as symbol of freedom).
Distinguish between relevant and non-relevant contextual information (e.g., artistâ€™s life and times) to support an interpretation of the mood, message, or meaning of that artwork.
Recognize differences in criteria used to evaluate works of art depending on styles (e.g., Cubist, Anasazi, Harlem Renaissance), genres (e.g., portrait, still life, landscape), and media.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Synthesize and Relate Knowledge and Personal Experiences to Make Art

expectations.expectationDescription: Create a work of art that reflects or is inspired by the natural and/or built environment in a new way.

Identify how art is used to inform or change beliefs, values, or behaviors of an individual or society (e.g., religious art can illustrate a groupâ€™s beliefs, community murals can reflect concerns of the neighborhood, an advertising image can be persuasive).

sections.sectionDescription: Introduce the course objectives, expectations, and structure. Discuss the importance of art and its impact on society.
Explore various techniques to combine ideas to generate innovative concepts for art-making.
Identify and demonstrate different methods of artistic investigation, including research on subject matter and techniques.
Develop skills in various art-making techniques and experiment with different approaches and cultural influences.
Learn and demonstrate quality craftsmanship through proper care and use of materials, tools, and equipment.
Describe and visually document places and objects of personal significance through art.
Create artistic statements using art vocabulary to describe personal choices and motivations in art-making.
Define and discuss the roles and responsibilities of various museum professionals and their skills in maintaining and presenting art.
Develop arguments for the safe and effective use of materials and techniques in preparing and presenting artwork.
Cite evidence on how exhibitions present ideas and provide information about specific concepts or topics.
Use art-specific vocabulary to compare how artworks from different cultures reflect their times and places.
Identify and analyze cultural associations suggested by visual imagery in art.
Distinguish between relevant and non-relevant contextual information to support the interpretation of an artwork's mood, message, or meaning.
Recognize the differences in criteria used to evaluate works of art based on styles, genres, and media.
Create a work of art that reflects or is inspired by the natural and/or built environment in a new way.
Identify how art is used to inform or change the beliefs, values, or behaviors of individuals or society.
Review techniques for combining ideas to generate innovative concepts for art-making.
Review diverse methods of artistic investigation.
Review skills in various art-making techniques and approaches.
Review quality craftsmanship through care and use of materials, tools, and equipment.
Review documenting places and objects of personal significance through art.
Review creating artistic statements using art vocabulary.
Review the roles and responsibilities of museum professionals.
Review the safe and effective use of materials and techniques in art presentation.
Review how exhibitions present ideas and information.
Review how artworks from different cultures reflect their times and places.
Review cultural associations suggested by visual imagery.
Review distinguishing relevant and non-relevant contextual information in art.
Review criteria used to evaluate works of art based on styles, genres, and media.
Review creating art that reflects or is inspired by the environment.
Review how art informs or changes beliefs, values, or behaviors.
Review techniques for combining ideas to generate innovative concepts for art-making.
Review diverse methods of artistic investigation.
Review skills in various art-making techniques and approaches.
Review quality craftsmanship through care and use of materials, tools, and equipment.
Conduct a comprehensive review of all objectives and expectations covered throughout the course. Assess students' understanding and application of the course content.

expectations.expectationDescription: Compare computing device designs based on how humans interact with them. The study of human-computer interaction (HCI) can improve the design of devices, including both hardware and software. Teachers can guide students to consider usability through several lenses.
Explain how hardware and software can be used to collect and exchange data. Collecting and exchanging data involves input, output, storage, and processing.

Identify problems that can occur in computing devices and their components within a system. Since a computing device may interact with interconnected devices within a system, problems may not be due to the computing device itself but to devices or components connected to it.
Identify multiple methods of encryption to secure the transmission of information.
Identify different physical and digital security measures that protect electronic information.
Discuss how protocols are used in transmitting data across networks and the Internet.
Compare different computational tools used to collect, analyze and present data that is meaningful and useful.
Identify multiple encoding schemes used to represent data, including binary and ASCII.
Discuss the validity of a computational model based on the reliability of the data.
Identify planning strategies such as flowcharts or pseudocode, to simulate algorithms that solve problems.
Identify variables that represent different data types and perform operations on their values.
Design programs that combine control structures, including nested loops and compound conditionals.
Decompose problems into parts to facilitate the design, implementation, and review of programs.
Use procedures to organize code and make it easier to reuse.
Seek and incorporate feedback from team members and users to refine a solution that meets user needs.
Incorporate existing code into programs and give attribution.
Test programs using a range of inputs and identify expected outputs.
Maintain a timeline with specific tasks while collaboratively developing computational artifacts.
Document programs in order to make them easier to follow, test, and debug.
Identify some of the tradeoffs associated with computing technologies that can affect people's everyday activities and career options.
Identify issues of bias and accessibility in the design of existing technologies.
Identify the advantages of creating a computational product by collaborating with others using digital technologies.
Describe how some digital information can be public or can be kept private and secure.

sections.sectionDescription: Discuss how humans interact with different computing device designs and introduce the concept of human-computer interaction (HCI).
Explore various computing devices and their usability through multiple lenses, considering HCI principles.
Explain how hardware and software collect and exchange data, focusing on input, output, storage, and processing.
Identify common problems in computing devices and their components, and discuss potential solutions.
Introduce multiple methods of encryption used to secure information transmission.
Identify different physical and digital security measures that protect electronic information.
Discuss how protocols are used in transmitting data across networks and the Internet.
Compare different computational tools used to collect, analyze, and present meaningful data.
Identify multiple encoding schemes used to represent data, including binary and ASCII.
Discuss the validity of a computational model based on the reliability of the data.
Identify planning strategies such as flowcharts or pseudocode to simulate algorithms that solve problems.
Identify variables representing different data types and perform operations on their values.
Design programs combining control structures, including nested loops and compound conditionals.
Decompose problems into parts to facilitate the design, implementation, and review of programs.
Use procedures to organize code and make it easier to reuse.
Seek and incorporate feedback from team members and users to refine solutions that meet user needs.
Incorporate existing code into programs and provide proper attribution.
Test programs using a range of inputs and identify expected outputs.
Maintain a timeline with specific tasks while collaboratively developing computational artifacts.
Document programs to make them easier to follow, test, and debug.
Identify tradeoffs associated with computing technologies affecting everyday activities and career options.
Identify issues of bias and accessibility in the design of existing technologies.
Identify the advantages of creating a computational product by collaborating with others using digital technologies.
Describe how some digital information can be public or kept private and secure.
