sections.sectionTitle: Review of Networks and the Internet
sections.sectionDescription: Review the key concepts from Networks and the Internet.
Review the key concepts from Data and Analysis.
Review the key concepts from Algorithms and Programming.
Review the key concepts from Impacts of Computing.
Review all key concepts covered in the course to prepare for final assessments.
Begin planning a final project that incorporates multiple concepts learned throughout the course.
Continue developing the final project, focusing on implementation and iteration.
Finalize the project and prepare for presentations.
Students present their final projects to the class.
Evaluate and provide feedback on student projects.
Reflect on the course, discuss learnings, and gather student feedback.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Understand ratio concepts and use ratio reasoning to solve problems.

expectations.expectationDescription: Understand the concept of a ratio as comparing two quantities multiplicatively or joining/composing the two quantities in a way that preserves a multiplicative relationship. Use ratio language to describe a ratio relationship between two quantities. For example, 'There were 2/3 as many men as women at the concert.'

Understand the concept of a unit rate a/b associated with a ratio a : b with b â‰  0, and use rate language (e.g., for every, for each, for each 1, per) in the context of a ratio relationship. (Complex fraction notation is not an expectation for unit rates in this grade level.)

Use ratio and rate reasoning to solve mathematical problems and problems in real-world context (e.g., by reasoning about data collected from measurements, tables of equivalent ratios, tape diagrams, double number line diagrams, or equations).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Apply and extend previous understanding of multiplication and division to divide fractions by fractions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Interpret and compute quotients of fractions to solve mathematical problems and problems in real-world context involving division of fractions by fractions using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.
Fluently divide multi-digit numbers using a standard algorithm.
Fluently add, subtract, multiply, and divide multi-digit decimals using a standard algorithm for each operation.
Use previous understanding of factors to find the greatest common factor and the least common multiple.

Understand that positive and negative numbers are used together to describe quantities having opposite directions or values. Use positive and negative numbers to represent quantities in real-world context, explaining the meaning of 0 in each situation.

Understand a rational number can be represented as a point on the number line. Extend number line diagrams and coordinate axes familiar from previous grades to represent points on the line and in the plane with negative number coordinates.
Understand ordering and absolute value of rational numbers.

Solve mathematical problems and problems in real-world context by graphing points in all four quadrants of the coordinate plane. Include use of coordinates and absolute value to find distances between points with the same first coordinate or the same second coordinate.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Apply and extend previous understanding of arithmetic to algebraic expressions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Write and evaluate numerical expressions involving whole-number exponents.
Write, read, and evaluate algebraic expressions.
Apply the properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions.
Identify when two expressions are equivalent.
Understand solving an equation or inequality as a process of reasoning to find the value(s) of the variables that make that equation or inequality true.

Use variables to represent numbers and write expressions when solving mathematical problems and problems in real-world context; understand that a variable can represent an unknown number or any number in a specified set.
Solve mathematical problems and problems in real-world context by writing and solving equations.
Write an inequality to represent a constraint or condition to solve mathematical problems and problems in real-world context.
Use variables to represent two quantities that change in relationship to one another to solve mathematical problems and problems in real-world context.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Solve mathematical problems and problems in real-world context involving area, surface area, and volume.

expectations.expectationDescription: Find the area of various shapes and solve mathematical problems and problems in real-world context.
Find the volume of a right rectangular prism with fractional edge lengths and solve mathematical problems and problems in real-world context.
Draw polygons in the coordinate plane given coordinates for the vertices and solve mathematical problems and problems in a real-world context.
Represent three-dimensional figures using nets made up of rectangles and triangles, and use the nets to find the surface area of these figures.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Develop understanding of statistical variability.

expectations.expectationDescription: Recognize a statistical question as one that anticipates variability in the data related to the question and accounts for variability in the answers.
Understand that a set of data collected to answer a statistical question has a distribution whose general characteristics can be described by its center, spread, and overall shape.

Recognize that a measure of center for a numerical data set summarizes all of its values with a single number, while a measure of variation uses a single number to describe the spread of the data set.
Display and interpret numerical data by creating plots on a number line including histograms, dot plots, and box plots.
Summarize numerical data sets in relation to their context.
Make sense of problems and persevere in solving them.
Reason abstractly and quantitatively.
Construct viable arguments and critique the reasoning of others.
Model with mathematics.
Use appropriate tools strategically.
Attend to precision.
Look for and make use of structure.
Look for and express regularity in repeated reasoning.

sections.sectionDescription: Introduce the concept of ratios by comparing two quantities multiplicatively. Use real-life examples to describe ratio relationships between two quantities.
Understand and calculate unit rates associated with ratios. Use rate language to describe these relationships in various contexts.
Apply ratio and rate reasoning to solve mathematical and real-world problems using tools like tables, tape diagrams, and equations.
Interpret and compute quotients of fractions. Solve problems involving the division of fractions by fractions using visual models and equations.
Practice and achieve fluency in dividing multi-digit numbers using the standard algorithm.
Fluently add and subtract multi-digit decimals using the standard algorithm.
Fluently multiply and divide multi-digit decimals using the standard algorithm.

sections.sectionTitle: Greatest Common Factor and Least Common Multiple
sections.sectionDescription: Use understanding of factors to find the greatest common factor (GCF) and the least common multiple (LCM) of numbers.
Learn about positive and negative numbers and how they are used to describe quantities with opposite directions or values. Explain the meaning of zero in various contexts.

sections.sectionTitle: Rational Numbers on a Number Line
sections.sectionDescription: Understand and represent rational numbers on a number line. Extend these concepts to coordinate axes to include negative number coordinates.
Understand the concept of ordering rational numbers and learn to compare them.
Learn the concept of absolute value and how to determine the absolute value of rational numbers.
Solve problems by graphing points in all four quadrants of the coordinate plane. Use coordinates and absolute values to find distances between points.
Write and evaluate numerical expressions involving whole-number exponents.
Learn to write, read, and evaluate algebraic expressions.
Apply the properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions.
Learn to identify when two expressions are equivalent.
Understand solving an equation as a process of reasoning to find the value(s) of variables that make the equation true.
Use variables to represent numbers and write expressions to solve mathematical problems and real-world contexts.
Solve mathematical and real-world problems by writing and solving equations.
Write inequalities to represent constraints or conditions in solving mathematical and real-world problems.
Use variables to represent two quantities that change in relationship to each other to solve mathematical and real-world problems.
Learn to find the area of various shapes and solve related mathematical and real-world problems.
Find the volume of a right rectangular prism with fractional edge lengths and solve related mathematical and real-world problems.
Draw polygons in the coordinate plane given the coordinates for the vertices and solve related mathematical and real-world problems.

sections.sectionTitle: Using Nets to Find Surface Area
sections.sectionDescription: Represent three-dimensional figures using nets made up of rectangles and triangles. Use these nets to find the surface area of the figures.
Recognize and formulate statistical questions that anticipate variability in the data.
Understand and describe data distributions by their center, spread, and overall shape.
Summarize data sets using measures of center and variation.
Create and interpret plots on a number line, including histograms, dot plots, and box plots.
Summarize numerical data sets in relation to their context.
Make sense of problems and persevere in solving them.
Reason abstractly and quantitatively.
Construct viable arguments and critique the reasoning of others.
Model with mathematics.
Use appropriate tools strategically.
Attend to precision in mathematical processes.
Look for and make use of structure in mathematical concepts.
Look for and express regularity in repeated reasoning.
Review and reinforce concepts related to ratios, proportions, and unit rates.
Review and reinforce concepts related to the number system, including fractions, decimals, and negative numbers.
Conduct a comprehensive review of all topics covered during the year to prepare for final assessments.
Administer final assessments to evaluate student understanding of the course material.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop an understanding of the flow of energy in a system beginning with the Sun to and among organisms. They also understand that plants and animals (including humans) have specialized internal and external structures and can respond to stimuli to increase survival.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use evidence to construct an argument regarding the impact of human activities on the environment and how they positively and negatively affect the competition for energy and resources in ecosystems.
Engage in argument from evidence to support a claim about the factors that cause species to change and how humans can impact those factors.
Develop and use models to demonstrate the interdependence of organisms and their environment including biotic and abiotic factors.
Construct a model that shows the cycling of matter and flow of energy in ecosystems.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop an understanding of forces and energy and how energy can transfer from one object to another or be converted from one form to another. They also develop an understanding of the nature of matter.

expectations.expectationDescription: Analyze and interpret data to show that changes in states of matter are caused by different rates of movement of atoms in solids, liquids, and gases (Kinetic Theory).
Plan and carry out an investigation to demonstrate that variations in temperature and/or pressure affect changes in state of matter.
Develop and use models to represent that matter is made up of smaller particles called atoms.
Develop and use a model to predict how forces act on objects at a distance.
Analyze how humans use technology to store (potential) and/or use (kinetic) energy.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop an understanding of how the Sun provides light and energy for Earth systems.

expectations.expectationDescription: Investigate and construct an explanation demonstrating that radiation from the Sun provides energy and is absorbed to warm the Earthâ€™s surface and atmosphere.
Use ratios and proportions to analyze and interpret data related to scale, properties, and relationships among objects in our solar system.
Develop and use models to explain how constellations and other night sky patterns appear to move due to Earthâ€™s rotation and revolution.
Develop and use models to construct an explanation of how eclipses, moon phases, and tides occur within the Sun-Earth-Moon system.
Use a model to show how the tilt of Earthâ€™s axis causes variations in the length of the day and gives rise to seasons.

sections.sectionDescription: Introduce students to the basics of Life Science, including the flow of energy in ecosystems and the specialized structures of plants and animals.

outline.title: Impact of Human Activities on the Environment

sections.sectionDescription: Discuss and provide evidence on how human activities affect the environment and ecosystems, both positively and negatively.
Examine and debate the various factors that cause species to change and the impact of human activities on these factors.
Develop models to show the interdependence of organisms and their environments, including both biotic and abiotic factors.
Construct models that demonstrate the cycling of matter and the flow of energy within ecosystems.
Introduce students to the basics of Physical Science, including forces, energy transfer, and the nature of matter.
Analyze and interpret data to understand how different rates of atom movement cause changes in the states of matter.
Plan and carry out investigations to demonstrate how variations in temperature and/or pressure affect changes in the state of matter.
Develop and use models to represent matter as made up of smaller particles called atoms.
Develop and use models to predict how forces act on objects at a distance.
Analyze how humans use technology to store potential energy and use kinetic energy.

outline.title: Introduction to Earth and Space Science

sections.sectionTitle: Overview of Earth and Space Science
sections.sectionDescription: Introduce students to the basics of Earth and Space Science, focusing on how the Sun provides light and energy for Earth systems.
Investigate and construct explanations demonstrating how radiation from the Sun provides energy and warms the Earthâ€™s surface and atmosphere.
Use ratios and proportions to analyze and interpret data related to the scale, properties, and relationships among objects in our solar system.
Develop and use models to explain how constellations and other night sky patterns appear to move due to Earthâ€™s rotation and revolution.
Develop and use models to construct explanations of how eclipses, moon phases, and tides occur within the Sun-Earth-Moon system.
Use models to show how the tilt of Earthâ€™s axis causes variations in the length of the day and gives rise to seasons.
Review the key concepts of Life Science including the flow of energy, interdependence of organisms, and human impact on ecosystems.
Review the key concepts of Physical Science including states of matter, atomic structure, and energy in technology.

outline.title: Review of Earth and Space Science Standards

sections.sectionDescription: Review the key concepts of Earth and Space Science including the Sun's energy, solar system properties, and the Sun-Earth-Moon system.
Reinforce and review all major concepts covered in Life Science, ensuring understanding and retention.
Reinforce and review all major concepts covered in Physical Science, ensuring understanding and retention.
Reinforce and review all major concepts covered in Earth and Space Science, ensuring understanding and retention.
Explore more advanced topics in Life Science, building on the foundational knowledge from previous weeks.
Explore more advanced topics in Physical Science, building on the foundational knowledge from previous weeks.

outline.title: Extended Topics in Earth and Space Science

sections.sectionDescription: Explore more advanced topics in Earth and Space Science, building on the foundational knowledge from previous weeks.
Engage students in project-based learning activities related to Life Science standards, promoting hands-on learning and critical thinking.
Engage students in project-based learning activities related to Physical Science standards, promoting hands-on learning and critical thinking.

outline.title: Project-Based Learning in Earth and Space Science

sections.sectionDescription: Engage students in project-based learning activities related to Earth and Space Science standards, promoting hands-on learning and critical thinking.
Develop and conduct interdisciplinary science projects that integrate concepts from Life Science, Physical Science, and Earth and Space Science.
Focus on scientific inquiry and the scientific method, encouraging students to design and conduct their own experiments.
Guide students in preparing projects for a science fair, applying their knowledge from all science standards covered.
Students present their science fair projects, demonstrating their understanding and application of scientific concepts.
Teach students how to analyze and interpret data from their experiments, reinforcing skills in scientific reasoning and critical thinking.
Focus on scientific writing and reporting, teaching students how to document and communicate their findings effectively.
Review all concepts covered throughout the year, encouraging students to reflect on their learning and growth.
Conduct final assessments to evaluate students' understanding of the science standards covered throughout the year.
Review the year's achievements and celebrate students' hard work and progress in science.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students leverage technology to take an active role in choosing, achieving, and demonstrating competency in their learning goals, informed by the learning sciences.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students articulate personal learning goals, select, and manage appropriate technologies to achieve them, and reflect on their successes and areas of improvement in working toward their goals.
Students identify and begin to develop online networks of experts and peers to customize their learning environments in accordance with school policy.
Students integrate feedback from people and digital tools to improve their learning process, and they select technology to demonstrate their learning in a variety of ways.
Students navigate a variety of technologies and transfer their skills to troubleshoot and learn how to use new technologies.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students recognize the rights, responsibilities, and opportunities of living, learning, and working in an interconnected digital world, and they act and model in ways that are safe, legal, and ethical.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students cultivate their digital identities and reputations within a digital environment and understand that digital actions are permanent.
Students demonstrate and advocate for positive, safe, legal, and ethical behavior when using technology and when interacting with others online.
Students demonstrate and advocate for an understanding of intellectual property including copyright, permission, and fair use by including appropriate citation and attribution elements.
Students demonstrate an understanding of what personal data is, how it is collected, and how to keep it private and secure, including the awareness of current technology terms and processes.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students critically curate a variety of resources using digital tools to construct knowledge, produce creative artifacts, and make meaningful learning experiences for themselves and others.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students practice and improve research strategies to locate information and other resources for their intellectual or creative pursuits.
Students practice evaluating the accuracy, perspective, credibility, and relevance of information, media, data or other resources.
Students locate and collect a variety of resources and organize information to make meaningful connections.
Students explore real-world problems and issues and actively pursue solutions for them.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students use a variety of technologies within a design process to identify and solve problems by creating new, useful or imaginative solutions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students engage in a design process for generating and testing ideas and developing innovative products to solve problems.
Students select and use digital tools to support a design process and expand their understanding to identify constraints and trade-offs and to weigh risks.
Students engage in a design process to develop, test, and revise prototypes, embrace the iterative process of trial and error, and understand setbacks as potential opportunities for improvement.
Students demonstrate an ability to persevere and handle greater ambiguity as they work to solve open-ended problems.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop and employ strategies for understanding and solving problems in ways that leverage the power of technological methods to develop and test solutions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students practice defining and solving problems by selecting technology for data analysis, modeling, and algorithmic thinking.
Students find and organize data and use technology to analyze and represent it to solve problems and make decisions.
Students break problems into component parts, identify key pieces, and use that information to solve problems.
Students understand how automation works and apply algorithmic thinking to design and automate solutions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students communicate clearly and express themselves creatively for a variety of purposes using the platforms, tools, styles, formats and digital media appropriate to their goals.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students select appropriate platforms and tools to create, share, and communicate their work effectively.
Students create original works or responsibly repurpose digital resources into new creative works.
Students create artifacts using digital tools to communicate complex ideas textually, visually, graphically, and auditorily.
Students publish or present content designed for intended audiences and select platforms that effectively convey their ideas.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students use digital tools to broaden their perspectives and enrich their learning by collaborating with others and working effectively in teams locally and globally.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students use digital tools to interact with others to develop a richer understanding of different perspectives and cultures.
Students use collaborative technologies to connect with others, including peers, experts, and community members, to learn about issues and problems or to gain a broader perspective.
Students perform a variety of roles within a team, using age-appropriate technology to complete a project or solve a problem.
Students work with others, using collaborative technologies to explore local and global issues and investigate and advocate for possible solutions.

sections.sectionDescription: Introduce students to the concept of an empowered learner. Discuss how technology can be leveraged for learning and goal setting.
Students articulate their personal learning goals and select technologies to help achieve them. Reflect on successes and areas for improvement.
Students learn to identify and develop online networks of experts and peers. Discuss the importance of customizing learning environments.
Students integrate feedback from digital tools and people to improve their learning processes. Explore different technologies to demonstrate learning.
Students navigate various technologies and learn to transfer skills to troubleshoot and use new technologies.
Introduce students to the concept of digital citizenship. Discuss rights, responsibilities, and ethical behavior in a digital world.
Students learn to cultivate and manage their digital identities and understand the permanence of digital actions.

sections.sectionTitle: Promoting Safe and Ethical Online Behavior
sections.sectionDescription: Students demonstrate and advocate for positive, safe, legal, and ethical behavior when using technology and interacting online.
Students learn about intellectual property, including copyright, permission, and fair use. Discuss appropriate citation and attribution.
Students understand what personal data is, how it is collected, and how to keep it private and secure. Discuss current technology terms and processes.
Introduce students to the concept of knowledge construction using digital tools. Discuss how to produce creative artifacts and make meaningful learning experiences.
Students practice and improve research strategies to locate information and other resources for intellectual or creative pursuits.
Students learn to evaluate the accuracy, perspective, credibility, and relevance of information, media, data, or other resources.
Students locate and collect a variety of resources, organizing information to make meaningful connections.
Students explore real-world problems and issues, actively pursuing solutions for them.
Introduce students to the concept of using technology within design processes to identify and solve problems with new and imaginative solutions.

Students select and use digital tools to support the design process, identify constraints and trade-offs, and weigh risks.
Students engage in a design process to develop, test, and revise prototypes, embracing the iterative process of trial and error.
Students demonstrate an ability to persevere and handle greater ambiguity as they work to solve open-ended problems.
Introduce students to computational thinking and how to employ strategies to solve problems using technological methods.
Students practice defining and solving problems by selecting technology for data analysis, modeling, and algorithmic thinking.
Students find and organize data, using technology to analyze and represent it to solve problems and make decisions.
Students break problems into component parts, identify key pieces, and use that information to solve problems.

Students perform a variety of roles within a team, using age-appropriate technology to complete a project or solve a problem.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will generate and conceptualize artistic ideas, organize and develop artistic ideas and work, and refine and complete artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Apply strategies to overcome creative blocks and develop criteria to guide making a work of art or design to meet an identified goal.

Demonstrate persistence in developing skills with various materials, methods, and approaches; apply standards of craftsmanship; and apply visual organizational strategies to design and produce a work of art, design, or media.
Reflect on and explain important information about personal artwork in an artist statement or another format.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will select, analyze, and interpret artistic work for performance, develop and refine artistic techniques and work for presentation, and convey meaning through the presentation of artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Compare how technologies have changed the way artwork is presented and experienced.
Analyze and evaluate methods for preparing and presenting artworks in an exhibition.
Analyze how preservation and security measures can affect viewing and experiencing art.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will perceive and analyze artistic work, interpret intent and meaning in artistic work, and apply criteria to evaluate artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Explain how the location of artworks/artifacts influence how they are perceived and valued, and analyze multiple ways that images influence specific audiences.
Cite specific evidence from an artwork and relevant evidence from the context to support an interpretation of the mood, message, or meaning of that artwork.
Compare and explain the difference between an evaluation of an artwork based on articulated personal criteria and an evaluation based on a set of criteria established by art specialists.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will synthesize and relate knowledge and personal experiences to make art, and relate artistic ideas and works with societal, cultural, and historical context to deepen understanding.

expectations.expectationDescription: Make art inspired by community art and/or by art made by local artists.
Analyze how response to art is influenced by understanding the time and place in which it was created, the available resources, and cultural uses.

sections.sectionDescription: Introduce students to various strategies for overcoming creative blocks and developing criteria for making art. Engage students in brainstorming and ideation exercises.
Teach students about persistence in developing artistic skills with different materials and methods. Focus on craftsmanship and visual organization strategies.
Guide students in writing artist statements to reflect on and explain their personal artwork.
Discuss how technologies have changed the way artwork is presented and experienced. Include examples of historical and modern presentation methods.
Teach students methods for preparing and presenting artworks in an exhibition. Include practical activities such as setting up a mock exhibition.
Analyze how preservation and security measures can affect the viewing and experiencing of art. Discuss various preservation techniques and their importance.
Explain how the location of artworks influences their perception and value. Analyze how images influence specific audiences.
Teach students to cite specific evidence from an artwork and relevant context to support their interpretation of its mood, message, or meaning.
Compare and explain the differences between personal and specialist evaluations of artwork. Develop personal criteria and apply specialist criteria in evaluations.
Make art inspired by community art and local artists. Engage with the community to find inspiration and understand local artistic contributions.
Analyze how responses to art are influenced by the time, place, available resources, and cultural uses in which the art was created.
Review the concepts of generating ideas, developing skills, and reflecting on personal artwork covered in weeks 1-3.
Review the concepts of technology in art presentation, preparing for exhibitions, and art preservation covered in weeks 4-6.
Review the concepts of perception of artworks, interpreting art, and evaluating art covered in weeks 7-9.

Explore advanced strategies for overcoming creative blocks and developing more complex criteria for artistic creation.
Focus on developing advanced skills with new materials and methods, emphasizing craftsmanship and visual organization.

Investigate innovative technologies in art presentation and how they transform the experience of art.
Design and prepare a comprehensive exhibition, considering advanced methods and strategies for presenting artworks.
Explore advanced art preservation and security measures, focusing on their impact on art viewing and experience.
Analyze the deeper impact of location on the perception and value of artworks, and study various audience perspectives.
Develop advanced skills in interpreting artworks, citing specific and contextual evidence to support interpretations.
Apply specialist criteria in art evaluation, comparing with personal criteria to understand different evaluation perspectives.
Engage in advanced community art projects, collaborating with local artists and creating art inspired by community influences.
Analyze the influence of cultural context on art responses, considering historical, geographical, and societal factors.
Review and reinforce the concepts of generating, developing, and reflecting on artistic ideas and work.
Review and reinforce the concepts of presenting, preparing, and preserving artworks.
Review and reinforce the concepts of perceiving, interpreting, and evaluating artistic works.
Review and reinforce the concepts of community art and cultural contexts.
Begin planning a comprehensive art project that incorporates creating, presenting, responding, and connecting.
Develop the comprehensive art project, applying skills and knowledge from previous weeks.
Refine and finalize the comprehensive art project, preparing for presentation.
Present the comprehensive art project to the class, focusing on presentation techniques and audience engagement.
Review and evaluate the comprehensive art projects, providing feedback and reflections.
Recap the entire course, reviewing key concepts and celebrating student achievements.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will identify advantages, disadvantages, and consequences with the design of computer devices, design projects combining hardware and software to collect and exchange data, and evaluate strategies to fix problems with computing devices and their components within a system.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify advantages, disadvantages, and consequences with the design of computer devices based on an analysis of how users interact with devices.
Design projects that combine hardware and software to collect and exchange data, considering factors such as functionality, cost, size, speed, accessibility, and aesthetics.

Evaluate strategies to fix problems with computing devices and their components within a system, including following a troubleshooting flow diagram, making changes to software, checking connections and settings, and swapping in working components.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will evaluate methods of encryption for secure transmission of information, explain how physical and digital security measures protect electronic information, and compare and contrast models to understand protocols used for data transmission.

expectations.expectationDescription: Evaluate multiple methods of encryption for the secure transmission of information, and explain how physical and digital security measures protect electronic information.
Compare and contrast models to understand the many protocols used for data transmission, focusing on understanding the purpose of protocols and how they enable secure and errorless communication.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will collect and analyze data using computational tools to create meaningful and useful models, use multiple encoding schemes to represent data, and use computational models to determine the reliability and validity of data.

expectations.expectationDescription: Collect and analyze data using computational tools to create models that are meaningful and useful, and transform data for visualization and analysis purposes.
Use multiple encoding schemes to represent data, including binary and ASCII, representing the same data in multiple ways.
Use computational models and determine the reliability and validity of data they generate, refining models by considering relevant data points, their relationships, and accuracy.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will use planning strategies to develop algorithms to address complex problems, and compare and contrast variables that represent different data types and perform operations on their values.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use planning strategies, such as flowcharts or pseudocode, to develop algorithms to address complex problems, even if not actually programming the solutions.

Compare and contrast variables representing different data types and perform operations on their values, deciding when and how to declare and name new variables and using naming conventions to improve program readability.

sections.sectionTitle: Advantages and Disadvantages of Computer Devices
sections.sectionDescription: Introduce students to the design of computer devices, focusing on the analysis of how users interact with different devices. Discuss the pros and cons of various designs.
Teach students to design projects that integrate hardware and software for data collection and exchange, considering factors like cost, size, and speed.
Evaluate different strategies for troubleshooting computing devices, including using flow diagrams, software changes, and checking connections.

outline.title: Introduction to Networks and the Internet

sections.sectionDescription: Evaluate various encryption methods for secure data transmission and explain how security measures protect electronic information.
Compare and contrast different network protocols, focusing on their purposes and how they ensure secure and errorless data transmission.

Explore different encoding schemes like binary and ASCII, and how the same data can be represented in multiple ways.
Use computational models to assess data reliability and validity, refining models by considering relevant data points and their relationships.

Compare and contrast different data types, perform operations on variables, and discuss best practices for naming and declaring variables.
Review concepts from Computing Systems, including device design, project creation, and troubleshooting.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will analyze proportional relationships, compute unit rates, recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities, and use proportional relationships to solve multi-step ratio and percent problems.

expectations.expectationDescription: Analyze proportional relationships and use them to solve mathematical problems and problems in real-world context.
Compute unit rates associated with ratios involving both simple and complex fractions, including ratios of quantities measured in like or different units.

Recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities, identify the constant of proportionality, represent proportional relationships by equations, and explain the meaning of points on the graph of a proportional relationship.
Use proportional relationships to solve multi-step ratio and percent problems involving various real-world contexts.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will apply and extend previous understanding of operations with fractions to add, subtract, multiply, and divide rational numbers except division by zero.

expectations.expectationDescription: Apply and extend previous understanding of operations with fractions to add, subtract, multiply, and divide rational numbers except division by zero.
Add and subtract integers and other rational numbers; represent addition and subtraction on a number line diagram.
Multiply and divide integers and other rational numbers, understand properties of operations, and convert rational numbers to decimal form using long division.
Solve mathematical problems and problems in real-world context involving the four operations with rational numbers, including complex fractions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will use properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions, rewrite expressions in different forms, solve multi-step mathematical problems, and use variables to represent quantities in mathematical problems.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions.
Apply properties of operations as strategies to add, subtract, factor, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients.
Rewrite an expression in different forms, and understand the relationship between the different forms and their meanings in a problem context.

Solve multi-step mathematical problems and problems in real-world context posed with positive and negative rational numbers in any form, and use variables to represent quantities in mathematical problems.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will draw, construct, and describe geometrical figures, and solve mathematical problems and problems in real-world context involving angle measure, area, surface area, and volume.

expectations.expectationDescription: Draw, construct, and describe geometrical figures, and describe the relationships between them.

Draw geometric shapes with given conditions using a variety of methods, focusing on constructing triangles from three measures of angles or sides.
Describe the two-dimensional figures that result from slicing three-dimensional figures.
Solve mathematical problems and problems in real-world context involving area, surface area, and volume of two-dimensional and three-dimensional objects.
Understand and use the formulas for the area and circumference of a circle to solve problems, and give an informal derivation of the relationship between the circumference and area of a circle.
Use facts about supplementary, complementary, vertical, and adjacent angles in multi-step problems to write and solve simple equations for an unknown angle in a figure.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will use random sampling to draw inferences about a population, draw informal comparative inferences about two populations, and investigate chance processes and develop, use, and evaluate probability models.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use random sampling to draw inferences about a population.
Understand that statistics can be used to gain information about a population by examining a sample of the population, and support valid inferences from random samples.
Use data from a random sample to draw inferences about a population with an unknown characteristic of interest, and generate multiple samples to gauge the variation in estimates or predictions.
Draw informal comparative inferences about two populations and use measures of center and measures of variability for numerical data to draw comparative inferences.

Informally assess the degree of visual overlap of two numerical data distributions with similar variabilities, and measure the difference between the centers by expressing it as a multiple of a measure of variability.
Use measures of center and measures of variability for numerical data from random samples to draw informal comparative inferences about two populations.
Investigate chance processes and develop, use, and evaluate probability models.
Understand that the probability of a chance event is a number between 0 and 1 that expresses the likelihood of the event occurring.
Approximate the probability of a chance event by collecting data on the chance process that produces it and observing its long-run relative frequency.
Develop a probability model and use it to find probabilities of events, compare probabilities from a model to observed frequencies, and explain possible sources of discrepancy.

sections.sectionDescription: Introduce the concept of ratios and how they are used to compare quantities.
Teach students how to compute unit rates associated with ratios involving both simple and complex fractions.
Help students recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities.

sections.sectionDescription: Teach long division to convert rational numbers to decimal form.

sections.sectionDescription: Solve real-world problems involving the four operations with rational numbers, including complex fractions.

sections.sectionDescription: Use measures of center and variability to draw informal comparative inferences about two populations.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will explore how cause and effect take place within and between a wide variety of force and motion systems from forces on individual objects to the forces that shape our Earth.

expectations.expectationDescription: Collect and analyze data demonstrating how electromagnetic forces can be attractive or repulsive and can vary in strength.
Develop and use a model to predict how forces act on objects at a distance.
Plan and carry out an investigation that can support an evidence-based explanation of how objects on Earth are affected by gravitational force.
Use non-algebraic mathematics and computational thinking to explain Newtonâ€™s laws of motion.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop an understanding of the patterns of energy flow along with matter cycling within and among Earthâ€™s systems.

expectations.expectationDescription: Construct a model that shows the cycling of matter and flow of energy in the atmosphere, hydrosphere, and geosphere.
Construct a model to explain how the distribution of fossils and rocks, continental shapes, and seafloor structures provides evidence of past plate motions.
Analyze and interpret data to construct an explanation for how advances in technology have improved weather prediction.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop an understanding of the structure and function of cells.

expectations.expectationDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information to provide evidence that all living things are made of cells, cells come from existing cells, and cells are the basic structural and functional unit of all living things.
Construct an explanation to demonstrate the relationship between major cell structures and cell functions (plant and animal).
Develop and use a model to explain how cells, tissues, and organ systems maintain life (animals).
Construct an explanation for how organisms maintain internal stability and evaluate the effect of external factors on organismsâ€™ internal stability.
Construct an explanation for how some plant cells convert light energy into food energy.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Take risks to pursue ideas, themes, meanings, and approaches that emerge in the process of art-making or designing.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use tools, materials, and processes purposefully and demonstrate awareness of practices, issues, and ethics of appropriation, fair use, copyright, open source, and creative commons as they apply to creating works of art and design.
Select, organize, and design images and words to make visually clear and compelling presentations.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Apply relevant criteria to examine, reflect on, and plan revisions for a work of art or design in progress.

expectations.expectationDescription: Develop and apply criteria for evaluating a collection of artworks for presentation.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Select, Analyze, and Interpret Artistic Work for Performance

expectations.expectationDescription: Develop and apply criteria for evaluating a collection of artworks for presentation.
Collaboratively prepare and present selected theme-based artwork for display, and formulate exhibition narratives for the viewer.
Analyze how the choice of what art or design to preserve reflects the values of the community.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Perceive and Analyze Artistic Work

expectations.expectationDescription: Explain how artistsâ€™ choices of visual characteristics are influenced by the culture and environment in which they live.
Compare and contrast contexts in which viewers encounter images that influence ideas, emotions, and actions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Synthesize and Relate Knowledge and Personal Experiences to Make Art

expectations.expectationDescription: Make art collaboratively to reflect on and reinforce positive aspects of group identity.
Distinguish different ways art is used to represent, establish, reinforce, and reflect group identity.

sections.sectionDescription: Introduce students to the concept of generating and conceptualizing artistic ideas. Discuss the importance of creativity in art.
Teach students how to document the early stages of the creative process using images or words in various media.
Guide students in collaboratively shaping an artistic investigation of a contemporary issue using modern art practices.
Encourage students to take risks and pursue new ideas, themes, and approaches in their art-making process.

outline.title: Tools, Materials, and Ethics in Art

sections.sectionDescription: Teach students to use tools, materials, and processes purposefully while being aware of ethical issues like appropriation and copyright.
Instruct students on how to select, organize, and design images and words to create visually compelling presentations.
Teach students how to apply relevant criteria to examine and reflect on their art, planning necessary revisions.
Develop and apply criteria for evaluating a collection of artworks for presentation.
Guide students in selecting, analyzing, and interpreting artistic work for performance and presentation.
Develop and apply criteria for evaluating a collection of artworks for presentation.
Collaboratively prepare and present theme-based artwork for display, creating narratives for the viewer.
Analyze how choices of art or design preservation reflect community values.
Discuss how artists' visual choices are influenced by their culture and environment.
Compare and contrast contexts in which viewers encounter images that influence their ideas, emotions, and actions.

outline.title: Connecting Knowledge and Experience in Art

sections.sectionDescription: Explore how art is used to represent, establish, reinforce, and reflect group identity.
Engage students in collaborative art projects to reflect on and reinforce positive aspects of group identity.
Review the concepts and skills covered in weeks 1 to 6, reinforcing understanding and application.
Review the concepts and skills covered in weeks 7 to 12, reinforcing understanding and application.
Review the concepts and skills covered in weeks 13 to 15, reinforcing understanding and application.
Explore advanced techniques in documenting the creative process using various media.
Engage in advanced collaborative art projects focusing on contemporary issues.
Encourage taking advanced risks in exploring new themes and meanings in art.
Discuss advanced issues in the ethical use of tools and materials in art creation.
Create advanced, visually compelling presentations using sophisticated design techniques.
Apply advanced criteria to refine and complete artistic work, focusing on detailed revisions.
Develop professional-level presentations of art collections, focusing on theme and audience.
Curate advanced theme-based exhibitions, developing narratives for a professional display.
Analyze how advanced choices in art preservation reflect and influence community values.
Explore how advanced visual characteristics in art are influenced by culture and environment.
Conduct advanced comparisons of contexts in which viewers encounter images and their influence.
Explore advanced methods of creating art that reflects and reinforces group identity.
Engage in advanced collaborative art projects focusing on group identity and cultural reflection.
Review advanced concepts and skills covered in weeks 17 to 23, reinforcing application.
Review advanced concepts and skills covered in weeks 24 to 29, reinforcing application.
Begin planning final projects, applying all learned skills and concepts to create comprehensive artworks.
Develop final projects, incorporating feedback and refining artistic techniques.
Refine final projects, ensuring all criteria are met and the artworks are presentation-ready.
Present final projects to the class, explaining the creative process and decisions made.
Reflect on the course, reviewing key concepts and discussing growth and future applications in art.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Improve the design of computing devices based on an analysis of how users interact with them, and consider unintended consequences.

expectations.expectationDescription: The study of humanâ€“computer interaction (HCI) can improve the design of devices, including both hardware and software.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Design and evaluate projects that combine hardware and software components to collect and exchange data.

expectations.expectationDescription: Collecting and exchanging data involves input, output, storage, and processing.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Systematically identify and develop strategies to fix problems with computing devices and their components.

expectations.expectationDescription: Since a computing device may interact with interconnected devices within a system, problems may not be due to the computing device itself but to devices or components connected to it.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Apply multiple methods of encryption to model the secure transmission of information.

expectations.expectationDescription: Encryption can be as simple as letter substitution or as complicated as modern methods used to secure networks and the Internet.
Evaluate how various physical and digital security measures protect electronic information and how a lack of such measures could lead to vulnerabilities.
Develop models to illustrate the role of protocols in transmitting data across networks and the Internet.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Collect data using computational tools and transform the data to make it more meaningful and useful.

expectations.expectationDescription: As students continue to build on their ability to organize and present data visually to support a claim, they will need to understand when and how to transform data for this purpose.
Represent data using multiple encoding schemes including binary and ASCII.
Design computational models and evaluate them based on the reliability and validity of the data they generate.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Develop planning strategies, such as flowcharts or pseudocode, to develop algorithms to address complex problems.

expectations.expectationDescription: Complex problems are problems that would be difficult for students to solve computationally.
Create named variables that represent different data types and perform operations on their values.
Design and iteratively develop programs that combine control structures, including nested loops and compound conditionals.
Decompose problems into parts to facilitate the design, implementation, and review of programs.
Create procedures with parameters to organize code and make it easier to reuse.
Seek and incorporate feedback from team members and users to refine a solution that meets user needs.
Incorporate existing code, media, and libraries into original programs, and give attribution.
Systematically test and refine programs using a range of possible inputs.
Distribute and execute tasks while maintaining a project timeline when collaboratively developing computational artifacts.
Document programs to make them easier to follow, test, and debug.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Compare and contrast tradeoffs associated with computing technologies that affect people's everyday activities and career options.

expectations.expectationDescription: Advancements in computer technology are neither wholly positive nor negative.
Develop a solution to address an issue of bias or accessibility in the design of existing technologies.
Collaborate with contributors by using digital technologies when creating a computational product.
Evaluate the benefits and risks associated with sharing information digitally.

sections.sectionDescription: Introduction to how computing systems work and their impact on society. Discuss the basic components and functions of computing devices.
Study how human-computer interaction can enhance device design, focusing on both hardware and software improvements.
Explore the integration of hardware and software to design projects that collect and exchange data.
Learn about data collection, input, output, storage, and processing methods.
Develop strategies for identifying and fixing problems in computing devices and their components.
Understand how problems may arise from interconnected devices rather than the computing device itself.

outline.title: Introduction to Networks and the Internet

sections.sectionDescription: Overview of networks and the internet, including basic principles and components.
Learn about various encryption methods from simple letter substitution to complex modern techniques.
Evaluate physical and digital security measures to protect electronic information and understand potential vulnerabilities.
Develop models to illustrate the role of protocols in data transmission across networks and the internet.
Collect data using computational tools and transform it to make it meaningful and useful.
Learn techniques for organizing and presenting data visually to support a claim and when to transform data.
Represent data using multiple encoding schemes, including binary and ASCII.
Design computational models and evaluate them based on the reliability and validity of the data they generate.
Develop planning strategies such as flowcharts or pseudocode to address complex problems.
Understand what makes problems complex and how to solve them computationally.
Create named variables representing different data types and perform operations on their values.
Design and iteratively develop programs using control structures, including nested loops and compound conditionals.
Decompose problems into parts to facilitate design, implementation, and review of programs.
Create procedures with parameters to organize code and make it easier to reuse.
Seek and incorporate feedback from team members and users to refine solutions.
Incorporate existing code, media, and libraries into original programs, ensuring proper attribution.
Systematically test and refine programs using a range of possible inputs.
Distribute and execute tasks while maintaining a project timeline when collaboratively developing computational artifacts.
Document programs to make them easier to follow, test, and debug.
Compare and contrast tradeoffs associated with computing technologies and their effects on everyday activities and career options.
Discuss how advancements in computer technology can have both positive and negative impacts.
Develop solutions to address issues of bias or accessibility in existing technologies.
Collaborate with contributors using digital technologies to create computational products.
Evaluate the benefits and risks associated with sharing information digitally.

outline.title: Review Week: Computing Systems and HCI

sections.sectionDescription: Review the design and interaction of computing systems and how HCI can improve these systems.

outline.title: Review Week: Hardware, Software, and Troubleshooting

sections.sectionDescription: Review the integration of hardware and software components and troubleshooting techniques.

outline.title: Review Week: Networks and the Internet

sections.sectionDescription: Review the concepts of networks and the internet, including encryption and data transmission protocols.
Review data collection, transformation, encoding, and computational models.
Review planning strategies, control structures, and collaborative development in programming.
Review the tradeoffs, bias, accessibility, and collaborative aspects of computing technologies.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Understand that there are irrational numbers, and approximate them using rational numbers.

expectations.expectationDescription: Know that numbers that are not rational are called irrational. Understand informally that every number has a decimal expansion. Know that numbers whose decimal expansions do not terminate in zeros or in a repeating sequence of fixed digits are called irrational.
Use rational approximations of irrational numbers to compare the size of irrational numbers. Locate them approximately on a number line diagram, and estimate their value.

Understand that given any two distinct rational numbers, a < b, there exist a rational number c and an irrational number d such that a < c < b and a < d < b. Given any two distinct irrational numbers, a < b, there exist a rational number c and an irrational number d such that a < c < b and a < d < b.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Work with radicals and integer exponents.

expectations.expectationDescription: Understand and apply the properties of integer exponents to generate equivalent numerical expressions.

Use square root and cube root symbols to represent solutions to equations of the form x^2 = p and x^3= p, where p is a positive rational number. Know that âˆš2 is irrational. a. Evaluate square roots of perfect squares less than or equal to 225. b. Evaluate cube roots of perfect cubes less than or equal to 1000.
Use numbers expressed in the form of a single digit times an integer power of 10 to estimate very large or very small quantities, and express how many times larger or smaller one is than the other.

Perform operations with numbers expressed in scientific notation including problems where both decimal and scientific notation are used. Use scientific notation and choose units of appropriate size for measurements of very large or very small quantities.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Define, evaluate, and compare functions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Understand that a function is a rule that assigns to each input exactly one output. The graph of a function is the set of ordered pairs consisting of an input and the corresponding output. (Function notation is not required in Grade 8.)

Compare properties of two functions each represented in a different way (algebraically, graphically, numerically in tables, or by verbal descriptions). For example, given a linear function represented by a table of values and a linear function represented by an algebraic expression, determine which function has the greater rate of change.

Interpret the equation y = mx + b as defining a linear function whose graph is a straight line; give examples of functions that are not linear. For example, the function A = s^2 giving the area of a square as a function of its side length in not linear because its graph contains the points (1,1), (2,4), and (3,9) which are not on a straight line.

Given a description of a situation, generate a function to model a linear relationship between two quantities. Determine the rate of change and initial value of the function from a description of a relationship or from two (x, y) values, including reading these from a table or a graph. Track how the values of the two quantities change together. Interpret the rate of change and initial value of a linear function in terms of the situation it models, its graph, or its table of values.

Describe qualitatively the functional relationship between two quantities by analyzing a graph (e.g., where the function is increasing or decreasing, linear or nonlinear). Sketch a graph that exhibits the qualitative features of a function that has been described verbally.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Understand congruence and similarity.

expectations.expectationDescription: Verify experimentally the properties of rotations, reflections, and translations. Properties include: lines are taken to lines, line segments are taken to line segments of the same length, angles are taken to angles of the same measure, parallel lines are taken to parallel lines.

Understand that a two-dimensional figure is congruent to another if one can be obtained from the other by a sequence of rotations, reflections, and translations; given two congruent figures, describe a sequence that demonstrates congruence.
Describe the effect of dilations, translations, rotations, and reflections on two-dimensional figures using coordinates.

Understand that a two-dimensional figure is similar to another if, and only if, one can be obtained from the other by a sequence of rotations, reflections, translations, and dilations; given two similar two-dimensional figures, describe a sequence that demonstrates similarity.

Use informal arguments to establish facts about the angle sum and exterior angle of triangles, about the angles created when parallel lines are cut by a transversal, and the angle-angle criterion for similarity of triangles. For example, arrange three copies of the same triangle so that the sum of the three angles appears to form a line, and give an argument in terms of transversals why this is so.
Understand the Pythagorean Theorem and its converse.
Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to determine unknown side lengths in right triangles in real-world context and mathematical problems in two and three dimensions.
Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to find the distance between two points in a coordinate system.
Understand and use formulas for volumes of cones, cylinders and spheres and use them to solve real-world context and mathematical problems.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Investigate patterns of association in bivariate data and investigate chance processes and develop, use, and evaluate probability models.

expectations.expectationDescription: Construct and interpret scatter plots for bivariate measurement data to investigate and describe patterns such as clustering, outliers, positive or negative association, linear association, and nonlinear association.

Know that straight lines are widely used to model relationships between two quantitative variables. For scatter plots that suggest a linear association, informally fit a straight line, and informally assess the model fit by judging the closeness of the data points to the line.
Use the equation of a linear model to solve problems in the context of bivariate measurement data, interpreting the slope and intercept.

Understand that patterns of association can also be seen in bivariate categorical data by displaying frequencies and relative frequencies in a two-way table. Construct and interpret a two-way table summarizing data on two categorical variables collected from the same subjects. Use relative frequencies calculated for rows or columns to describe possible association between the two variables.

Find probabilities of compound events using organized lists, tables, tree diagrams, and simulation. a. Understand that the probability of a compound event is the fraction of outcomes in the sample space for which the compound event occurs. b. Represent sample spaces for compound events using organized lists, tables, tree diagrams and other methods. Identify the outcomes in the sample space which compose the event. c. Design and use a simulation to generate frequencies for compound events.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Develop mathematical habits of mind.

expectations.expectationDescription: Make sense of problems and persevere in solving them.
Reason abstractly and quantitatively.
Construct viable arguments and critique the reasoning of others.
Model with mathematics.
Use appropriate tools strategically.
Attend to precision.
Look for and make use of structure.
Look for and express regularity in repeated reasoning.

sections.sectionDescription: Introduce irrational numbers and explain how they differ from rational numbers. Discuss decimal expansions that do not terminate or repeat.
Teach students to use rational approximations to compare the size of irrational numbers and locate them on a number line.
Explain how between any two rational numbers there exists a rational and an irrational number, and illustrate this concept with examples.
Introduce and apply the properties of integer exponents to generate equivalent numerical expressions.
Use square root and cube root symbols to solve equations. Evaluate square roots of perfect squares and cube roots of perfect cubes.
Teach students to use scientific notation to express very large or small quantities and compare their sizes.
Perform operations with numbers in scientific notation and choose appropriate units for measurements.
Define a function and explore its representation as a set of ordered pairs.
Compare properties of functions represented in different ways: algebraically, graphically, and in tables.
Interpret linear functions and give examples of nonlinear functions.
Create linear models from descriptions, determine rate of change and initial values, and interpret these in various contexts.
Describe relationships between quantities by analyzing graphs, and sketch graphs based on verbal descriptions.
Verify experimentally the properties of rotations, reflections, and translations.
Explain congruence through sequences of rotations, reflections, and translations.
Describe how transformations affect figures using coordinate notation.
Explain similarity through sequences of transformations.
Establish facts about angle sums, exterior angles, and angles created by transversals with parallel lines.
Understand and prove the Pythagorean Theorem and its converse.
Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to determine unknown side lengths in right triangles in various contexts.
Find the distance between two points in a coordinate system using the Pythagorean Theorem.
Understand and use formulas for the volumes of cones, cylinders, and spheres to solve problems.
Construct and interpret scatter plots to identify patterns of association between bivariate data.
Informally fit a straight line to data in scatter plots and assess the closeness of the fit.
Use linear equations to solve problems involving bivariate measurement data, interpreting slopes and intercepts.
Construct and interpret two-way tables to summarize data on two categorical variables and identify patterns of association.
Find probabilities of compound events using organized lists, tables, tree diagrams, and simulations.
Develop strategies for making sense of problems and persevering in solving them.
Enhance abilities to reason abstractly and quantitatively.
Learn to construct viable arguments and critique the reasoning of others.
Apply mathematics to solve real-world problems by creating models.
Choose and use appropriate mathematical tools strategically to solve problems.
Focus on precision in mathematical calculations and communication.
Identify and use structure to solve problems more efficiently.
Recognize and use patterns in repeated reasoning to solve problems.
Review topics from weeks 1-9 to reinforce understanding and address any gaps.
Review topics from weeks 10-18 to reinforce understanding and address any gaps.
Conduct a comprehensive review of all topics and administer a final assessment.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students apply stability and change to explore chemical properties of matter and chemical reactions to further understand energy and matter.

expectations.expectationDescription: Develop and use a model to demonstrate that atoms and molecules can be combined or rearranged in chemical reactions to form new compounds with the total number of each type of atom conserved.
Obtain and evaluate information regarding how scientists identify substances based on unique physical and chemical properties.
Construct an explanation on how energy can be transferred from one energy store to another.
Develop and use mathematical models to explain wave characteristics and interactions.
Develop a solution to increase efficiency when transferring energy from one source to another.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop an understanding of patterns and how genetic information is passed from generation to generation. They also develop the understanding of how traits within populations change over time.

expectations.expectationDescription: Construct an explanation of how genetic variations occur in offspring through the inheritance of traits or through mutations.

Communicate how advancements in technology have furthered the field of genetic research and use evidence to support an argument about the positive and negative effects of genetic research on human lives.
Develop and use a model to explain how natural selection may lead to increases and decreases of specific traits in populations over time.
Gather and communicate evidence on how the process of natural selection provides an explanation of how new species can evolve.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students explore natural and human-induced cause-and-effect changes in Earth systems over time.

expectations.expectationDescription: Analyze and interpret data about the Earthâ€™s geological column to communicate relative ages of rock layers and fossils.
Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information about data and historical patterns to predict natural hazards and other geological events.
Construct and support an argument about how human consumption of limited resources impacts the biosphere.

sections.sectionDescription: Students will learn about the basic structure of atoms and molecules, including their properties and how they combine or rearrange in chemical reactions.

outline.title: Chemical Reactions and Conservation of Matter

sections.sectionDescription: Students will develop models to demonstrate how atoms and molecules interact in chemical reactions, emphasizing the conservation of atoms.
Students will evaluate how scientists identify substances using unique physical and chemical properties.
Students will construct explanations on the different ways energy can be transferred from one store to another.
Students will develop mathematical models to explain wave characteristics and their interactions.
Students will develop solutions to increase efficiency in transferring energy from one source to another.
Students will construct explanations on how genetic variations occur in offspring through inheritance or mutations.
Students will explore how technology has advanced genetic research and discuss its positive and negative impacts on human lives.
Students will develop models to explain how natural selection can lead to changes in specific traits within populations over time.
Students will gather and communicate evidence on how natural selection provides an explanation for the evolution of new species.

outline.title: Introduction to Earth and Space Science

sections.sectionDescription: Students will analyze and interpret data about the Earth's geological column to understand the relative ages of rock layers and fossils.
Students will evaluate and communicate information on historical data to predict natural hazards and geological events.
Students will construct arguments on how human consumption of limited resources impacts the biosphere.
Students will review key concepts and objectives from the Physical Science Standards covered in weeks 1-6.
Students will review key concepts and objectives from the Life Science Standards covered in weeks 7-10.

sections.sectionTitle: Review Earth and Space Science Standards
sections.sectionDescription: Students will review key concepts and objectives from the Earth and Space Science Standards covered in weeks 11-13.
Students will delve deeper into complex chemical reactions and the conservation of matter, building on prior knowledge.
Students will engage in detailed studies and experiments to identify substances using physical properties.
Students will explore advanced concepts in energy transfer between different stores, incorporating real-world applications.
Students will study advanced wave phenomena, focusing on wave interactions and real-world applications.
Students will develop and test innovative solutions to improve energy transfer efficiency.
Students will conduct in-depth studies on genetic variations and mutations, including case studies.
Students will debate and discuss the ethical implications of advancements in genetic research.
Students will explore natural selection in detail, using models and simulations to understand its impact on populations.
Students will study the process of speciation and how new species evolve through natural selection.
Students will conduct detailed analyses of geological data to understand the Earth's history and rock formations.
Students will use advanced techniques to predict and analyze natural hazards and geological events.
Students will study human impacts on the biosphere and develop strategies for sustainable resource management.

sections.sectionTitle: Review Advanced Topics in Physical Science
sections.sectionDescription: Students will review advanced topics and applications from the Physical Science Standards.

sections.sectionTitle: Review Advanced Topics in Life Science
sections.sectionDescription: Students will review advanced topics and applications from the Life Science Standards.

sections.sectionTitle: Review Advanced Topics in Earth and Space Science
sections.sectionDescription: Students will review advanced topics and applications from the Earth and Space Science Standards.
Students will engage in a comprehensive review of all Physical Science topics covered.
Students will engage in a comprehensive review of all Life Science topics covered.

sections.sectionTitle: Comprehensive Review of Earth and Space Science
sections.sectionDescription: Students will engage in a comprehensive review of all Earth and Space Science topics covered.
Students will begin planning their final projects, incorporating knowledge from all science disciplines covered.
Students will present their final projects, demonstrating their understanding and application of the science standards.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students leverage technology to take an active role in choosing, achieving, and demonstrating competency in their learning goals, informed by the learning sciences.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students articulate personal learning goals, select, and manage appropriate technologies to achieve them, and reflect on their successes and areas of improvement in working toward their goals.
Students identify and begin to develop online networks of experts and peers to customize their learning environments in accordance with school policy.
Students integrate feedback from people and digital tools to improve their learning process, and they select technology to demonstrate their learning in a variety of ways.
Students navigate a variety of technologies and transfer their skills to troubleshoot and learn how to use new technologies.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students recognize the rights, responsibilities, and opportunities of living, learning, and working in an interconnected digital world, and they act and model in ways that are safe, legal, and ethical.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students cultivate their digital identities and reputations within a digital environment and understand that digital actions are permanent.
Students demonstrate and advocate for positive, safe, legal, and ethical behavior when using technology and when interacting with others online.
Students demonstrate and advocate for an understanding of intellectual property including copyright, permission, and fair use by including appropriate citation and attribution elements.
Students demonstrate an understanding of what personal data is, how it is collected, and how to keep it private and secure, including the awareness of current technology terms and processes.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students critically curate a variety of resources using digital tools to construct knowledge, produce creative artifacts, and make meaningful learning experiences for themselves and others.
