expectations.expectationDescription: Students practice and improve research strategies to locate information and other resources for their intellectual or creative pursuits.
Students practice evaluating the accuracy, perspective, credibility, and relevance of information, media, data or other resources.
Students locate and collect a variety of resources and organize information to make meaningful connections.
Students explore real-world problems and issues and actively pursue solutions for them.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students use a variety of technologies within a design process to identify and solve problems by creating new, useful or imaginative solutions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students engage in a design process for generating and testing ideas and developing innovative products to solve problems.
Students select and use digital tools to support a design process and expand their understanding to identify constraints and trade-offs and to weigh risks.
Students engage in a design process to develop, test, and revise prototypes, embrace the iterative process of trial and error, and understand setbacks as potential opportunities for improvement.
Students demonstrate an ability to persevere and handle greater ambiguity as they work to solve open-ended problems.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students develop and employ strategies for understanding and solving problems in ways that leverage the power of technological methods to develop and test solutions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students practice defining and solving problems by selecting technology for data analysis, modeling, and algorithmic thinking.
Students find and organize data and use technology to analyze and represent it to solve problems and make decisions.
Students break problems into component parts, identify key pieces, and use that information to solve problems.
Students understand how automation works and apply algorithmic thinking to design and automate solutions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students communicate clearly and express themselves creatively for a variety of purposes using the platforms, tools, styles, formats and digital media appropriate to their goals.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students select appropriate platforms and tools to create, share, and communicate their work effectively.
Students create original works or responsibly repurpose digital resources into new creative works.
Students create artifacts using digital tools to communicate complex ideas textually, visually, graphically, and auditorily.
Students publish or present content designed for intended audiences and select platforms that effectively convey their ideas.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students use digital tools to broaden their perspectives and enrich their learning by collaborating with others and working effectively in teams locally and globally.

expectations.expectationDescription: Students use digital tools to interact with others to develop a richer understanding of different perspectives and cultures.
Students use collaborative technologies to connect with others, including peers, experts and community members, to learn about issues and problems or to gain a broader perspective.
Students perform a variety of roles within a team, using age-appropriate technology to complete a project or solve a problem.
Students work with others, using collaborative technologies to explore local and global issues and investigate and advocate for possible solutions.

sections.sectionDescription: Introduce students to the concept of being an empowered learner and how technology can help them achieve their learning goals.
Teach students how to articulate their personal learning goals and manage appropriate technologies to achieve them.
Guide students in identifying and developing online networks of experts and peers to customize their learning environments.
Help students learn how to integrate feedback from people and digital tools to improve their learning process.
Teach students to navigate a variety of technologies and transfer their skills to troubleshoot and learn new technologies.
Introduce students to the concept of digital citizenship and its importance in the digital world.
Teach students how to cultivate their digital identities and understand the permanence of digital actions.

outline.title: Digital Citizen - Safe and Ethical Behavior

sections.sectionDescription: Guide students in demonstrating and advocating for positive, safe, legal, and ethical behavior when using technology.
Teach students about intellectual property, including copyright, permission, and fair use, with appropriate citation and attribution.
Educate students on what personal data is, how it is collected, and how to keep it private and secure.
Introduce students to the concept of knowledge construction using digital tools.
Teach students research strategies to locate information and resources for their intellectual or creative pursuits.
Guide students in evaluating the accuracy, perspective, credibility, and relevance of information and other resources.
Teach students how to locate, collect, and organize resources to make meaningful connections.
Encourage students to explore real-world problems and actively pursue solutions.
Introduce students to innovative design processes using technology.
Teach students to engage in a design process to generate and test ideas and develop innovative solutions.
Guide students in selecting and using digital tools to support the design process, identifying constraints and trade-offs.
Teach students to develop, test, and revise prototypes, embracing trial and error.
Encourage students to persevere and handle ambiguity in solving open-ended problems.
Introduce students to computational thinking and its importance in solving problems.
Teach students to define and solve problems using technology for data analysis, modeling, and algorithmic thinking.
Guide students in finding, organizing, analyzing, and representing data to solve problems and make decisions.
Teach students to break problems into component parts, identify key pieces, and use that information to solve problems.
Educate students on how automation works and how to apply algorithmic thinking to design and automate solutions.
Introduce students to creative communication and the use of digital tools for effective expression.
Teach students to select appropriate platforms and tools to create, share, and communicate their work effectively.
Guide students in creating original works or responsibly repurposing digital resources into new creative works.
Teach students to create artifacts using digital tools to communicate complex ideas textually, visually, graphically, and auditorily.
Guide students in publishing or presenting content designed for intended audiences using effective platforms.
Introduce students to global collaboration and the use of digital tools to broaden their perspectives.
Teach students to use digital tools to interact with others and develop a richer understanding of different perspectives and cultures.
Guide students in using collaborative technologies to connect with others and learn about issues and problems.
Teach students to perform a variety of roles within a team using age-appropriate technology to complete projects or solve problems.

outline.title: Global Collaborator - Local and Global Issues

sections.sectionDescription: Encourage students to use collaborative technologies to explore local and global issues and advocate for solutions.
Review and reflect on the key concepts covered throughout the course, reinforcing understanding and preparing for future learning.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Generate and Conceptualize Artistic Ideas

expectations.expectationDescription: Engage collaboratively (e.g., pairs, small groups, whole group) in exploration and imaginative play with materials (e.g., puppets, model towns, paper murals).
Use careful observation in preparation for making a work of art.
Explore uses of materials, tools, approaches (e.g., using elements of modern art, applying artistic ideas from diverse cultures) to create works of art or design.
Demonstrate safe and proper procedures for using materials, tools, and equipment while making art.
Identify and classify uses of everyday objects through drawings, diagrams, sculptures, or other visual means.
Use art vocabulary to describe choices in personal artwork.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Select, Analyze, and Interpret Artistic Work for Performance

expectations.expectationDescription: Explain why some objects, artifacts, and artwork are valued over others.
Give reasonable answers to questions about preserving artworks (e.g., where, when, why, how artwork should be preserved).
Identify the roles and responsibilities of people who work in and visit museums and other art venues.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Perceive and Analyze Artistic Work

expectations.expectationDescription: Select and describe the subject matter of art (e.g., artworks that illustrate daily life experiences of yourself and others).
Compare images that represent the same subject matter.
Interpret identifying subject matter and describing relevant details.
Classify artwork based on different reasons for preferences (e.g., favorite color, favorite subject matter).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Synthesize and Relate Knowledge and Personal Experiences to Make Art

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify times, places, and reasons by which students make art outside of school.
Identify a variety of reasons why people from different places and times make art (e.g., to express themselves, to tell a story, to make things look beautiful, to remember special people and events).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Recognize that technology provides the opportunity to enhance relevance, increase confidence, offer authentic choice, and produce positive impacts in learning.

Use digital tools (e.g. computers, tablets, cameras, software, 3D printers, etc.â€¦) to build knowledge, produce creative artifacts, and make meaningful learning experiences for themselves and others.

expectations.expectationDescription: Recognize the letters, numbers, and basic functions of a keyboard, touchpad/trackpad, mouse, and other input devices.
Use the letters, numbers, and basic functions of the keyboard effectively (shift, space, tab, enter/return).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Identify the rights, responsibilities, and opportunities of living, learning, and working in an interconnected society and model behaviors that are safe, legal, and ethical.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify personal information, understand the need to keep it private, and engage in activities for keeping personal information private.
Participate in systems for keeping personal information private and protected (for example: passwords, biometric sensors).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use the Design Process (use, modify, create) with a variety of tools to identify and solve problems by creating new, modified, or imaginative solutions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Understand that a model is used for developing and testing ideas for a diverse range of users.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Develop and employ Computational Thinking strategies (break-down, find patterns, and create algorithms) to identify and solve problems.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify patterns.
Use Algorithms (a set of step-by-step instructions) to construct programs (using a block-based programming language or unplugged activities) that accomplish a task as a means of creative expression.
Identify multiple ways solutions can be applied to solve problems. Vocabulary Term: Abstraction.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use digital tools to creatively share and express ideas.

expectations.expectationDescription: Create a variety of artifacts.
Exchange information or ideas clearly and creatively using digital tools while considering audience and intended purpose.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use digital tools to collaborate with others both locally and globally.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify technology (hardware and software) that allows collaboration with others.
Use digital tools to connect with individuals from different backgrounds and cultures.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Select appropriate sources to conduct authentic research to produce a relevant and credible product.

expectations.expectationDescription: Understand that answers to questions can be found through research from a variety of sources.
Understand that resources on the Internet vary in quality and are found in a variety of places so care is needed in selection.
Understand there is an appropriate place to find information to research the answer to a question.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Understand how people can use technology.

expectations.expectationDescription: Understand that technology is everywhere and changes our lives.
Understand that there is a connection between people and devices.
Practice using and identifying basic hardware and software using accurate terminology.
Create simple artifacts using a computing device.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Display perseverance and patience in problem-solving. Demonstrate skills and strategies needed to succeed in mathematics, including critical thinking, reasoning, and effective collaboration and expression. Seek help and apply feedback. Set and monitor goals.
Demonstrate and explain the relationship between numbers and quantities up to 20; connect counting to cardinality (the last number counted represents the total quantity in a set).

expectations.expectationDescription: Count up to 20 objects in a variety of structured arrangements and up to 10 objects in a scattered arrangement.
When counting objects, explain that the last number counted represents the total quantity in a set (cardinality), regardless of the arrangement and order.
Given a number from 1-20, identify the number that is one more or one less.
Identify pennies, nickels, and dimes and know their name and value.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use count sequences within 100 to count forward and backward in sequence.

expectations.expectationDescription: Count forward to 100 by tens and ones and backward from 20 by ones.
Count forward beginning from any number within 100 and count backward from any number within 20.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use place value understanding to compose and decompose numbers from 11â€“19.

expectations.expectationDescription: Describe numbers from 11 to 19 by composing (putting together) and decomposing (breaking apart) the numbers into ten ones and some more ones.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Identify, write, represent, and compare numbers up to 20.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify written numerals 0-20 and represent a number of objects with a written numeral 0-20 (with 0 representing a count of no objects).
Compare two sets of up to 10 objects and identify whether the number of objects in one group is more or less than the other group, using the words 'greater than,' 'less than,' or 'the same as'.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Explain the concepts of addition, subtraction, and equality and use these concepts to solve real-life problems within 10.

expectations.expectationDescription: Compose (put together) and decompose (break apart) numbers up to 10 using objects and drawings.
Represent addition and subtraction within 10 from a given authentic situation using a variety of representations and strategies.
Use a variety of strategies to solve addition and subtraction problems within 10.
Fluently add and subtract within 5 using a variety of strategies to solve practical, mathematical problems.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Explain, extend, and create repeating patterns with a repetition, not exceeding 4 and describe patterns involving the passage of time.

expectations.expectationDescription: Create, extend, and describe repeating patterns with numbers and shapes, and explain the rationale for the pattern.
Describe patterns involving the passage of time using words and phrases related to actual events.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Observe, describe, and compare the physical and measurable attributes of objects and analyze graphical displays of data to answer relevant questions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Directly compare, describe, and order common objects, using measurable attributes (length, height, width, or weight) and describe the difference.
Classify and sort up to ten objects into categories by an attribute; count the number of objects in each category and sort the categories by count.
Ask questions and answer them based on gathered information, observations, and appropriate graphical displays to solve problems relevant to everyday life.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Identify, describe, and compare basic shapes encountered in the environment, and form two-dimensional shapes and three-dimensional figures.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify, sort, classify, analyze, and compare two-dimensional shapes and three-dimensional figures, in different sizes and orientations, using informal language to describe their similarities, differences, number of sides and vertices, and other attributes.
Describe the relative location of an object using positional words.
Use basic shapes to represent specific shapes found in the environment by creating models and drawings.
Use two or more basic shapes to form larger shapes.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate observations about time patterns (day to night and night to day) and objects (sun, moon, stars) in the day and night sky.

expectations.expectationDescription: Ask questions to classify objects according to those seen in the day sky, the night sky, and both.
Develop a model to communicate the changes that occur in the sky during the day, as day turns into night, during the night, and as night turns into day using pictures and words.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information to describe the physical attributes of earth materials (soil, rocks, water, and air).

expectations.expectationDescription: Ask questions to identify and describe earth materialsâ€”soil, rocks, water, and air.
Construct an argument supported by evidence for how rocks can be grouped by physical attributes (size, weight, texture, color).
Use tools to observe and record physical attributes of soil such as texture and color.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information to describe objects in terms of the materials they are made of and their physical attributes.

expectations.expectationDescription: Ask questions to compare and sort objects made of different materials. (Common materials include clay, cloth, plastic, wood, paper, and metal.)
Use senses and science tools to classify common objects, such as buttons or swatches of cloth, according to their physical attributes (color, size, shape, weight, and texture).
Plan and carry out an investigation to predict and observe whether objects, based on their physical attributes, will sink or float.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information to compare and describe different types of motion.

expectations.expectationDescription: Plan and carry out an investigation to determine the relationship between an objectâ€™s physical attributes and its resulting motion (straight, circular, back and forth, fast and slow, and motionless) when a force is applied. (Examples could include toss, drop, push, and pull.)
Construct an argument as to the best way to move an object based on its physical attributes.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information about how organisms (alive and not alive) and non-living objects are grouped.

expectations.expectationDescription: Construct an explanation based on observations to recognize the differences between organisms and nonliving objects.
Develop a model to represent how a set of organisms and nonliving objects are sorted into groups based on their attributes.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information to compare the similarities and differences in groups of organisms.

expectations.expectationDescription: Construct an argument supported by evidence for how animals can be grouped according to their features.
Construct an argument supported by evidence for how plants can be grouped according to their features.
Ask questions and make observations to identify the similarities and differences of offspring to their parents and to other members of the same species.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Generate and conceptualize artistic ideas and work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Express and share ideas for media artworks through a variety of methods including, but not limited to, sketching and modeling.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Organize and develop artistic ideas and work.

expectations.expectationDescription: With guidance, use and evaluate student-generated ideas to form plans and models for media arts products.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Refine and complete artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Create and share media arts content for expression and meaning in media arts products, utilizing discipline-specific elements and principles.
Begin to recognize the effects of the editing process on finished work.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Select, analyze, and interpret artistic work for presentation.

expectations.expectationDescription: With guidance, combine varied academic, fine arts, and media content in media artworks.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Develop and refine artistic techniques and work for presentation.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify and explore basic artistic and technical skills (e.g. selecting and properly handling creation tools, making choices, cooperating when creating media artworks).
Identify and demonstrate creative skills within media arts productions (e.g. problem solving, performing).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Convey meaning through the presentation of artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: With guidance, discuss how time, place, and audience affect the presentation of media artworks and perform a related task in presenting media artworks.
With guidance, discuss the experience of presenting media artworks.
Sign and title selected media artwork and craft an appropriate artist statement.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Perceive and analyze artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: With guidance, identify and describe components and messages in media artworks.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Interpret intent and meaning in artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Interpret the intent and meaning of a variety of media artworks, expressing moods, feelings, themes, and/or ideas and using self-developed criteria incorporating specific elements and principles.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Apply criteria to evaluate artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: With guidance, identify meaning in a variety of media artworks.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Relate artistic ideas and works with societal, cultural, and historical context to deepen understanding.

expectations.expectationDescription: Explore and describe media artworks in everyday life (e.g. popular media, connections with family and friends).
Build digital citizenship skills by interacting safely and appropriately with media arts tools and environments.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Synthesize and relate knowledge and personal experiences to make art.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use personal experiences, interests, and models when creating media artworks.
Share meaningful experiences of media arts productions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Recognize that technology provides the opportunity to enhance relevance, increase confidence, offer authentic choice, and produce positive impacts in learning.

Use digital tools (e.g. computers, tablets, cameras, software, 3D printers, etc.â€¦) to build knowledge, produce creative artifacts, and make meaningful learning experiences for themselves and others.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify and use the home row of the keyboard effectively.
Build (use, modify and/or create) collections of digital images and words to communicate learning using a variety of media types.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Identify the rights, responsibilities, and opportunities of living, learning, and working in an interconnected society and model behaviors that are safe, legal, and ethical.

expectations.expectationDescription: Understand shared information on the Internet can be permanent.
Recognize and avoid harmful behaviors in online environments (e.g. viruses, in-app purchases, cyber-bullying, etc).
Follow safety rules and exhibit responsibility when using a device.
Create an artifact that shows the use of positive safe behavior when using technology.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use the Design Process (use, modify, create) with a variety of tools to identify and solve problems by creating new, modified, or imaginative solutions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Recognize that innovation in technology meets a range of needs (3D printing, coding, robotics, drones, etc.).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Develop and employ Computational Thinking strategies (break-down, find patterns, and create algorithms) to identify and solve problems.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify patterns.
Create and use Algorithms (a set of step-by-step instructions) to complete a task.
Use Algorithms (a set of step-by-step instructions) to construct programs (using a block-based programming language or unplugged activities) that accomplish a task as a means of creative expression.
Analyze and debug (identify and fix) with or without a computing device.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use digital tools to creatively share and express ideas.

expectations.expectationDescription: Create a variety of artifacts.
Present information using a digital device.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use digital tools to collaborate with others both locally and globally.

expectations.expectationDescription: Understand features of online environments.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Select appropriate sources to conduct authentic research to produce a relevant and credible product.

expectations.expectationDescription: Understand that resources on the Internet vary in quality and are found in a variety of places so care is needed in selection.
Understand there is an appropriate place to find information to research the answer to a question.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Understand how people can use technology.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify that technological innovation changes how people live and work.
Understand that when you are on a networked device you are connected to other people.
Practice using a variety of computing hardware and software to achieve personal learning goals.
Identify and describe solutions to simple hardware and software problems (ex. volume control).
Describe how technology can impact an individualâ€™s life positively and negatively.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Display perseverance and patience in problem-solving. Demonstrate skills and strategies needed to succeed in mathematics, including critical thinking, reasoning, and effective collaboration and expression. Seek help and apply feedback. Set and monitor goals.
Extend the count sequence to 120. Read, write, and represent numerical values to 120 and compare numerical values to 100.

expectations.expectationDescription: Count within 120, forward and backward, starting at any number. In this range, read and write numerals and represent a number of objects with a written numeral.
Explain that the two digits of a 2-digit number represent the amounts of tens and ones.
Compare and order whole numbers up to 100 using concrete models, drawings, and the symbols >, =, and <.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Explain the relationship between addition and subtraction and apply the properties of operations to solve real-life addition and subtraction problems within 20.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use a variety of strategies to solve addition and subtraction problems within 20.
Use pictures, drawings, and equations to develop strategies for addition and subtraction within 20 by exploring strings of related problems.
Recognize the inverse relationship between subtraction and addition within 20 and use this inverse relationship to solve authentic problems.
Fluently add and subtract within 10 using a variety of strategies.
Use the meaning of the equal sign to determine whether equations involving addition and subtraction are true or false.
Determine the unknown whole number in an addition or subtraction equation relating to three whole numbers.
Apply properties of operations as strategies to solve addition and subtraction problem situations within 20.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Identify, describe, extend, and create repeating patterns, growing patterns, and shrinking patterns found in real-life situations.

expectations.expectationDescription: Investigate, create, and make predictions about repeating patterns with a core of up to 3 elements resulting from repeating an operation, as a series of shapes, or a number string.
Identify, describe, and create growing, shrinking, and repeating patterns based on the repeated addition or subtraction of 1s, 2s, 5s, and 10s.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Compose shapes, analyze the attributes of shapes, and relate their parts to the whole.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify common two-dimensional shapes and three-dimensional figures, sort and classify them by their attributes and build and draw shapes that possess defining attributes.

Compose two-dimensional shapes (rectangles, squares, triangles, half-circles, and quarter-circles) and three-dimensional figures (cubes, rectangular prisms, cones, and cylinders) to create a shape formed of two or more common shapes and compose new shapes from the composite shape.
Partition circles and rectangles into two and four equal shares.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use concrete models, the base ten structure, and properties of operations to add and subtract within 100.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use a variety of strategies to solve applicable, mathematical addition and subtraction problems with one- and two-digit whole numbers.
Given a two-digit number, mentally find 10 more or 10 less than the number, without having to count; explain the reasoning used.
Add and subtract multiples of 10 within 100.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use appropriate tools to measure, order, and compare intervals of length and time, as well as denominations of money to solve real-life, mathematical problems and analyze graphical displays of data to answer relevant questions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Estimate, measure, and record lengths of objects using non-standard units, and compare and order up to three objects using the recorded measurements. Describe the objects compared.
Tell and write time in hours and half-hours using analog and digital clocks, and measure elapsed time to the hour on the hour using a predetermined number line.
Identify the value of quarters and compare the values of pennies, nickels, dimes, and quarters.
Ask questions and answer them based on gathered information, observations, and appropriate graphical displays to compare and order whole numbers.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate weather data to identify weather patterns.

expectations.expectationDescription: Represent data in tables and/or graphs to identify and describe different types of weather and the characteristics of each type.
Ask questions to identify forms of precipitation such as rain, snow, sleet, and hailstones as either solid (ice) or liquid (water).

Plan and carry out investigations on current weather conditions by observing, measuring with simple weather instruments (thermometer, wind vane, rain gauge), and recording weather data (temperature, precipitation, sky conditions, and weather events) in a periodic journal, on a calendar, and graphically.
Analyze data to identify seasonal patterns of change.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information to investigate light and sound.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use observations to construct an explanation of how light is required to make objects visible.
Ask questions to identify and compare sources of light.
Plan and carry out an investigation of shadows by placing objects at various points from a source of light.
Construct an explanation supported by evidence that vibrating materials can make sound and that sound can make materials vibrate.
Design a signal that can serve as an emergency alert using light and/or sound to communicate over a distance.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information to demonstrate the effects of magnets on other magnets and other objects.

expectations.expectationDescription: Construct an explanation of how magnets are used in everyday life.
Plan and carry out an investigation to demonstrate how magnets attract and repel each other and the effect of magnets on common objects.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information about the basic needs of plants and animals.

expectations.expectationDescription: Develop models to identify the parts of a plantâ€”root, stem, leaf, and flower.
Ask questions to compare and contrast the basic needs of plants (air, water, light, and nutrients) and animals (air, water, food, and shelter).
Design a solution to ensure that a plant or animal has all of its needs met.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Generate and conceptualize artistic ideas and work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Explore and share multiple ideas for media artworks through a variety of methods including, but not limited to, brainstorming and improvising.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Organize and develop artistic ideas and work.

expectations.expectationDescription: With some guidance, use and evaluate student-generated ideas to create plans and models for media arts products.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Refine and complete artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Create and organize content into unified media artwork(s) utilizing discipline-specific elements and principles.
Recognize the effect of the editing process on the final product.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Select, analyze, and interpret artistic work for presentation.

expectations.expectationDescription: Practice combining varied academic, fine arts, and media content into unified media artworks.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Develop and refine artistic techniques and work for presentation.

expectations.expectationDescription: Investigate basic artistic and technical skills (e.g. selection and proper handling of creation tools, making choices, cooperating when creating media artworks).
Identify and demonstrate use of creative thinking skills (e.g. playful practice, trial and error within and through media arts productions).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Convey meaning through the presentation of artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify and describe how time, place, and audience affect the presentation of media artworks and perform related task(s).
Identify, describe, and share the experience of presenting media artworks.
Title and sign selected media artwork and craft an artist statement.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Perceive and analyze artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify and describe the components and messages in media artworks.
Identify and describe how different media artworks create different experiences.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Interpret intent and meaning in artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Consider context and identify purpose and meaning of various media artworks.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Apply criteria to evaluate artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Consider context and discuss thoughts about positive and negative qualities of media.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Relate artistic ideas and works with societal, cultural, and historical context to deepen understanding.

expectations.expectationDescription: Discuss and explore how media artworks and ideas relate to everyday and cultural life.
Build digital citizenship skills by interacting safely and appropriately with media arts tools and environments.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Synthesize and relate knowledge and personal experiences to make art.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use personal experiences, interests, and prior knowledge when creating media arts productions.
Discuss and share personal experiences related to media artworks that include meaning and purpose.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Recognize that technology provides the opportunity to enhance relevance, increase confidence, offer authentic choice, and produce positive impacts in learning.

Use digital tools (e.g. computers, tablets, cameras, software, 3D printers, etc.â€¦) to build knowledge, produce creative artifacts, and make meaningful learning experiences for themselves and others.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify and use the home row of the keyboard effectively.
Build (use, modify and/or create) collections of digital images and words to communicate learning using a variety of media types.
Analyze collections of digital images and words for how well each collection communicates learning.
Identify a problem of interest to the learner and create a solution using digital tools.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Identify the rights, responsibilities, and opportunities of living, learning, and working in an interconnected society and model behaviors that are safe, legal, and ethical.

expectations.expectationDescription: Recognize work that is created by others.
Recognize that credit is given for the work of others found online.
Create an artifact that demonstrates a positive personal digital identity.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use the Design Process (use, modify, create) with a variety of tools to identify and solve problems by creating new, modified, or imaginative solutions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Modify an existing model for a specific purpose or for a specific group of users.
Create and test a model and analyze it from the perspective of an end user.
Understand that innovation follows a process such as system life cycle, engineering design (use, modify, create) or design thinking (empathize, define, ideate, prototype and test).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Develop and employ Computational Thinking strategies (break-down, find patterns, and create algorithms) to identify and solve problems.

expectations.expectationDescription: Recognize that problems can be broken down into smaller parts in order to create a solution. Vocabulary Term: Decompose (to break down)
Identify multiple ways solutions can be applied to solve problems. Vocabulary Term: Abstraction
Analyze and debug (identify and fix) with or without a computing device.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use digital tools to creatively share and express ideas.

expectations.expectationDescription: Create a variety of artifacts.
Exchange information or ideas clearly and creatively using digital tools while considering audience and intended purpose.
Present information using a digital device.
Create artifacts for specific purposes that give and receive feedback.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use digital tools to collaborate with others both locally and globally.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify technology (hardware and software) that allows collaboration with others.
Use digital tools to connect with individuals from different backgrounds and cultures.
Understand features of online environments.
Participate in various roles on a team to work on a common goal and create an inclusive environment.
Participate in an online collaborative learning environment.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Select appropriate sources to conduct authentic research to produce a relevant and credible product.

expectations.expectationDescription: Progress from using a teacher developed list of resources, to selecting resources independently.
Select digital and analog resources, explain why a source was selected, and describe why it was the best source.
Collect and organize data.
Create a product of research collaboratively or independently. (e.g., table of data, writing assignment, collection of resources).
Create and share a research project reflecting and crediting a variety of quality resources.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Understand how people can use technology.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use devices appropriately.
Choose and use appropriate hardware and software tools for a given purpose using accurate terminology.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Display perseverance and patience in problem-solving. Demonstrate skills and strategies needed to succeed in mathematics, including critical thinking, reasoning, and effective collaboration and expression. Seek help and apply feedback. Set and monitor goals.
Using the place value structure, explore the count sequences to represent, read, write, and compare numerical values to 1000 and describe basic place-value relationships and structures.

expectations.expectationDescription: Explain the value of a three-digit number using hundreds, tens, and ones in a variety of ways.

Count forward and backward by ones from any number within 1000. Count forward by fives from multiples of 5 within 1000. Count forward and backward by 10s and 100s from any number within 1000. Count forward by 25s from 0.
Represent, compare, and order whole numbers to 1000 with an emphasis on place value and equality. Use >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Apply multiple part-whole strategies, properties of operations and place value understanding to solve real-life, mathematical problems involving addition and subtraction within 1,000.

expectations.expectationDescription: Fluently add and subtract within 20 using a variety of mental, part-whole strategies.
Find 10 more or 10 less than a given three-digit number and find 100 more or 100 less than a given three-digit number.
Solve problems involving the addition and subtraction of two-digit numbers using part-whole strategies.
Fluently add and subtract within 100 using strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Work with equal groups to gain foundations for multiplication through real-life, mathematical problems.

expectations.expectationDescription: Determine whether a group (up to 20) has an odd or even number of objects. Write an equation to express an even number as a sum of two equal addends.
Use addition to find the total number of objects arranged in rectangular arrays with up to 5 rows and up to 5 columns; write an equation to express the total as a sum of equal addends.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Identify, describe, extend, and create repeating patterns, growing patterns, and shrinking patterns.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify, describe, and create a numerical pattern resulting from repeating an operation such as addition and subtraction.
Identify, describe, and create growing patterns and shrinking patterns involving addition and subtraction up to 20.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Estimate and measure the lengths of objects and distance to solve problems found in real-life using standard units of measurement, including inches, feet, and yards and analyze graphical displays of data to answer relevant questions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Construct simple measuring instruments using unit models. Compare unit models to rulers.
Estimate and measure the length of an object or distance to the nearest whole unit using appropriate units and standard measuring tools.
Measure to determine how much longer one object is than another and express the length difference in terms of a standard-length unit.
Ask questions and answer them based on gathered information, observations, and appropriate graphical displays to solve problems relevant to everyday life.
Represent whole-number sums and differences within a standard unit of measurement on a number line diagram.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Solve real-life problems involving time and money.

expectations.expectationDescription: Tell and write time from analog and digital clocks to the nearest five minutes, and estimate and measure elapsed time using a timeline, to the hour or half hour on the hour or half hour.

Find the value of a group of coins and determine combinations of coins that equal a given amount that is less than one hundred cents, and solve problems involving dollar bills, quarters, dimes, nickels, and pennies, using $ and Â¢ symbols appropriately.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Draw and partition shapes and other objects with specific attributes, and conduct observations of everyday items and structures to identify how shapes exist in the world.

expectations.expectationDescription: Describe, compare and sort 2-D shapes including polygons, triangles, quadrilaterals, pentagons, hexagons, and 3-D shapes including rectangular prisms and cones, given a set of attributes.
Identify at least one line of symmetry in everyday objects to describe each object as a whole.

Partition circles and rectangles into two, three, or four equal shares. Identify and describe equal-sized parts of the whole using fractional names (â€œhalves,â€ â€œthirds,â€ â€œfourthsâ€, â€œhalf of,â€ â€œthird of,â€ â€œquarter of,â€ etc.).
Recognize that equal shares of identical wholes may be different shapes within the same whole.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information about stars having different sizes and brightness.

expectations.expectationDescription: Ask questions to describe the physical attributes (size and brightness) of stars.
Construct an argument to support the claim that although the sun appears to be the brightest and largest star, it is actually medium in size and brightness.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information to develop an understanding of the patterns of the sun and the moon and the sunâ€™s effect on Earth.

expectations.expectationDescription: Plan and carry out an investigation to determine the effect of the position of the sun in relation to a fixed object on Earth at various times of the day.
Design and build a structure that demonstrates how shadows change throughout the day.
Represent data in tables and/or graphs of the length of the day and night to recognize the change in seasons.
Use data from personal observations to describe, illustrate, and predict how the appearance of the moon changes over time in a pattern.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information about how weather, plants, animals, and humans cause changes to the environment.

expectations.expectationDescription: Ask questions to obtain information about major changes to the environment in your community.
Construct an explanation of the causes and effects of a change to the environment in your community.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information about the properties of matter and changes that occur in objects.

expectations.expectationDescription: Ask questions to describe and classify different objects according to their physical properties.
Construct an explanation for how structures made from small pieces (linking cubes, building blocks) can be disassembled and then rearranged to make new and different structures.
Provide evidence from observations to construct an explanation that some changes in matter caused by heating or cooling can be reversed and some changes are irreversible.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information to explain the effect of a force (a push or a pull) in the movement of an object (changes in speed and direction).

expectations.expectationDescription: Plan and carry out an investigation to demonstrate how pushing and pulling on an object affects the motion of the object.
Design a device to change the speed or direction of an object.
Record and analyze data to decide if a design solution works as intended to change the speed or direction of an object with a force (a push or a pull).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information about the life cycles of different living organisms.

expectations.expectationDescription: Ask questions to determine the sequence of the life cycle of common animals in your area: a mammal such as a cat, dog or classroom pet, a bird such as a chicken, an amphibian such as a frog, and an insect such as a butterfly.
Plan and carry out an investigation of the life cycle of a plant by growing a plant from a seed and by recording changes over a period of time.
Construct an explanation of an animalâ€™s role in dispersing seeds or in the pollination of plants.
Develop models to illustrate the unique and diverse life cycles of organisms other than humans.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Generate and conceptualize artistic ideas and work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Develop and share multiple ideas for media artworks using a variety of tools, methods, and/or materials.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Organize and develop artistic ideas and work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Independently use and evaluate student-generated ideas to formulate plans for media arts productions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Refine and complete artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Create, organize, and edit content into unified, meaningful media arts products utilizing discipline-specific elements and principles.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Select, analyze, and interpret artistic work for presentation.

expectations.expectationDescription: Combine varied academic media content into unified media artworks.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Develop and refine artistic techniques and work for presentation.

expectations.expectationDescription: Develop basic artistic and technical skills (e.g. selecting and safely manipulating creation tools, making choices, collaborating when creating media artworks).
Examine fundamental creative and innovative strategies to develop solutions within and through media arts productions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Convey meaning through the presentation of artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Design, evaluate, and refine presentation and distribution of multiple formats/contexts of media artworks considering the impact on personal growth and meaning.
Develop and maintain an individual portfolio of media artworks that shows proficiency in craftsmanship, technical skills, and development of an emerging personal voice.
Analyze why and how an exhibition or production may influence ideas, beliefs, and experiences.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Perceive and analyze artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify and describe how messages are created through the components of a media artwork.
Recognize and share how meaning and style in media artworks affect audience experience.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Interpret intent and meaning in artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify and discuss the purpose and meaning of various media artworks considering the context in which they were made.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Apply criteria to evaluate artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Analyze and interpret media artworks through thoughtful discussion or written response, considering themes, ideas, mood/feeling, context, and artistic goals based on input from the critique process.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Relate artistic ideas and works with societal, cultural, and historical context to deepen understanding.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify and build media arts skills to address social, cultural, or societal issues while examining related careers, higher order thinking, problem-solving, creativity, personal beliefs, imagination, and lifelong learning opportunities in a local and global context.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Synthesize and relate knowledge and personal experiences to make art.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify and demonstrate trends in the media arts to communicate cultural differences to connect people and places through values, purpose, interdisciplinary study, differing perspectives to increase innovation and the quality of work.
Interpret the use and impact of digital citizenship to include environments, technological contexts, copyright, plagiarism, citations, validating resources, and social media.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Identify the features of current technologies and use that knowledge to understand emerging technologies.

expectations.expectationDescription: Describe how internal and external parts of computing devices function to form a system.
Model how computer hardware and software work together as a system to accomplish tasks.
Determine potential solutions to solve simple hardware and software problems using common troubleshooting strategies.
Develop and apply keyboarding skills, utilizing current technology.
Compare and contrast prior knowledge on current technologies with that of new or emerging technologies.
Develop, reflect on, and revise personal learning goals in collaboration with their peers.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Curate (analyze and evaluate) a variety of resources and digital tools to construct knowledge and produce creative artifacts.

expectations.expectationDescription: Curate (analyze and evaluate) information from digital resources using a variety of tools and methods to create collections of artifacts that demonstrate meaningful connections or conclusions.
Build knowledge by actively exploring real-world issues.
Explain why a real-world issue exists or was created and develop a possible solution.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Identify the rights, responsibilities, and opportunities of living, learning, and working in an interconnected society and model behaviors that are safe, legal, and ethical.

expectations.expectationDescription: Discuss real-world cybersecurity problems (e.g. viruses, phishing attacks, click bait, etc) and how personal information can be protected.
Understand, demonstrate, and encourage respect for intellectual property of print and digital media.
Create and manage digital identity through positive, safe, and ethical online interactions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use a variety of technologies within a design process to identify and solve problems by creating new, useful, or imaginative solutions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Explore and practice a deliberate design process for generating ideas, testing theories, creating innovative artifacts, or solving authentic problems.
Select, evaluate, and use appropriate digital tools to plan and manage a design process.
Modify, remix, or incorporate portions of an existing program into one's own work, to develop something new or add more advanced features.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Develop and employ strategies for understanding and solving problems in ways that use the power of technological methods to develop and test solutions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Compare and refine multiple algorithms for the same task and determine which is the most appropriate.
Decompose (break down) problems into smaller, manageable subproblems to facilitate the program development process.
Test and debug (identify and fix errors) a program or algorithm to ensure it runs as intended.
Create programs that include sequences, events, loops, conditionals, and variables.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Select and use the most appropriate platform, tool, style, format and digital media to clearly and creatively express thoughts, messages, goals, or positions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Create original works or responsibly repurpose or remix digital resources into new creations.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use digital tools to expand personal viewpoints and enrich learning by collaborating effectively both locally and globally.

expectations.expectationDescription: Explore local and global issues using digital tools to connect with learners from a variety of backgrounds and cultures.
Seek diverse perspectives for the purpose of improving computational artifacts.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Gather, evaluate, and organize quality information from multiple sources.

expectations.expectationDescription: Understand and use effective research strategies to locate information and other resources.
Evaluate the accuracy, perspective, credibility and relevance of information, media, data, or other resources.
Use information from multiple sources to identify real-world issues and create solutions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Understand the relationship between technology, lifelong learning, and the appropriate use of information.

expectations.expectationDescription: Discuss computing technologies that have changed the world, and express how those technologies influence, and are influenced by, cultural practices.
Identify and propose ways to improve usability of technology for diverse users.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Display perseverance and patience in problem-solving. Demonstrate skills and strategies needed to succeed in mathematics, including critical thinking, reasoning, and effective collaboration and expression. Seek help and apply feedback. Set and monitor goals.
Use place value reasoning to represent, read, write, and compare numerical values up to 10,000 and round whole numbers up to 1,000.

expectations.expectationDescription: Read and write multi-digit whole numbers up to 10,000 using base-ten numerals and expanded form.
Use place value reasoning to compare multi-digit numbers up to 10,000, using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.
Use place value understanding to round whole numbers up to 1000 to the nearest 10 or 100.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use part-whole strategies to represent and solve real-life problems involving addition and subtraction with whole numbers up to 10,000.

expectations.expectationDescription: Fluently add and subtract within 1000 to solve problems.

Apply part-whole strategies, properties of operations and place value understanding, to solve problems involving addition and subtraction within 10,000. Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Justify solutions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use part-whole strategies to solve real-life, mathematical problems involving multiplication and division with whole numbers within 100.

expectations.expectationDescription: Describe, extend, and create numeric patterns related to multiplication. Make predictions related to the patterns.
Represent single digit multiplication and division facts using a variety of strategies. Explain the relationship between multiplication and division.
Apply properties of operations (i.e., commutative property, associative property, distributive property) to multiply and divide within 100.
Use the meaning of the equal sign to determine whether expressions involving addition, subtraction, and multiplication are equivalent.
Use place value reasoning and properties of operations to multiply one-digit whole numbers by multiples of 10, in the range 10-90.
Solve practical, relevant problems involving multiplication and division within 100 using part-whole strategies, visual representations, and/or concrete models.
Use multiplication and division to solve problems involving whole numbers to 100. Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Justify solutions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Represent fractions with denominators of 2, 3, 4, 6 and 8 in multiple ways within a framework using visual models.

expectations.expectationDescription: Describe a unit fraction and explain how multiple copies of a unit fraction form a non-unit fraction. Use parts of a whole, parts of a set, points on a number line, distances on a number line and area models.
Compare two unit fractions by flexibly using a variety of tools and strategies.
Represent fractions, including fractions greater than one, in multiple ways.
Recognize and generate simple equivalent fractions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Solve real-life, mathematical problems involving length, liquid volume, mass, and time and analyze graphical displays of data to answer relevant questions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Ask questions and answer them based on gathered information, observations, and appropriate graphical displays to solve problems relevant to everyday life.
Tell and write time to the nearest minute and estimate time to the nearest fifteen minutes (quarter hour) from the analysis of an analog clock.

Solve meaningful problems involving elapsed time, including intervals of time to the hour, half hour, and quarter hour where the times presented are only on the hour, half hour, or quarter hour within a.m. or p.m. only.
Use rulers to measure lengths in halves and fourths (quarters) of an inch and a whole inch.

Estimate and measure liquid volumes, lengths and masses of objects using customary units. Solve problems involving mass, length, and volume given in the same unit, and reason about the relative sizes of measurement units within the customary system.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Identify the attributes of polygons, including parallel segments, perpendicular segments, right angles, and symmetry.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify perpendicular line segments, parallel line segments, and right angles, identify these in polygons, and solve problems involving parallel line segments, perpendicular line segments, and right angles.

Classify, compare, and contrast polygons, with a focus on quadrilaterals, based on properties. Analyze specific 3-dimensional figures to identify and describe quadrilaterals as faces of these figures.
Identify lines of symmetry in polygons.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Identify area as a measurable attribute of rectangles and determine the area of a rectangle presented in real-life, mathematical problems.

expectations.expectationDescription: Investigate area by covering the space of rectangles presented in realistic situations using multiple copies of the same unit, with no gaps or overlaps, and determine the total area (total number of units that covered the space).
Determine the area of rectangles (or shapes composed of rectangles) presented in relevant problems by tiling and counting.
Discover and explain how area can be found by multiplying the dimensions of a rectangle.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Determine the perimeter of a polygon presented in real-life, mathematical problems.

expectations.expectationDescription: Determine the perimeter of a polygon and explain that the perimeter represents the distance around a polygon. Solve problems involving perimeters of polygons.
Investigate and describe how rectangles with the same perimeter can have different areas or how rectangles with the same area can have different perimeters.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information about the physical attributes of rocks and soils.

expectations.expectationDescription: Ask questions and analyze data to classify rocks by their physical attributes (color, texture, luster, and hardness) using simple tests.
Plan and carry out investigations to describe properties (color, texture, capacity to retain water, and ability to support growth of plants) of soils and soil types (sand, clay, loam).
Make observations of the local environment to construct an explanation of how water and/or wind have made changes to soil and/or rocks over time.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information on how fossils provide evidence of past organisms.

expectations.expectationDescription: Construct an argument from observations of fossils (authentic or reproductions) to communicate how they serve as evidence of past organisms and the environments in which they lived.
Develop a model to describe the sequence and conditions required for an organism to become fossilized.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information about the ways heat energy is transferred and measured.

expectations.expectationDescription: Ask questions to identify sources of heat energy.
Plan and carry out an investigation to gather data using thermometers to produce tables and charts that illustrate the effect of sunlight on various objects.
Use tools and every day materials to design and construct a device/structure that will increase/decrease the warming effects of sunlight on various materials.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information about the similarities and differences between plants, animals, and habitats found within geographic regions (Blue Ridge Mountains, Piedmont, Coastal Plains, Valley and Ridge, and Appalachian Plateau) of Georgia.

expectations.expectationDescription: Ask questions to differentiate between plants, animals, and habitats found within Georgiaâ€™s geographic regions.
Construct an explanation of how external features and adaptations (camouflage, hibernation, migration, mimicry) of animals allow them to survive in their habitat.
Use evidence to construct an explanation of why some organisms can thrive in one habitat and not in another.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information about the effects of pollution (air, land, and water) and humans on the environment.

expectations.expectationDescription: Ask questions to collect information and create records of sources and effects of pollution on the plants and animals.
Explore, research, and communicate solutions, such as conservation of resources and recycling of materials, to protect plants and animals.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Generate and conceptualize artistic ideas and work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify and develop ideas, goals, and solutions for original media artworks through authentic engagement focused on creative processes through divergent thinking and open-ended inquiry.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Organize and develop artistic ideas and work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Structure and critique ideas, plans, prototypes, and processes for media arts productions, considering artistic intent, resources, presentation context, and associated elements and principles.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Refine and complete artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Understand and apply a variety of media arts processes to produce increasingly complex works of art that communicate personal choice.
Increase technical skill using a range of elements and principles.

Refine and modify media artworks, improving technical quality and intentionally accentuating selected expressive and stylistic elements to reflect an understanding of purpose, tone, mood, audience, and place.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Select, analyze, and interpret artistic work for presentation.

expectations.expectationDescription: Synthesize multiple contents and forms into unified media arts productions that convey a strong theme and personal voice.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Develop and refine artistic techniques and work for presentation.

expectations.expectationDescription: Exhibit an increasing set of artistic, design, and technical skills through performing various roles in producing media artworks through creative problem-solving, collaborative communication, and organization.
Demonstrate creativity, exploratory process, and adaptability using innovative tools and techniques in revising and developing solutions to achieve an assigned purpose in constructing media artworks.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Convey meaning through the presentation of artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Design, evaluate, and refine presentation and distribution of multiple formats/contexts of media artworks considering the impact on personal growth and meaning.
Develop and maintain an individual portfolio of media artworks that shows proficiency in craftsmanship, technical skills, and the development of an emerging personal voice.
Analyze why and how an exhibition or production may influence ideas, beliefs, and experiences.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Perceive and analyze artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify, describe, and analyze methods, various styles, message, and meaning with intent to develop and organize own ideas, resolve specific visual arts problems, and create works of media art to manage audience experience.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Interpret intent and meaning in artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Interpret the intent and meanings of a variety of media artworks, focusing on intentions, forms, and various contexts, by incorporating specific elements and principles.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Apply criteria to evaluate artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Analyze and interpret media artworks through thoughtful discussion or written response, considering themes, ideas, mood/feeling, context, and artistic goals, based on input from the critique process.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Relate artistic ideas and works with societal, cultural, and historical context to deepen understanding.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify and build media arts skills to address social, cultural, or societal issues while examining related careers, higher order thinking, problem-solving, creativity, personal beliefs, imagination, and lifelong learning opportunities in a local and global context.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Synthesize and relate knowledge and personal experiences to make art.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify and demonstrate trends in the media arts to communicate cultural differences to connect people and places through values, purpose, interdisciplinary study, differing perspectives to increase innovation and the quality of work.
Interpret the use and impact of digital citizenship to include environments, technological contexts, copyright, plagiarism, citations, resource validation, and social media.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Identify the features of current technologies and use that knowledge to understand emerging technologies.

expectations.expectationDescription: Describe how internal and external parts of computing devices function to form a system.
Model how computer hardware and software work together as a system to accomplish tasks.
Determine potential solutions to solve simple hardware and software problems using common troubleshooting strategies.
Develop and apply keyboarding skills, utilizing current technology.
Compare and contrast prior knowledge on current technologies with that of new or emerging technologies.
Develop, reflect on, and revise personal learning goals in collaboration with their peers.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Curate (analyze and evaluate) a variety of resources and digital tools to construct knowledge and produce creative artifacts.

expectations.expectationDescription: Curate (analyze and evaluate) information from digital resources using a variety of tools and methods to create collections of artifacts that demonstrate meaningful connections or conclusions.
Build knowledge by actively exploring real-world issues.
Explain why a real-world issue exists or was created and develop a possible solution.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Identify the rights, responsibilities, and opportunities of living, learning, and working in an interconnected society and model behaviors that are safe, legal, and ethical.

expectations.expectationDescription: Discuss real-world cybersecurity problems (e.g. viruses, phishing attacks, click bait, etc) and how personal information can be protected.
Understand, demonstrate, and encourage respect for intellectual property of print and digital media.
Create and manage digital identity through positive, safe, and ethical online interactions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use a variety of technologies within a design process to identify and solve problems by creating new, useful, or imaginative solutions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Explore and practice a deliberate design process for generating ideas, testing theories, creating innovative artifacts, or solving authentic problems.
Select, evaluate, and use appropriate digital tools to plan and manage a design process.
Modify, remix, or incorporate portions of an existing program into one's own work, to develop something new or add more advanced features.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Develop and employ strategies for understanding and solving problems in ways that use the power of technological methods to develop and test solutions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Compare and refine multiple algorithms for the same task and determine which is the most appropriate.
Decompose (break down) problems into smaller, manageable subproblems to facilitate the program development process.
Test and debug (identify and fix errors) a program or algorithm to ensure it runs as intended.
Create programs that include sequences, events, loops, conditionals, and variables.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Select and use the most appropriate platform, tool, style, format and digital media to clearly and creatively express thoughts, messages, goals, or positions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Create original works or responsibly repurpose or remix digital resources into new creations.
Communicate complex ideas clearly and effectively by creating or using a variety of digital objects.
Publish or present content that customizes the message and medium for their intended audiences.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use digital tools to expand personal viewpoints and enrich learning by collaborating effectively both locally and globally.

expectations.expectationDescription: Explore local and global issues using digital tools to connect with learners from a variety of backgrounds and cultures.
Take on varying roles, with teacher guidance, when collaborating with peers during the design, implementation, and review stages of program development.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Gather, evaluate, and organize quality information from multiple sources.

expectations.expectationDescription: Evaluate the accuracy, perspective, credibility and relevance of information, media, data, or other resources.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Understand the relationship between technology, lifelong learning, and the appropriate use of information.

expectations.expectationDescription: Discuss computing technologies that have changed the world, and express how those technologies influence, and are influenced by, cultural practices.
Identify and propose ways to improve usability of technology for diverse users.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Display perseverance and patience in problem-solving. Demonstrate skills and strategies needed to succeed in mathematics, including critical thinking, reasoning, and effective collaboration and expression. Seek help and apply feedback. Set and monitor goals.
Recognize patterns within the base ten place value system with quantities presented in real-life situations to compare and round multi-digit whole numbers through the hundred-thousands place.

expectations.expectationDescription: Read and write multi-digit whole numbers to the hundred-thousands place using base-ten numerals and expanded form.

Recognize and show that a digit in one place has a value ten times greater than what it represents in the place to its right and extend this understanding to determine the value of a digit when it is shifted to the left or right, based on the relationship between multiplication and division.
Use place value reasoning to represent, compare, and order multi-digit numbers, using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.
Use place value understanding to round multi-digit whole numbers.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Using part-whole strategies, solve problems involving addition and subtraction through the hundred-thousands place, as well as multiplication and division of multi-digit whole numbers presented in real-life, mathematical situations.

expectations.expectationDescription: Fluently add and subtract multi-digit numbers to solve practical, mathematical problems using place value understanding, properties of operations, and relationships between operations.
Interpret, model, and solve problems involving multiplicative comparison.

Solve relevant problems involving multiplication of a number with up to four digits by a 1-digit whole number or involving multiplication of two two-digit numbers using strategies based on place value and the properties of operations. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.

Solve authentic division problems involving up to 4-digit dividends and 1-digit divisors (including whole number quotients with remainders) using strategies based on place-value understanding, properties of operations, and the relationships between operations.

Solve multi-step problems using addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division involving whole numbers. Use mental computation and estimation strategies to justify the reasonableness of solutions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Generate and analyze patterns, including those involving shapes, input/output diagrams, factors, multiples, prime numbers, and composite numbers.

expectations.expectationDescription: Generate both number and shape patterns that follow a provided rule.
Use input-output rules, tables, and charts to represent and describe patterns, find relationships, and solve problems.
Find factor pairs in the range 1â€“100 and find multiples of single-digit numbers up to 100.
Identify composite numbers and prime numbers and explain the relationship with the factor pairs.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Solve real-life problems involving addition, subtraction, equivalence, and comparison of fractions with denominators of 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100 using part-whole strategies and visual models.

expectations.expectationDescription: Using concrete materials, drawings, and number lines, demonstrate and explain the relationship between equivalent fractions, including fractions greater than one, and explain the identity property of multiplication as it relates to equivalent fractions. Generate equivalent fractions using these relationships.
