expectations.expectationDescription: Interpret tables, charts, and graphs created by someone else.
Discuss design decisions in choosing between text, tables, charts, and graphs.
Discuss design decisions to make visualizations of data clear and concise.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Recognize that there may be multiple approaches to solving a problem.
Approach problem solving iteratively, using a cyclical process.
Design, develop, debug and implement computer programs.

expectations.expectationDescription: Develop a working vocabulary of programming including flowcharting and/or storyboarding, coding, debugging, user interfaces, usability, variables, lists, loops, conditionals, programming language, events.
Utilize the design process to brainstorm, implement, test, and revise an idea.
Cite evidence on how computers represent data and media (sounds, images, video, etc.).
Design a user interface and test with other users using a paper prototype.
Implement a simple algorithm in a computer program.
Develop an event driven program.
Create a program that accepts user and/or sensor input and stores the result in a variable.
Create a computer program that implements a loop.
Develop a program that makes a decision based on data or user input.
Debug a program with an error.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Develop a plan to create, design, and build a website with digital content to a specific target market.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify the objectives (e.g., increase sales, promote new products, increase company awareness, target new customers) for the websiteâ€™s target market.
Specify website requirements, including timeline and resources, and organize them into a requirements document.

Find and evaluate similar websites (in terms of overall function and layout) using an evaluation instrument for side-by-side comparison. Consider major design elements (ease of use, responsiveness, adaptability to mobile, tablet and desktop, etc.).
Evaluate a variety of web design tools and development platforms using an evaluation instrument and choose the appropriate platform.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Design digital products that reveal a professional layout and look by applying design principles to produce professional quality digital products.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify graphical elements and the appropriate use of elements on a web site.
Explore and apply color principles to digital products.
Establish a brand through consistent use of graphics, color, layout and text.
Analyze the look and layout of a website based on the first impression of content and page elements. Get feedback from independent people and incorporate where appropriate.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Create a single functional web page using a web development platform based on a design mockup and user requirements.

expectations.expectationDescription: Create and edit images and graphics for website publication.
Plan, produce, and edit digital audio for website publication.
Plan, produce, edit, and post a multimedia-rich video project to a website.
Plan, produce, and edit animations for website publication.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Develop and use a test plan to debug each new website version to ensure it runs as intended and meets the end-user requirements for a responsive site.

expectations.expectationDescription: Create a test and debug plan. Resolve issues and fix any errors that surface during the test and debug process.
Create an end user testing plan, get user feedback, and incorporate feedback into the final website.
Prepare website for publishing and promotion.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Develop a plan to create, design, and build a game with digital content for a specific target market.

expectations.expectationDescription: Explore various game types including role-playing games (RPG), real-time strategy (RTS), simulations, puzzles, educational, massively multiplayer online (MMO), and others.
Create a Game Design Document (GDD), which includes, characters, story, theme, and gameplay mechanics.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Develop a visual model of a game from the Game Design Document (GDD).

expectations.expectationDescription: Create storyboards from the GDD that demonstrate game progression and consistent use of a theme.
Use the GDD to design the wireframes and comprehensive layout for the user experience (UX).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Create a functional game, using a game development platform, based on the storyboards, wireframes, and comprehensive layout.

expectations.expectationDescription: Create game elements, backgrounds, and characters.
Use scripting languages to create desired game mechanics, and to control the environment, user interface (UI), and character behaviors.
Plan, produce, and edit graphics and animations for game publication.
Plan, produce, and edit digital audio for game publication.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Develop and use a test plan to debug use each time a version of the game is released to ensure it runs as intended and meets the end-user requirements.

expectations.expectationDescription: Create a test and debug plan. Resolve any issues and fix any errors that surface during the test and debug process.
Create an end user testing plan, get user feedback, and incorporate feedback into the final game.
Prepare final game for publishing prior to publishing to the target audience.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Create digital artifacts to address a current issue requiring resolution.

expectations.expectationDescription: Summarize ethical, privacy, and legal issues of a digital world using current case studies.
Collaborate as a team to develop an artifact that represents multiple perspectives regarding a global crisis.
Analyze and explain the functionality and suitability (or appropriateness) of a computational artifact.
Develop a program for creative expression or to satisfy personal curiosity which may have visual, audible, and/or tactile results.
Develop a program specifically with the goal of solving a problem, creating new knowledge, or helping people, organizations, or society.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Identify sub-problems to consider while addressing a larger problem.
Recognize when it is appropriate to solve a problem computationally; Make sense of computational problems and persevere in solving them.
Develop through application, logical observations relative to computational thinking procedures to analyze and solve problems current to everyday life.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify characteristics of computational thinking (decomposition, pattern recognition, algorithmic thinking and abstraction).
Explain issues and analyze routine hardware and software problems current to everyday life.
Apply troubleshooting concepts to issues regarding compatibility, data, and identity.
Describe ways to resolve operational problems caused by hardware errors.
Explain how technology can create ethical and legal issues in the business world and a technology-based society and how it can be used to solve & manage those issues.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Utilize computational thinking to solve problems.

expectations.expectationDescription: Make observations and organize the concepts of modularity, including functions and methods, as it relates to programming code reusability and cloud computing in the software industry.

Develop a working vocabulary of computational thinking including sequences, algorithms, binary, pattern matching, decomposition, abstraction, parallelization, data, automation, data collection, data analysis, boolean, integer, branches (if...then...else), and iteration {loops (For, While)}.
Analyze the problem-solving process, the input-process-output-storage model of a computer, and how computers help humans solve problems.
Develop an algorithm to decompose a problem of a daily task.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Recognize when to use the same solution for multiple problems.
Evaluate the storage and representation of data; Analyze how data is collected with both computational and non-computational tools and processes.

expectations.expectationDescription: Discuss binary numbers, logic, sets, and functions and their application to computer science.
Explain that searches may be enhanced by using Boolean logic (e.g., using â€œnotâ€, â€œorâ€, â€œandâ€).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Understand and use the basic steps in algorithmic problem solving in computing and other authentic applications.

expectations.expectationDescription: Select basic steps to solve algorithmic problems.
Evaluate basic steps of algorithmic problem solving to design solutions.
Solve algorithmic problems of increasing complexity.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use and compare simple coding control structures (e.g., if-then, loops)

expectations.expectationDescription: Use a visual block-based and/or text-based programming language individually and collaboratively to solve problems of increasing complexity.
Create a program individually and collaboratively using a text-based programming language; Identify variables and compare the types of data stored as variables.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Consider the purpose of computational artifacts for practical use, personal expression, and/or societal impact.

expectations.expectationDescription: Compare and contrast examples of high level and low-level programming languages.
Investigate the notion of hierarchy in computing including high level languages, translations, instruction sets, and logic circuits.
Develop problem solutions using a programming language, including all of the following: looping behavior, conditional statements, expressions, variables, and functions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Test computational artifacts systematically by considering multiple scenarios and using test cases.
Describe how humans and machines interact to accomplish tasks that cannot be accomplished by either alone.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify what distinguishes humans from machines focusing on human intelligence versus machine intelligence (e.g., robot motion, speech and language understanding, and computer vision); Explain why some tasks can be accomplished more easily by computers.

Describe ways in which computers use models of intelligent behavior (e.g., robot motion, speech and language understanding, and computer vision) and how they differ (e.g., emotional decision making versus logical decisions, common sense, literal versus abstract).
Design and demonstrate the use of a device (e.g., robot, e-textile) to accomplish a task, individually and collaboratively.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use online resources to participate in collaborative activities for the purpose of developing solutions or products.
Improve teamwork and collaboration skills: providing useful feedback, integrating feedback, understanding, and accepting multiple perspectives.

expectations.expectationDescription: Understand the difference between CC and BCC as well as Reply and Reply All and when to use each appropriately.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Collaborate productively and recognize the value of working with individuals of varying perspectives, skills, and backgrounds.

expectations.expectationDescription: Set and implement equitable expectations and workloads when working in teams.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Demonstrate correct keyboarding techniques while increasing speed and maintaining accuracy.
Use productivity technology tools (e.g. word processing, spreadsheet, presentation software) for individual and collaborative writing, communication, and publishing activities.
Recognize that equitable access to computing benefits society as a whole.
Consider othersâ€™ perspectives as well as oneâ€™s own perspective when developing computational solutions.
Consider the needs of a variety of end users regarding accessibility and usability.
Use software applications to collaborate and create authentic products.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify and utilize the appropriate software application for productivity.
Use various applications in a professional manner to share and communicate with peers and teachers.
Share documents created using word processing, presentation, and spreadsheet software.
Create original works using software applications in a collaborative manner.
Collaborate in small groups to create and edit online documents in real time.
Identify and use appropriate file sharing strategies (e.g., copy and paste, links, posts, and attachments).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Display perseverance and patience in problem-solving. Demonstrate skills and strategies needed to succeed in mathematics, including critical thinking, reasoning, and effective collaboration and expression. Seek help and apply feedback. Set and monitor goals.

Solve relevant, mathematical problems, including multi-step problems, involving the four operations with rational numbers and quantities in any form (integers, percentages, fractions, and decimal numbers).

expectations.expectationDescription: Show that a number and its opposite have a sum of 0 (are additive inverses). Describe situations in which opposite quantities combine to make 0.

Show and explain p + q as the number located a distance |q| from p, in the positive or negative direction, depending on whether q is positive or negative. Interpret sums of rational numbers by describing applicable situations.
Represent addition and subtraction with rational numbers on a horizontal or a vertical number line diagram to solve authentic problems.

Show and explain subtraction of rational numbers as adding the additive inverse, p â€“ q = p + (â€“q). Show that the distance between two rational numbers on the number line is the absolute value of their difference and apply this principle in contextual situations.
Apply properties of operations, including part-whole reasoning, as strategies to add and subtract rational numbers.
Make sense of multiplication of rational numbers using realistic applications.
Show and explain that integers can be divided, assuming the divisor is not zero, and every quotient of integers is a rational number.
Represent the multiplication and division of integers using a variety of strategies and interpret products and quotients of rational numbers by describing them based on the relevant situation.
Apply properties of operations as strategies to solve multiplication and division problems involving rational numbers represented in an applicable scenario.

Convert rational numbers between forms to include fractions, decimal numbers and percentages, using understanding of the part divided by the whole. Know that the decimal form of a rational number terminates in 0s or eventually repeats.

Solve multi-step, contextual problems involving rational numbers, converting between forms as appropriate, and assessing the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use properties of operations, generate equivalent expressions and interpret the expressions to explain relevant situations.

expectations.expectationDescription: Apply properties of operations as strategies to add, subtract, factor, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients.
Rewrite an expression in different forms from a contextual problem to clarify the problem and show how the quantities in it are related.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Represent authentic situations using equations and inequalities with variables; solve equations and inequalities symbolically, using the properties of equality.

expectations.expectationDescription: Construct algebraic equations to solve practical problems leading to equations of the form px + q = r and p(x + q) = r, where p, q, and r are specific rational numbers. Interpret the solution based on the situation.

Construct algebraic inequalities to solve problems, leading to inequalities of the form px + q > r, px + q < r, px + q â‰¤ r, or px + q â‰¥ r, where p, q, and r are specific rational numbers. Graph and interpret the solution based on the realistic situation that the inequalities represent.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Recognize proportional relationships in relevant, mathematical problems; represent, solve, and explain these relationships with tables, graphs, and equations.

expectations.expectationDescription: Compute unit rates associated with ratios of fractions, including ratios of lengths, areas and other quantities measured in like or different units presented in realistic problems.
Determine the unit rate (constant of proportionality) in tables, graphs (1, r), equations, diagrams, and verbal descriptions of proportional relationships to solve realistic problems.
Determine whether two quantities presented in authentic problems are in a proportional relationship.
Identify, represent, and use proportional relationships.

Use context to explain what a point (x, y) on the graph of a proportional relationship means in terms of the situation, with special attention to the points (0, 0) and (1, r) where r is the unit rate.
Solve everyday problems involving scale drawings of geometric figures, including computing actual lengths and areas from a scale drawing and reproducing a scale drawing at a different scale.
Use similar triangles to explain why the slope, m, is the same between any two distinct points on a non-vertical line in the coordinate plane.
Graph proportional relationships, interpreting the unit rate as the slope of the graph. Compare two different proportional relationships represented in different ways.
Use proportional relationships to solve multi-step ratio and percent problems presented in applicable situations.
Predict characteristics of a population by examining the characteristics of a representative sample. Recognize the potential limitations and scope of the sample to the population.
Analyze sampling methods and conclude that random sampling produces and supports valid inferences.
Use data from repeated random samples to evaluate how much a sample mean is expected to vary from a population mean. Simulate multiple samples of the same size.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Solve practical problems involving angle measurement, circles, area of circles, surface area of prisms and cylinders, and volume of cylinders and prisms composed of cubes and right prisms.

expectations.expectationDescription: Measure angles in whole nonstandard units.
Measure angles in whole number degrees using a protractor.
Use facts about supplementary, complementary, vertical, and adjacent angles in a multi-step problem to write and solve equations for an unknown angle in a figure.
Explore and describe the relationship between pi, radius, diameter, circumference, and area of a circle to derive the formulas for the circumference and area of a circle.
Given the formula for the area and circumference of a circle, solve problems that exist in everyday life.
Solve realistic problems involving surface area of right prisms and cylinders.

Describe the two-dimensional figures (cross sections) that result from slicing three-dimensional figures, as in the plane sections of right rectangular prisms, right rectangular pyramids, cones, cylinders, and spheres.
Explore volume as a measurable attribute of cylinders and right prisms. Find the volume of these geometric figures using concrete problems.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Using mathematical reasoning, investigate chance processes and develop, evaluate, and use probability models to find probabilities of simple events presented in authentic situations.

expectations.expectationDescription: Represent the probability of a chance event as a number between 0 and 1 that expresses the likelihood of the event occurring. Describe that a probability near 0 indicates an unlikely event, a probability around 1/2 indicates an event that is neither unlikely nor likely, and a probability near 1 indicates a likely event.
Approximate the probability of a chance event by collecting data on an event and observing its long-run relative frequency will approach the theoretical probability.

Develop a probability model and use it to find probabilities of simple events. Compare experimental and theoretical probabilities of events. If the probabilities are not close, explain possible sources of the discrepancy.
Develop a uniform probability model by assigning equal probability to all outcomes and use the model to determine probabilities of events.
Develop a probability model (which may not be uniform) by observing frequencies in data generated from a chance process.

Use appropriate graphical displays and numerical summaries from data distributions with categorical or quantitative (numerical) variables as probability models to draw informal inferences about two samples or populations.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information to investigate the diversity of living organisms and how they can be compared scientifically.

expectations.expectationDescription: Develop and defend a model that categorizes organisms based on common characteristics.

Evaluate historical models of how organisms were classified based on physical characteristics and how that led to the six kingdom system (currently archaea, bacteria, protists, fungi, plants, and animals).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information to describe how cell structures, cells, tissues, organs, and organ systems interact to maintain the basic needs of organisms.

expectations.expectationDescription: Develop a model and construct an explanation of how cell structures (specifically the nucleus, cytoplasm, cell membrane, cell wall, chloroplasts, lysosome, and mitochondria) contribute to the function of the cell as a system in obtaining nutrients in order to grow, reproduce, make needed materials, and process waste.
Develop and use a conceptual model of how cells are organized into tissues, tissues into organs, organs into systems, and systems into organisms.
Construct an argument that systems of the body (Cardiovascular, Excretory, Digestive, Respiratory, Muscular, Nervous, and Immune) interact with one another to carry out life processes.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information to explain how organisms reproduce either sexually or asexually and transfer genetic information to determine the traits of their offspring.

expectations.expectationDescription: Construct an explanation supported with scientific evidence of the role of genes and chromosomes in the process of inheriting a specific trait.
Develop and use a model to describe how asexual reproduction can result in offspring with identical genetic information while sexual reproduction results in genetic variation.
Ask questions to gather and synthesize information about the ways humans influence the inheritance of desired traits in organisms through selective breeding.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information to examine the interdependence of organisms with one another and their environments.

expectations.expectationDescription: Construct an explanation for the patterns of interactions observed in different ecosystems in terms of the relationships among and between organisms and abiotic components of the ecosystem.
Develop a model to describe the cycling of matter and the flow of energy among biotic and abiotic components of an ecosystem.
Analyze and interpret data to provide evidence for how resource availability, disease, climate, and human activity affect individual organisms, populations, communities, and ecosystems.

Ask questions to gather and synthesize information from multiple sources to differentiate between Earthâ€™s major terrestrial biomes (i.e., tropical rain forest, savanna, temperate forest, desert, grassland, taiga, and tundra) and aquatic ecosystems (i.e., freshwater, estuaries, and marine).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information from multiple sources to explain the theory of evolution of living organisms through inherited characteristics.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use mathematical representations to evaluate explanations of how natural selection leads to changes in specific traits of populations over successive generations.
Construct an explanation based on evidence that describes how genetic variation and environmental factors influence the probability of survival and reproduction of a species.
Analyze and interpret data for patterns in the fossil record that document the existence, diversity, and extinction of organisms and their relationships to modern organisms.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Generate and conceptualize artistic ideas and work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify and develop ideas, goals, and solutions for original media artworks through authentic engagement focused on creative processes through divergent thinking and open-ended inquiry.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Organize and develop artistic ideas and work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Structure and critique ideas, plans, prototypes, and processes for media arts productions, considering artistic intent, resources, presentation context, and associated elements and principles.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Refine and complete artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Understand and apply a variety of media arts processes to produce increasingly complex works of art, communicating personal choice and increasing technical skill using a range of elements and principles.

Refine and modify media artworks, improving technical quality and intentionally accentuating selected expressive and stylistic elements to reflect an understanding of purpose, tone, mood, audience, and place.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Select, analyze, and interpret artistic work for presentation.

expectations.expectationDescription: Synthesize multiple contents and forms into unified media arts productions that convey a strong theme and personal voice.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Develop and refine artistic techniques and work for presentation.

expectations.expectationDescription: Exhibit an increasing set of artistic, design, and technical skills through performing various roles in producing media artworks through creative problem-solving, collaborative communication, and organization.
Demonstrate creativity, exploratory process, and adaptability using innovative tools and techniques in revising and developing solutions to achieve an assigned purpose in constructing media artworks.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Convey meaning through the presentation of artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Design, evaluate, and refine presentation and distribution of multiple formats/context of media artworks, considering impact on personal growth and meaning conveyed.
Develop and maintain an individual portfolio of media artworks that shows proficiency in craftsmanship, technical skills, and the development of an emerging personal voice.
Analyze why and how an exhibition or production may influence ideas, beliefs, and experiences.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Perceive and analyze artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify, describe, and analyze methods, various styles, message and meaning with intent to develop and organize personal ideas, resolve specific visual arts problems, and create works of media art to manage audience experience.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Interpret intent and meaning in artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Interpret the intent and meanings of a variety of media artworks, focusing on intentions, forms, and various contexts by incorporating specific elements and principles.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Apply criteria to evaluate artistic work.

expectations.expectationDescription: Analyze and interpret media artworks through thoughtful discussion and/or written response, considering themes, ideas, mood/feeling, context and artistic goals based on input from the critique process.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Relate artistic ideas and works with societal, cultural, and historical context to deepen understanding.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify and build media arts skills to address social, cultural, or societal issues while examining related careers, higher order thinking, problem-solving, creativity, personal beliefs, imagination and lifelong learning opportunities in a local and global context.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Synthesize and relate knowledge and personal experiences to make art.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify and demonstrate trends in the media arts to communicate cultural differences to connect people and places through values, purpose, interdisciplinary study, differing perspectives to increase innovation, and the quality of work.
Interpret the use and impact of digital citizenship to include environments, technological contexts, copyright, plagiarism, citations, validating resources, and social media.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use technology resources to increase self-direction and self-regulation in learning, including for problem solving and collaboration (e.g., using the Internet to access online resources, edit documents collaboratively).

expectations.expectationDescription: Understand the difference between editing a shared document and suggesting edits (e.g. track changes).
Use digital tools or platforms to organize, display, annotate, and/or share a curated collection.
Complete an individual project (e.g., research or design) using technology resources.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Understand benefits and risks of digital citizenship and practices safe, responsible, legal, and ethical behavior while using technology tools and resources, especially related to personal information.

expectations.expectationDescription: Understand that digital content is permanent and cannot be deleted.
Discuss the benefits and risks of using password management systems and storing personal information online.
Understand how browser settings such as cookies collect data and track personal information.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Explore computer science and computing-related careers.

expectations.expectationDescription: Investigate a career that requires computing and technology.
Describe how computer science enhances other career fields.
Predict the role of computer science in future careers.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Articulate ideas responsibly by observing intellectual property rights and giving appropriate attribution.
Understand the pervasiveness and tradeoffs of computers and computing in daily life.

expectations.expectationDescription: Find and adjust privacy settings for online accounts; discuss the positive and negative effects that social media can have on one's life.
Recognize how the overuse of technology can impact mental, physical, and emotional health.
Identify phishing emails, insecure websites (e.g., not https), and risky links when on the Internet; build a positive digital footprint (e.g., blog, website, social media).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Apply strategies for troubleshooting hardware and software problems that may occur during use.

expectations.expectationDescription: Choose the correct settings for printing and troubleshoot common printing issues (printer not turned on, printer not connected).
Connect devices (including internet/WIFI and Bluetooth) and troubleshoot common connection issues (e.g., disrupted Internet connection, website that is not loading).
Manage and deploy software updates and troubleshoot simple software issues (i.e., look up solutions to issues).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Explore the relationship between computer hardware and software.

expectations.expectationDescription: Develop a working vocabulary of embedded computing including digital, analog, events, microcontrollers, sensors, LED, switch, servo, cloud computing, and internet of things.
Investigate how software interacts with hardware in the boot process.
Analyze and explain how computers communicate information with simple hardware inputs and outputs.
Create a product that analyzes how simple computer hardware can be used to develop innovative new products that interact with the physical world.
Design a computer program that senses something in the real world and changes an output based on the input.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Investigate and identify the basic components of computers and networks.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify the basic components of the computer by disassembling and reassembling a demonstration model personal computer (can be done â€˜virtuallyâ€™ online if demo model is not available).

Demonstrate an understanding of key functional components (input devices, output devices, processor, operating system, software applications, memory, storage, wi-fi and/or ethernet ports, and IP addresses).
Demonstrate an understanding of the terms and units used to describe major hardware components (RAM, ROM, GHz, MHz, GB, MB, CD, DVD, RW).
Explain the interrelation of the operating system software, application software, and utility software, citing specific examples of each.

Develop a basic vocabulary of networks including the Internet, wired, wireless, cellular, wi-fi, messages, packets, connections, bandwidth, broadband, firewall, hacking, cybersecurity, encryption, local area network (LAN), wide area network (WAN), and OSI model.
Demonstrate an understanding of the fundamental concepts for how computers process programming commands (hex, binary language, sequence of commands, conditional structures, looping structures).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Investigate ways to differentiate networks and how they are used in business and industry.

expectations.expectationDescription: Create diagrams to illustrate types of network topologies to include star, ring, bus, mesh, and hybrid.
Differentiate networks based on coverage area including local area network (LAN), wide area network (WAN), and personal area network (PAN).
Differentiate between different network mediums including Wi-fi, wired, satellite, and microwave.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Evaluate and provide a rationale for the levels of the Open Systems Interconnection (OSI) model.

expectations.expectationDescription: Summarize from multiple sources the physical and digital aspects of computing networks.
Trace the layers required to transmit data from one node to another (the OSI model).
Construct and explain the basic functions of the OSI model.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Examine the basics of cybersecurity needs for business, government, and organizations.

expectations.expectationDescription: List and define the elements of the confidentiality, integrity, and availability (CIA) triad.
Explain components of access control: Identification, Authentication, Authorization, Accountability, and Non-repudiation.
Identify the characteristics of strong vs. weak passwords in data and identity security.
List and describe the basic steps in security risk management.
Develop a logical argument for the importance of physical security.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Cite evidence regarding the principles of cybersecurity and basic mechanisms used for protecting data and resources.

expectations.expectationDescription: Define the cybersecurity first principles of least privilege, minimization, abstraction, domain separation, process isolation, information hiding, layering, simplicity, modularity, and resource encapsulation.
Apply concepts related to the principles behind encryption, including the purpose of cryptography, hashing, and steganography.
Draw conclusions illustrating a basic understanding of internet protocol (IP) packets, ports and network transmission.
Summarize from multiple sources a basic understanding of anti-malware, firewalls, intrusion detection system/intrusion prevention system (IDS/IPS), and virtual private network (VPN).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Analyze and describe the characteristics of cybersecurity ethics, digital citizenship, and laws governing privacy.

expectations.expectationDescription: Explain the differences between a white hat (ethical) hacker and a black hat (unethical) hacker.
Cite evidence regarding the practice of ethical digital decision-making, including plagiarism, copyright law, and software licensing types (freeware, public domain, shareware, etc.).
Summarize and provide examples regarding security and privacy laws and their impact on society, citing recent cases.
Analyze cyberbullying to include legal and social consequences.
Develop a set of guidelines to prevent cyberbullying.
Develop arguments for policy-driven and technology-driven security.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Evaluate the accuracy, relevance, appropriateness, comprehensiveness, and biases that occur in electronic information sources.

expectations.expectationDescription: Demonstrate an understanding of the credibility, bias, accuracy, relevance, age appropriateness, and comprehensiveness of electronic information sources.
Evaluate and discuss of the credibility, bias, accuracy, relevance, age appropriateness, and comprehensiveness of electronic information sources.
Apply strategies for determining the reliability of information found on the Internet.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Gather, manipulate, and analyze data using a variety of digital tools to identify solutions and make informed decisions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Gather data and calculate numerical equations using spreadsheet formulas and functions.
Use spreadsheet data to create tables, charts, and graphs.
Use spreadsheets and databases to make predictions, solve problems, and draw conclusions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Traverse online environments using critical thinking to find valid sources of information.
Analyze various ways to visually represent data.

expectations.expectationDescription: Interpret tables, charts, and graphs created by someone else.
Discuss design decisions in choosing between text, tables, charts, and graphs.
Discuss design decisions to make visualizations of data clear and concise.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Recognize that there may be multiple approaches to solving a problem.
Approach problem solving iteratively, using a cyclical process.
Design, develop, debug and implement computer programs.

expectations.expectationDescription: Develop a working vocabulary of programming including flowcharting and/or storyboarding, coding, debugging, user interfaces, usability, variables, lists, loops, conditionals, programming language, events.
Utilize the design process to brainstorm, implement, test, and revise an idea.
Cite evidence on how computers represent data and media (sounds, images, video, etc.).
Design a user interface and test with other users using a paper prototype.
Implement a simple algorithm in a computer program.
Develop an event driven program.
Create a program that accepts user and/or sensor input and stores the result in a variable.
Create a computer program that implements a loop.
Develop a program that makes a decision based on data or user input.
Debug a program with an error.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Develop a plan to create, design, and build a website with digital content to a specific target market.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify the objectives (e.g., increase sales, promote new products, increase company awareness, target new customers) for the websiteâ€™s target market.
Specify website requirements, including timeline and resources, and organize them into a requirements document.

Find and evaluate similar websites (in terms of overall function and layout) using an evaluation instrument for side-by-side comparison. Consider major design elements (ease of use, responsiveness, adaptability to mobile, tablet and desktop, etc.).
Evaluate a variety of web design tools and development platforms using an evaluation instrument and choose the appropriate platform.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Design digital products that reveal a professional layout and look by applying design principles to produce professional quality digital products.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify graphical elements and the appropriate use of elements on a web site.
Explore and apply color principles to digital products.
Establish a brand through consistent use of graphics, color, layout and text.
Analyze the look and layout of a website based on the first impression of content and page elements. Get feedback from independent people and incorporate where appropriate.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Create a single functional web page using a web development platform based on a design mockup and user requirements.

expectations.expectationDescription: Create and edit images and graphics for website publication.
Plan, produce, and edit digital audio for website publication.
Plan, produce, edit, and post a multimedia-rich video project to a website.
Plan, produce, and edit animations for website publication.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Develop and use a test plan to debug each new website version to ensure it runs as intended and meets the end-user requirements for a responsive site.

expectations.expectationDescription: Create a test and debug plan. Resolve issues and fix any errors that surface during the test and debug process.
Create an end user testing plan, get user feedback, and incorporate feedback into the final website.
Prepare website for publishing and promotion.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Develop a plan to create, design, and build a game with digital content for a specific target market.

expectations.expectationDescription: Explore various game types including role-playing games (RPG), real-time strategy (RTS), simulations, puzzles, educational, massively multiplayer online (MMO), and others.
Create a Game Design Document (GDD), which includes, characters, story, theme, and gameplay mechanics.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Develop a visual model of a game from the Game Design Document (GDD).

expectations.expectationDescription: Create storyboards from the GDD that demonstrate game progression and consistent use of a theme.
Use the GDD to design the wireframes and comprehensive layout for the user experience (UX).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Create a functional game, using a game development platform, based on the storyboards, wireframes, and comprehensive layout.

expectations.expectationDescription: Create game elements, backgrounds, and characters.
Use scripting languages to create desired game mechanics, and to control the environment, user interface (UI), and character behaviors.
Plan, produce, and edit graphics and animations for game publication.
Plan, produce, and edit digital audio for game publication.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Develop and use a test plan to debug use each time a version of the game is released to ensure it runs as intended and meets the end-user requirements.

expectations.expectationDescription: Create a test and debug plan. Resolve any issues and fix any errors that surface during the test and debug process.
Create an end user testing plan, get user feedback, and incorporate feedback into the final game.
Prepare final game for publishing prior to publishing to the target audience.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Create digital artifacts to address a current issue requiring resolution.

expectations.expectationDescription: Summarize ethical, privacy, and legal issues of a digital world using current case studies.
Collaborate as a team to develop an artifact that represents multiple perspectives regarding a global crisis.
Analyze and explain the functionality and suitability (or appropriateness) of a computational artifact.
Develop a program for creative expression or to satisfy personal curiosity which may have visual, audible, and/or tactile results.
Develop a program specifically with the goal of solving a problem, creating new knowledge, or helping people, organizations, or society.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Identify sub-problems to consider while addressing a larger problem.
Recognize when it is appropriate to solve a problem computationally; Make sense of computational problems and persevere in solving them.
Develop through application, logical observations relative to computational thinking procedures to analyze and solve problems current to everyday life.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify characteristics of computational thinking (decomposition, pattern recognition, algorithmic thinking and abstraction).
Explain issues and analyze routine hardware and software problems current to everyday life.
Apply troubleshooting concepts to issues regarding compatibility, data, and identity.
Describe ways to resolve operational problems caused by hardware errors.
Explain how technology can create ethical and legal issues in the business world and a technology-based society and how it can be used to solve & manage those issues.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Utilize computational thinking to solve problems.

expectations.expectationDescription: Make observations and organize the concepts of modularity, including functions and methods, as it relates to programming code reusability and cloud computing in the software industry.

Develop a working vocabulary of computational thinking including sequences, algorithms, binary, pattern matching, decomposition, abstraction, parallelization, data, automation, data collection, data analysis, boolean, integer, branches (if...then...else), and iteration {loops (For, While)}.
Analyze the problem-solving process, the input-process-output-storage model of a computer, and how computers help humans solve problems.
Develop an algorithm to decompose a problem of a daily task.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Recognize when to use the same solution for multiple problems.
Evaluate the storage and representation of data; Analyze how data is collected with both computational and non-computational tools and processes.

expectations.expectationDescription: Discuss binary numbers, logic, sets, and functions and their application to computer science.
Explain that searches may be enhanced by using Boolean logic (e.g., using â€œnotâ€, â€œorâ€, â€œandâ€).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Understand and use the basic steps in algorithmic problem solving in computing and other authentic applications.

expectations.expectationDescription: Select basic steps to solve algorithmic problems.
Evaluate basic steps of algorithmic problem solving to design solutions.
Solve algorithmic problems of increasing complexity.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use and compare simple coding control structures (e.g., if-then, loops)

expectations.expectationDescription: Use a visual block-based and/or text-based programming language individually and collaboratively to solve problems of increasing complexity.
Create a program individually and collaboratively using a text-based programming language; Identify variables and compare the types of data stored as variables.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Consider the purpose of computational artifacts for practical use, personal expression, and/or societal impact.

expectations.expectationDescription: Compare and contrast examples of high level and low-level programming languages.
Investigate the notion of hierarchy in computing including high level languages, translations, instruction sets, and logic circuits.
Develop problem solutions using a programming language, including all of the following: looping behavior, conditional statements, expressions, variables, and functions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Test computational artifacts systematically by considering multiple scenarios and using test cases.
Describe how humans and machines interact to accomplish tasks that cannot be accomplished by either alone.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify what distinguishes humans from machines focusing on human intelligence versus machine intelligence (e.g., robot motion, speech and language understanding, and computer vision); Explain why some tasks can be accomplished more easily by computers.

Describe ways in which computers use models of intelligent behavior (e.g., robot motion, speech and language understanding, and computer vision) and how they differ (e.g., emotional decision making versus logical decisions, common sense, literal versus abstract).
Design and demonstrate the use of a device (e.g., robot, e-textile) to accomplish a task, individually and collaboratively.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use online resources to participate in collaborative activities for the purpose of developing solutions or products.
Improve teamwork and collaboration skills: providing useful feedback, integrating feedback, understanding, and accepting multiple perspectives.

expectations.expectationDescription: Understand the difference between CC and BCC as well as Reply and Reply All and when to use each appropriately.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Collaborate productively and recognize the value of working with individuals of varying perspectives, skills, and backgrounds.

expectations.expectationDescription: Set and implement equitable expectations and workloads when working in teams.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Demonstrate correct keyboarding techniques while increasing speed and maintaining accuracy.
Use productivity technology tools (e.g. word processing, spreadsheet, presentation software) for individual and collaborative writing, communication, and publishing activities.
Recognize that equitable access to computing benefits society as a whole.
Consider othersâ€™ perspectives as well as oneâ€™s own perspective when developing computational solutions.
Consider the needs of a variety of end users regarding accessibility and usability.
Use software applications to collaborate and create authentic products.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify and utilize the appropriate software application for productivity.
Use various applications in a professional manner to share and communicate with peers and teachers.
Share documents created using word processing, presentation, and spreadsheet software.
Create original works using software applications in a collaborative manner.
Collaborate in small groups to create and edit online documents in real time.
Identify and use appropriate file sharing strategies (e.g., copy and paste, links, posts, and attachments).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Display perseverance and patience in problem-solving. Demonstrate skills and strategies needed to succeed in mathematics, including critical thinking, reasoning, and effective collaboration and expression. Seek help and apply feedback. Set and monitor goals.
Solve problems involving irrational numbers and rational approximations of irrational numbers to explain realistic applications.

expectations.expectationDescription: Distinguish between rational and irrational numbers using decimal expansion. Convert a decimal expansion which repeats eventually into a rational number.
Approximate irrational numbers to compare the size of irrational numbers, locate them approximately on a number line, and estimate the value of expressions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Solve problems involving radicals and integer exponents including relevant application situations; apply place value understanding with scientific notation and use scientific notation to explain real phenomena.

expectations.expectationDescription: Apply the properties of integer exponents to generate equivalent numerical expressions.

Use square root and cube root symbols to represent solutions to equations. Recognize that xÂ² = p (where p is a positive rational number and |x| â‰¤ 25) has two solutions and xÂ³ = p (where p is a negative or positive rational number and |x| â‰¤ 10) has one solution. Evaluate square roots of perfect squares â‰¤ 625 and cube roots of perfect cubes â‰¥ -1000 and â‰¤ 1000.
Use numbers expressed in scientific notation to estimate very large or very small quantities, and to express how many times as much one is than the other.

Add, subtract, multiply and divide numbers expressed in scientific notation, including problems where both decimal and scientific notation are used. Interpret scientific notation that has been generated by technology (e.g., calculators or online technology tools).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Create and interpret expressions within relevant situations. Create, interpret, and solve linear equations and linear inequalities in one variable to model and explain real phenomena.

expectations.expectationDescription: Interpret expressions and parts of an expression, in context, by utilizing formulas or expressions with multiple terms and/or factors.

Describe and solve linear equations in one variable with one solution (x = a), infinitely many solutions (a = a), or no solutions (a = b). Show which of these possibilities is the case by successively transforming the given equation into simpler forms, until an equivalent equation of the form x = a, a = a, or a = b results (where a and b are different numbers).
Create and solve linear equations and inequalities in one variable within a relevant application.
Using algebraic properties and the properties of real numbers, justify the steps of a one-solution equation or inequality.
Solve linear equations and inequalities in one variable with coefficients represented by letters and explain the solution based on the contextual, mathematical situation.
Use algebraic reasoning to fluently manipulate linear and literal equations expressed in various forms to solve relevant, mathematical problems.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Show and explain the connections between proportional and non-proportional relationships, lines, and linear equations; create and interpret graphical mathematical models and use the graphical, mathematical model to explain real phenomena represented in the graph.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use the equation y = mx (proportional) for a line through the origin to derive the equation y = mx + b (non-proportional) for a line intersecting the vertical axis at b.
Show and explain that the graph of an equation representing an applicable situation in two variables is the set of all its solutions plotted in the coordinate plane.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Describe the properties of functions to define, evaluate, and compare relationships, and use functions and graphs of functions to model and explain real phenomena.

expectations.expectationDescription: Show and explain that a function is a rule that assigns to each input exactly one output.

Within realistic situations, identify and describe examples of functions that are linear or nonlinear. Sketch a graph that exhibits the qualitative features of a function that has been described verbally.
Relate the domain of a linear function to its graph and where applicable to the quantitative relationship it describes.

Compare properties (rate of change and initial value) of two functions used to model an authentic situation each represented in a different way (algebraically, graphically, numerically in tables, or by verbal descriptions).

Write and explain the equations y = mx + b (slope-intercept form), Ax + By = C (standard form), and (y - y1) = m(x - x1) (point-slope form) as defining a linear function whose graph is a straight line to reveal and explain different properties of the function.
Write a linear function defined by an expression in different but equivalent forms to reveal and explain different properties of the function.

Construct a function to model a linear relationship between two quantities. Determine the rate of change and initial value of the function from a description of a relationship or from two (x, y) values, including reading these from a table or from a graph.
Explain the meaning of the rate of change and initial value of a linear function in terms of the situation it models, and in terms of its graph or a table of values.
Graph and analyze linear functions expressed in various algebraic forms and show key characteristics of the graph to describe applicable situations.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Solve practical, linear problems involving situations using bivariate quantitative data.

expectations.expectationDescription: Show that straight lines are widely used to model relationships between two quantitative variables. For scatter plots that suggest a linear association, visually fit a straight line, and informally assess the model fit by judging the closeness of the data points to the line of best fit.
Use the equation of a linear model to solve problems in the context of bivariate measurement data, interpreting the slope and intercepts.
Explain the meaning of the predicted slope (rate of change) and the predicted intercept (constant term) of a linear model in the context of the data.

Use appropriate graphical displays from data distributions involving lines of best fit to draw informal inferences and answer the statistical investigative question posed in an unbiased statistical study.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Justify and use various strategies to solve systems of linear equations to model and explain realistic phenomena.

expectations.expectationDescription: Interpret and solve relevant mathematical problems leading to two linear equations in two variables.

Show and explain that solutions to a system of two linear equations in two variables correspond to points of intersection of their graphs, because the points of intersection satisfy both equations simultaneously.
Approximate solutions of two linear equations in two variables by graphing the equations and solving simple cases by inspection.
Analyze and solve systems of two linear equations in two variables algebraically to find exact solutions.
Create and compare the equations of two lines that are either parallel to each other, perpendicular to each other, or neither parallel nor perpendicular.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Solve contextual, geometric problems involving the Pythagorean Theorem and the volume of geometric figures to explain real phenomena.

expectations.expectationDescription: Explain a proof of the Pythagorean Theorem and its converse using visual models.
Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to determine unknown side lengths in right triangles within authentic, mathematical problems in two and three dimensions.
Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to find the distance between two points in a coordinate system in practical, mathematical problems.
Apply the formulas for the volume of cones, cylinders, and spheres and use them to solve in relevant problems.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information about the structure and properties of matter.

expectations.expectationDescription: Develop and use a model to compare and contrast pure substances (elements and compounds) and mixtures.
Develop and use models to describe the movement of particles in solids, liquids, gases, and plasma states when thermal energy is added or removed.
Plan and carry out investigations to compare and contrast chemical (i.e., reactivity, combustibility) and physical (i.e., density, melting point, boiling point) properties of matter.
Construct an argument based on observational evidence to support the claim that when a change in a substance occurs, it can be classified as either chemical or physical.

Develop models (e.g., atomic-level models, including drawings, and computer representations) by analyzing patterns within the periodic table that illustrate the structure, composition, and characteristics of atoms (protons, neutrons, and electrons) and simple molecules.
Construct an explanation based on evidence to describe conservation of matter in a chemical reaction including the resulting differences between products and reactants.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information about the law of conservation of energy to develop arguments that energy can transform from one form to another within a system.

expectations.expectationDescription: Analyze and interpret data to create graphical displays that illustrate the relationships of kinetic energy to mass and speed, and potential energy to mass and height of an object.
Plan and carry out an investigation to explain the transformation between kinetic and potential energy within a system (e.g., roller coasters, pendulums, rubber bands, etc.).
Construct an argument to support a claim about the type of energy transformations within a system [e.g., lighting a match (light to heat), turning on a light (electrical to light)].

Plan and carry out investigations on the effects of heat transfer on molecular motion as it relates to the collision of atoms (conduction), through space (radiation), or in currents in a liquid or a gas (convection).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information about cause and effect relationships between force, mass, and the motion of objects.

expectations.expectationDescription: Analyze and interpret data to identify patterns in the relationships between speed and distance, and velocity and acceleration.
Construct an explanation using Newtonâ€™s Laws of Motion to describe the effects of balanced and unbalanced forces on the motion of an object.
Construct an argument from evidence to support the claim that the amount of force needed to accelerate an object is proportional to its mass (inertia).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information to support the claim that electromagnetic (light) waves behave differently than mechanical (sound) waves.

expectations.expectationDescription: Ask questions to develop explanations about the similarities and differences between electromagnetic and mechanical waves.
Construct an explanation using data to illustrate the relationship between the electromagnetic spectrum and energy.
Design a device to illustrate practical applications of the electromagnetic spectrum (e.g., communication, medical, military).
Develop and use a model to compare and contrast how light and sound waves are reflected, refracted, absorbed, diffracted or transmitted through various materials.
Analyze and interpret data to predict patterns in the relationship between density of media and wave behavior (i.e., speed).
Develop and use a model (e.g., simulations, graphs, illustrations) to predict and describe the relationships between wave properties (e.g., frequency, amplitude, and wavelength) and energy.
Develop and use models to demonstrate the effects that lenses have on light (i.e., formation an image) and their possible technological applications.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information about gravity, electricity, and magnetism as major forces acting in nature.

expectations.expectationDescription: Construct an argument using evidence to support the claim that fields (i.e., magnetic fields, gravitational fields, and electric fields) exist between objects exerting forces on each other even when the objects are not in contact.
Plan and carry out investigations to demonstrate the distribution of charge in conductors and insulators.

Plan and carry out investigations to identify the factors (e.g., distance between objects, magnetic force produced by an electromagnet with varying number of wire turns, varying number or size of dry cells, and varying size of iron core) that affect the strength of electric and magnetic forces.

states.stateStandardName: Ohio`s Learning Standards and Model Curriculum

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will observe and understand weather changes

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will identify that weather changes occur throughout the day and from day to day.
Students will understand that air is a nonliving substance that surrounds Earth and wind is moving air.
Students will use wind, temperature, and precipitation to document short-term weather changes.
Students will observe yearly weather changes (seasons) as patterns in daily weather changes.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will observe the moon, sun, and stars at different times

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will describe the positions of the moon, sun, and stars at different times of the day or night.

Students will observe the apparent changes in the sun's position throughout the day and across seasons. They will identify that stars are visible at night and some are visible in the evening or morning.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will sort and describe objects by their properties

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will sort and describe objects based on the material properties, including color, size, and texture.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will understand the production of sound

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will identify that sound is produced by touching, blowing, or tapping objects. They will understand that the sound produced depends on the properties of the objects.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will understand the characteristics and traits of living things

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will recognize that living things grow and reproduce, and they are found worldwide.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will explore the physical traits and behaviors of living things

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will identify that living things have various structures and some of these structures and behaviors influence their survival.

sections.sectionDescription: Introduce students to the concept that weather changes occur throughout the day and from day to day.
Explain that air is a nonliving substance that surrounds Earth and wind is moving air.
Use wind, temperature, and precipitation to document short-term weather changes.
Observe yearly weather changes (seasons) as patterns in daily weather changes.
Describe the positions of the moon at different times of the day or night.
Observe the apparent changes in the sun's position throughout the day and across seasons.
Identify that stars are visible at night and some are visible in the evening or morning.
Sort and describe objects based on the material properties, including color, size, and texture.
Identify that sound is produced by touching, blowing, or tapping objects.
Understand that the sound produced depends on the properties of the objects.
Recognize that living things grow and reproduce, and they are found worldwide.
Identify that living things have various structures and some of these structures and behaviors influence their survival.
Students will create weather journals to document daily and seasonal weather changes.
Conduct experiments to observe the effects of wind on different objects.
Plan a star gazing night to observe and identify stars and constellations.
Create instruments from everyday materials to explore how different sounds are made.
Observe and document changes in the environment as seasons change.
Investigate and sort various materials based on their properties.
Study the life cycle of plants from seed to full-grown plant.
Learn about different animal habitats and how animals adapt to their environments.
Identify and describe patterns in weather changes.
Observe how light creates shadows and changes with the position of the sun.
Identify and describe the different parts of a plant and their functions.
Learn about various animal behaviors that help them survive in their habitats.
Create a class band using homemade instruments to understand sound production.
Learn how to predict weather changes based on wind, temperature, and precipitation observations.
Observe and record how shadows change in size and direction throughout the day.
Investigate different types of rocks and soil, and their properties.
Learn about the basic needs of plants for growth and survival.
Study the life cycles of various animals from birth to adulthood.
Begin planning final projects that incorporate various concepts learned throughout the year.
Develop and create final projects with guidance and support.
Complete and polish final projects, preparing for presentation.
Students present their final projects to the class, explaining their work and what they learned.
Review key concepts learned throughout the year and reflect on personal growth.
Celebrate the year's accomplishments and discuss how students can continue to explore science in the future.

objectives.objectiveDescription: The understanding and application of digital learning tools for accessing, creating, evaluating, applying and communicating ideas and information.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify and use appropriate digital learning tools and resources to accomplish a defined task.
Use digital learning tools and resources to locate, evaluate and use information.
Use digital learning tools and resources to construct knowledge.
Use digital learning tools and resources to communicate and disseminate information to multiple audiences.

objectives.objectiveDescription: The interconnectedness of technology, self, society and the natural world, specifically addressing the ethical, legal, political and global impact of technology.

expectations.expectationDescription: Demonstrate an understanding of technologyâ€™s impact on the advancement of humanity â€“ economically, environmentally and ethically.
Analyze the impact of communication and collaboration in both digital and physical environments.
Explain how technology, society and the individual impact one another.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Addresses the nature of technology to develop and improve products and systems over time to meet human/societal needs and wants through design processes.

expectations.expectationDescription: Define and describe technology, including its core concepts of systems, resources, requirements, processes, controls, optimization and trade-offs.
Identify a problem and use an engineering design process to solve the problem.
Demonstrate that solutions to complex problems require collaboration, interdisciplinary understanding and systems thinking.
Evaluate designs using functional, aesthetic and creative elements.

sections.sectionDescription: Introduce students to various digital learning tools and resources.
Teach students how to use digital tools to accomplish defined tasks.
Use digital learning tools to locate information.
Teach students how to evaluate the reliability and usefulness of online information.
Guide students on how to use the information they have found and evaluated.
Use digital tools to help students construct and organize knowledge.
Teach students how to use digital tools to communicate and share information with others.
Guide students on how to create digital presentations to disseminate information.
Discuss how technology has impacted humanity economically, environmentally, and ethically.
Analyze the impact of communication and collaboration in both digital and physical environments.
Explain how technology, society, and the individual impact one another.
Define and describe technology, including its core concepts of systems, resources, requirements, processes, controls, optimization, and trade-offs.
Identify a problem and use an engineering design process to solve the problem.
Learn about the steps involved in the engineering design process.
Demonstrate that solutions to complex problems require collaboration, interdisciplinary understanding, and systems thinking.
Evaluate designs using functional, aesthetic, and creative elements.
Use digital tools to create and share digital stories.
Discuss the environmental impact of various technologies.
Teach students how to use search engines to find reliable information.
Engage in a design challenge to solve a real-world problem using the engineering design process.
Use digital tools to create and share digital artwork.
Analyze how technological advancements have impacted society and communities.
Complete a collaborative project using digital tools.
Discuss ethical considerations in using technology.
Teach students about digital citizenship and responsible use of technology.
Explore examples of technological innovations and their impact.
Review the core concepts of technology learned throughout the course.
Introduce and explore advanced digital learning tools.
Begin planning final projects incorporating concepts from ICT, ST, and DT.
Develop and work on final projects with guidance and support.
Complete final projects and prepare for presentations.
Students present their final projects to the class, explaining their work and what they learned.
Review the key concepts and lessons learned throughout the course.
Reflect on personal growth and understanding of technology and its impact.
Discuss and set future learning goals related to technology.
Celebrate the achievements and learning of the year, with a focus on technology's impact and future potential.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Kindergarten standards for Computing Systems.

expectations.expectationDescription: With guidance, identify and label commonly used devices and their components, explaining their connection to different tasks, to perform a variety of tasks.
With guidance and support, identify and use hardware and software necessary for accomplishing a task.
With guidance and support, use problem-solving strategies to troubleshoot a problem.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Kindergarten standards for Networks and the Internet.

expectations.expectationDescription: With guidance and support, create a list of ways information can be shared electronically to gain a deeper understanding of how information is transmitted (e.g., email, social media).
With guidance and support, identify and use secure practices (e.g., passwords) to protect private information.
With guidance and support, identify what smart devices are to recognize what devices are able to connect to the internet.
With guidance and support, recognize how devices connect and exchange data over the internet to demonstrate how information is shared.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Kindergarten standards for Data and Analysis.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify data to collect and sort.
With guidance and support, demonstrate how data can be collected and stored in a variety of ways.
With guidance, organize and present data in various formats to make observations.
With guidance, create a model of an object or process to identify patterns.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Kindergarten standards for Algorithmic Thinking and Programming.

expectations.expectationDescription: With guidance and support, model a real-world process by constructing and following step-by-step directions (i.e., algorithms) to complete tasks.
Recognize that a group of items (e.g., numbers, symbols or pictures) can be used to represent data.
With guidance and support, model a sequence of instructions (i.e., program) with a beginning, middle and end to solve a problem or express an idea.
With guidance and support, plan or create an artifact to illustrate thoughts, ideas and problems in a sequential (step-by-step) manner (e.g., story map, storyboard, sequential graphic organizer).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Kindergarten standards for Artificial Intelligence.

expectations.expectationDescription: With guidance and support, locate sensors on computers, robots and intelligent appliances to understand that devices use sensors to gather information.
With guidance and support, access intelligent agents to demonstrate how they work.
With guidance and support, use a simple decision tree to make a decision to visually and explicitly represent decisions and decision-making.
With guidance and support, use a classifier that recognizes drawings to see if a program can guess what they are drawing.
With guidance and support, identify how computers can recognize different humans using some form of recognition software to see how computers interact with humans.
With guidance and support, locate AI applications used in daily life to understand how humans use AI.
Discuss if artificial intelligence is good or bad (see impacts of computing).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Kindergarten standards for Impacts of Computing.

expectations.expectationDescription: With guidance and support, identify technologies that impact one's own everyday life.
With guidance and support, recognize different ways computing devices are used regularly to understand technology's impact on oneâ€™s own daily life.
With guidance and support, identify and use safe and responsible behaviors concerning information and technology.
With guidance, discuss appropriate uses of technology to support informed decisions.
With guidance and support, discuss examples of appropriate and inappropriate behavior online, including cyberbullying, and the steps to keep yourself and others safe and out of harm's way.

sections.sectionDescription: Identify and label commonly used devices and their components, explaining their connection to different tasks.
Identify and use hardware and software necessary for accomplishing a task.
Use problem-solving strategies to troubleshoot a problem.
Create a list of ways information can be shared electronically to understand how information is transmitted.
Identify and use secure practices such as passwords to protect private information.
Identify what smart devices are and recognize what devices are able to connect to the internet.
Recognize how devices connect and exchange data over the internet to demonstrate how information is shared.
Identify data to collect and sort.
Demonstrate how data can be collected and stored in a variety of ways.
Organize and present data in various formats to make observations.
Create a model of an object or process to identify patterns.
Model a real-world process by constructing and following step-by-step directions to complete tasks.
Recognize that a group of items such as numbers, symbols, or pictures can be used to represent data.
Model a sequence of instructions with a beginning, middle, and end to solve a problem or express an idea.
Plan or create an artifact to illustrate thoughts, ideas, and problems in a sequential manner.
Locate sensors on computers, robots, and intelligent appliances to understand that devices use sensors to gather information.
Access intelligent agents to demonstrate how they work.
Use a simple decision tree to make a decision and visually represent decision-making.
Use a classifier that recognizes drawings to see if a program can guess what they are drawing.
Identify how computers can recognize different humans using some form of recognition software.
Locate AI applications used in daily life to understand how humans use AI.
Discuss if artificial intelligence is good or bad and see impacts of computing.
Identify technologies that impact one's own everyday life.
Recognize different ways computing devices are used regularly to understand technology's impact on daily life.
Identify and use safe and responsible behaviors concerning information and technology.
Discuss appropriate uses of technology to support informed decisions.
Discuss examples of appropriate and inappropriate behavior online, including cyberbullying, and steps to stay safe.
