Review the key concepts of computing systems and networks.
Review the key concepts of data collection, storage, and presentation.
Review the key concepts of algorithmic thinking and programming.
Review the key concepts of artificial intelligence.
Review the key concepts of the impacts of computing.

sections.sSID: CS.K, NI.K, DA.K, ATP.K, AI.K, IC.K
sections.sectionDescription: Begin planning final projects that incorporate various concepts learned throughout the year.

sections.sSID: CS.K, NI.K, DA.K, ATP.K, AI.K, IC.K
sections.sectionDescription: Develop and create final projects with guidance and support.

sections.sSID: CS.K, NI.K, DA.K, ATP.K, AI.K, IC.K
sections.sectionDescription: Students present their final projects to the class, explaining their work and what they learned.

sections.sSID: CS.K, NI.K, DA.K, ATP.K, AI.K, IC.K
sections.sectionDescription: Review key concepts learned throughout the year and celebrate the accomplishments and learning of the students.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Observe, listen, attend to, discriminate.

expectations.expectationDescription: Describe the meaning in the marks they make on paper.
Name and point out subject matter and details observed in works of art.
Describe different ways that an artwork expresses an emotion or mood.
Distinguish between common visual art forms (e.g., painting, drawing, sculpture).
Identify and name materials used in visual art.
Recognize and point out basic elements of art in their own artworks and that of others.
Explore their environments and experiences for artmaking ideas.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Generate, create, realize, use & master skills.

expectations.expectationDescription: Explore and experiment with a range of art materials and tools to create and communicate personal meaning.
Generate ideas and images for artwork based on observation, memory, imagination, and experience.
Discover, select and combine art and design elements to communicate subject matter in various visual forms.
Reduce objects into basic shapes and lines in relation to the whole image.
Engage in artmaking that explores and combines various forms of symbolic representation including words, symbols, images, music, and movement.
Create artwork that explores a central theme across disciplines.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Make connections, reconsider, question, self-assess.

expectations.expectationDescription: Describe their artworks and efforts and share their artmaking processes.
Show confidence and pride in their artistic accomplishments.
Connect their personal experiences to what they see in works of art.
Communicate the ideas and stories they see in works of art.
Describe what they see and feel in selected works of art.
Recognize and point out the similarities and differences between artistic styles.
Recognize that people have different opinions and responses to works of art.
Consider and talk about why people make and enjoy works of art.

sections.sectionDescription: Describe the meaning in the marks they make on paper.
Name and point out subject matter and details observed in works of art.
Describe different ways that an artwork expresses an emotion or mood.
Distinguish between common visual art forms such as painting, drawing, and sculpture.
Identify and name materials used in visual art.
Recognize and point out basic elements of art in their own artworks and that of others.
Explore their environments and experiences for artmaking ideas.

Create artwork that explores a central theme across disciplines.

Show confidence and pride in their artistic accomplishments.
Connect their personal experiences to what they see in works of art.
Communicate the ideas and stories they see in works of art.
Describe what they see and feel in selected works of art.
Recognize and point out the similarities and differences between artistic styles.
Recognize that people have different opinions and responses to works of art.
Consider and talk about why people make and enjoy works of art.
Further exploration and experimentation with a range of art materials and tools.
Generate new ideas and images for artwork based on observation and imagination.
Combine art and design elements to create visual forms.
Further practice in reducing objects to basic shapes and lines.
Engage in artmaking that explores various forms of symbolic representation.
Create artwork exploring a central theme across disciplines.
Describe and reflect on their artmaking processes.
Show confidence and pride in their artistic accomplishments.
Connect personal experiences to what they see in works of art.
Communicate the ideas and stories they see in works of art.
Describe what they see and feel in selected works of art.
Recognize and discuss artistic styles, similarities, and differences.
Begin planning final art projects incorporating various concepts learned throughout the year.
Develop and create final art projects with guidance and support.
Students present their final projects to the class, explaining their work and what they learned.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Know number names and the count sequence.

expectations.expectationDescription: Count to 100 by ones and by tens.
Count forward within 100 beginning from any given number other than 1.
Write numerals from 0 to 20. Represent a number of objects with a written numeral 0-20 (with 0 representing a count of no objects).
Understand the relationship between numbers and quantities; connect counting to cardinality using a variety of objects including pennies.

Count to answer 'how many?' questions about as many as 20 things arranged in a line, a rectangular array, or a circle, or as many as 10 things in a scattered configuration; given a number from 1-20, count out that many objects.

Orally identify (without using inequality symbols) whether the number of objects in one group is greater/more than, less/fewer than, or the same as the number of objects in another group, not to exceed 10 objects in each group.
Compare (without using inequality symbols) two numbers between 0 and 10 when presented as written numerals.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Understand addition as putting together and adding to, and understand subtraction as taking apart and taking from.

expectations.expectationDescription: Represent addition and subtraction with objects, fingers, mental images, drawings, sounds such as claps, acting out situations, verbal explanations, expressions, or equations.
Solve addition and subtraction problems (written or oral), and add and subtract within 10 by using objects or drawings to represent the problem.
Decompose numbers and record compositions for numbers less than or equal to 10 into pairs in more than one way by using objects and, when appropriate, drawings or equations.
For any number from 1 to 9, find the number that makes 10 when added to the given number, e.g., by using objects or drawings, and record the answer with a drawing or, when appropriate, an equation.
Fluently add and subtract within 5.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Number and Operations in Base Ten
objectives.objectiveDescription: Work with numbers 11â€“19 to gain foundations for place value.

expectations.expectationDescription: Compose and decompose numbers from 11 to 19 into a group of ten ones and some further ones by using objects and, when appropriate, drawings or equations; understand that these numbers are composed of a group of ten ones and one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, or nine ones.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Identify, describe, and compare measurable attributes.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify and describe measurable attributes (length, weight, and height) of a single object using vocabulary terms such as long/short, heavy/light, or tall/short.
Directly compare two objects with a measurable attribute in common to see which object has 'more of' or 'less of' the attribute, and describe the difference.

Classify objects into given categories; count the numbers of objects in each category and sort the categories by count. The number of objects in each category should be less than or equal to ten. Counting and sorting coins should be limited to pennies.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Identify and describe shapes (squares, circles, triangles, rectangles, hexagons, cubes, cones, cylinders, and spheres).

expectations.expectationDescription: Describe objects in the environment using names of shapes, and describe the relative positions of these objects using terms such as above, below, beside, in front of, behind, and next to.
Correctly name shapes regardless of their orientations or overall size.
Identify shapes as two-dimensional (lying in a plane, 'flat') or three-dimensional ('solid').
Describe and compare two- or three-dimensional shapes, in different sizes and orientations, using informal language to describe their commonalities, differences, parts, and other attributes.
Model shapes in the world by building shapes from components, e.g., sticks and clay balls, and drawing shapes.
Combine simple shapes to form larger shapes.

sections.sectionDescription: Learn to count to 100 by ones.
Learn to count to 100 by tens.
Practice counting forward within 100 from any given number.
Write numerals from 0 to 20.
Represent a number of objects with a written numeral 0-20.
Understand the relationship between numbers and quantities using various objects.
Count to answer 'how many?' questions about up to 20 objects arranged in various configurations.
Identify whether the number of objects in one group is greater, less, or the same as another group.
Compare two numbers between 0 and 10 when presented as written numerals.
Represent addition and subtraction with various methods.
Solve addition and subtraction problems within 10 using objects or drawings.
Decompose numbers less than or equal to 10 into pairs in multiple ways.
Find the number that makes 10 when added to any number from 1 to 9.
Fluently add and subtract within 5.
Compose and decompose numbers from 11 to 19 into a group of ten ones and further ones.
Identify and describe measurable attributes of objects using terms like long/short, heavy/light, or tall/short.
Compare two objects with a measurable attribute in common and describe the difference.
Classify objects into given categories; count the number of objects in each category and sort the categories by count.
Describe objects in the environment using names of shapes and their relative positions.
Correctly name shapes regardless of their orientations or overall size.
Identify shapes as two-dimensional (flat) or three-dimensional (solid).
Describe and compare two- or three-dimensional shapes using informal language.
Model shapes in the world by building shapes from components and drawing shapes.
Combine simple shapes to form larger shapes.
Review the concepts of counting and cardinality learned so far.
Review the concepts of addition and subtraction learned so far.

outline.title: Reviewing Number and Operations in Base Ten

sections.sectionDescription: Review the concepts of number and operations in base ten learned so far.
Review the concepts of measurement and data learned so far.
Review the concepts of geometry learned so far.
Practice advanced counting techniques and challenges.
Explore more complex addition and subtraction problems.
Deepen understanding of place value with larger numbers.
Explore advanced measurement and data concepts.
Explore complex shapes and geometric concepts.
Begin planning final projects incorporating various concepts learned throughout the year.
Develop and create final projects with guidance and support.
Complete final projects and prepare for presentations.
Students present their final projects to the class, explaining their work and what they learned.
Review key concepts learned throughout the year and celebrate the accomplishments and learning of the students.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will understand the sun as the primary source of energy

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will explain that sunlight warms Earth's land, air, and water.
Students will identify that the amount of sunlight exposure affects the warming or cooling of air, water, and land.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will explore the different forms of water on Earth

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will describe that water on Earth exists in many forms.

Students will explain that the physical properties of water can change due to changes in energy. They will identify that water can change from a liquid to a solid (freezing) and from a solid to a liquid (melting).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will investigate how properties of objects and materials can change

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will observe that objects and materials change when exposed to various conditions, such as heating or cooling. They will understand that changes in temperature are a result of changes in energy.
Students will identify that not all materials change in the same way when exposed to different conditions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will explore motion and how objects can be moved

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will describe the position of an object by locating it relative to another object or its surroundings.
Students will identify that an object is in motion when its position changes.

Students will explain that the motion of an object can be affected by pushing or pulling (forces). They will understand that a push or pull can make an object move faster, slower, or change direction.
Students will recognize that changes in motion are a result of changes in energy.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will understand the basic needs of living things

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will identify that living things require energy, water, and a specific temperature range in their environment.
Students will explain that plants get energy from sunlight, while animals get energy from plants and other animals.
Students will recognize that living things acquire resources from both living and nonliving components of their environment.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will explore how living things survive in their environment

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will understand that resources are necessary to meet the needs of individual organisms and populations.
Students will explain how living things interact with their physical environments to meet their needs.

outline.title: Introduction to Earth and Space Science

sections.sectionDescription: Students will explain that sunlight warms Earth's land, air, and water.
Students will identify that the amount of sunlight exposure affects the warming or cooling of air, water, and land.
Students will describe that water on Earth exists in many forms.

Students will explain that the physical properties of water can change due to changes in energy. They will identify that water can change from a liquid to a solid (freezing) and from a solid to a liquid (melting).

Students will observe that objects and materials change when exposed to various conditions, such as heating or cooling. They will understand that changes in temperature are a result of changes in energy.
Students will identify that not all materials change in the same way when exposed to different conditions.
Students will describe the position of an object by locating it relative to another object or its surroundings.
Students will identify that an object is in motion when its position changes.

Students will explain that the motion of an object can be affected by pushing or pulling (forces). They will understand that a push or pull can make an object move faster, slower, or change direction.
Students will recognize that changes in motion are a result of changes in energy.
Students will identify that living things require energy, water, and a specific temperature range in their environment.
Students will explain that plants get energy from sunlight, while animals get energy from plants and other animals.
Students will recognize that living things acquire resources from both living and nonliving components of their environment.
Students will understand that resources are necessary to meet the needs of individual organisms and populations.
Students will explain how living things interact with their physical environments to meet their needs.

sections.sectionTitle: Review of Earth and Space Science
sections.sectionDescription: Review the concepts of sunlight's impact on Earth and the different forms of water.
Review the concepts of properties of materials and motion.
Review the concepts of basic needs of living things and how they survive in their environments.
Plan a class project focusing on the impact of sunlight on Earth and the different forms of water.
Develop and conduct experiments related to the project topic.
Present the findings and results of the project to the class.
Plan a class project focusing on the properties of materials and motion.
Develop and conduct experiments related to the project topic.
Present the findings and results of the project to the class.
Plan a class project focusing on the basic needs of living things and their interactions with the environment.
Develop and conduct experiments related to the project topic.
Present the findings and results of the project to the class.
Review and integrate concepts from Earth and Space Science, Physical Science, and Life Science.

outline.title: Advanced Topics in Earth and Space Science

sections.sectionDescription: Explore advanced topics related to the sun's energy and water on Earth.
Explore advanced topics related to the properties of materials and motion.
Explore advanced topics related to the basic needs and interactions of living things.
Review all the concepts learned throughout the course and reflect on personal growth and understanding.
Begin planning final interdisciplinary projects that incorporate various techniques and concepts learned during the year.
Develop and refine final interdisciplinary projects.
Present final interdisciplinary projects to the class, explaining the integration of various scientific concepts.
Reflect on the entire course, celebrate accomplishments, and discuss how students can continue to explore science in the future.

objectives.objectiveDescription: The understanding and application of digital learning tools for accessing, creating, evaluating, applying and communicating ideas and information.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify and use appropriate digital learning tools and resources to accomplish a defined task.
Use digital learning tools and resources to locate, evaluate and use information.
Use digital learning tools and resources to construct knowledge.
Use digital learning tools and resources to communicate and disseminate information to multiple audiences.

objectives.objectiveDescription: The interconnectedness of technology, self, society and the natural world, specifically addressing the ethical, legal, political and global impact of technology.

expectations.expectationDescription: Demonstrate an understanding of technologyâ€™s impact on the advancement of humanity â€“ economically, environmentally and ethically.
Analyze the impact of communication and collaboration in both digital and physical environments.
Explain how technology, society and the individual impact one another.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Addresses the nature of technology to develop and improve products and systems over time to meet human/societal needs and wants through design processes.

expectations.expectationDescription: Define and describe technology, including its core concepts of systems, resources, requirements, processes, controls, optimization and trade-offs.
Identify a problem and use an engineering design process to solve the problem.
Demonstrate that solutions to complex problems require collaboration, interdisciplinary understanding and systems thinking.
Evaluate designs using functional, aesthetic and creative elements.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Objectives related to computing systems including device operation, hardware, software, and troubleshooting.

expectations.expectationDescription: Operate commonly used devices and their components to perform a variety of tasks.
With guidance, describe and use hardware and software necessary for accomplishing a task.
With guidance, use problem-solving strategies to troubleshoot a problem.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Objectives focusing on networking, cybersecurity, and the Internet of Things.

expectations.expectationDescription: Create a list of ways information can be shared electronically to gain a deeper understanding of how information is transmitted (e.g., email, social media).
Recognize that computing devices can be connected to retrieve information from the global community.
Identify and use secure practices (e.g., passwords) to protect private information.
Identify, use and discuss examples of how devices can be used with good and bad intentions.
Identify what smart devices are and how they connect to the internet.
Recognize how devices connect and exchange data over the internet to demonstrate how information is shared.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Objectives that cover data collection, storage, visualization, communication, inference, and modeling.

expectations.expectationDescription: With guidance, collect and organize data to retrieve for later use.
With guidance, demonstrate how data can be collected and stored in a variety of ways.
Organize and present data in various formats to make observations.
Create and explain a model of an object or process that includes patterns and key elements.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Objectives related to algorithm creation, variables, data representation, control structures, modularity, and program development.

expectations.expectationDescription: With guidance, model a real-world process by constructing and following step-by-step directions (i.e., algorithms) to complete tasks.
Categorize a group of items (e.g., numbers, symbols or pictures) based on the attributes or actions of each item, with or without a computing device.
With guidance, model a sequence of instructions (i.e., program) that includes repetition (i.e., loops) to solve a problem or express ideas.
With guidance, break down (i.e., decompose) a series of steps and separate the necessary from the unnecessary steps to create a precise sequence of instructions to solve a problem or express an idea.
With guidance, plan and create an artifact to illustrate thoughts, ideas and problems in a sequential (step-by-step) manner (e.g., story map, storyboard, sequential graphic organizer).
With guidance, identify and fix (i.e., debug) a multi-step process that includes sequencing.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Objectives encompassing aspects of AI such as perception, representation, reasoning, machine learning, natural interactions, and societal impacts.

expectations.expectationDescription: With guidance and support, recognize sensors on computers, robots and intelligent appliances to understand their function, such as motion, pressure/touch, temperature, proximity, light, sound, moisture or gases.
With guidance and support, use intelligent agents to help answer simple questions.
Use a decision tree to make a decision.
With guidance and support, discuss how a classifier recognizes drawings to gain an understanding of how machine learning works.
Using recognition software, identify attributes that computers use for identification to explain how computers recognize humans.
Identify AI applications that are used in daily lives to predict AI use in the future.
Discuss if computers and other technology are good or bad to create a working construct.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Objectives exploring the cultural, social, and ethical impacts of computing.

expectations.expectationDescription: Discuss different technologies and their impact on everyday life.
Identify how people use and are impacted by many types of technologies in their daily work and personal lives.
With guidance, describe safe and responsible behaviors for the use of information and technology.
With guidance, discuss appropriate and ethical uses of technology to guide informed decisions.
Discuss examples of appropriate and inappropriate behavior online, including cyberbullying, and the steps to keep yourself and others safe and out of harm's way.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Represent and solve problems involving addition and subtraction.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use addition and subtraction within 20 to solve word problems involving situations of adding to, taking from, putting together, taking apart and comparing, with unknowns in all positions, e.g., by using objects, drawings, and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.

Solve word problems that call for addition of three whole numbers whose sum is less than or equal to 20, e.g., by using objects, drawings, and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.
Apply properties of operations as strategies to add and subtract, e.g., using Commutative and Associative Properties of Addition.
Understand subtraction as an unknown-addend problem.
Relate counting to addition and subtraction, e.g., by counting on to add 2.
Add and subtract within 20, demonstrating fluency with various strategies for addition and subtraction within 10.
Understand the meaning of the equal sign, and determine if equations involving addition and subtraction are true or false.
Determine the unknown whole number in an addition or subtraction equation relating three whole numbers.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Number and Operations in Base Ten
objectives.objectiveDescription: Extend the counting sequence and understand place value.

expectations.expectationDescription: Count to 120, starting at any number less than 120.
Understand that the two digits of a two-digit number represent amounts of tens and ones.
Compare two two-digit numbers based on meanings of the tens and ones digits.
Add within 100, including adding a two-digit number and a multiple of 10, using strategies based on place value.
Mentally find 10 more or 10 less than a two-digit number, without having to count.
Subtract multiples of 10 in the range 10-90 from multiples of 10 in the range 10-90.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Measure lengths and work with time and money.

expectations.expectationDescription: Order three objects by length; compare the lengths of two objects indirectly by using a third object.
Express the length of an object as a whole number of length units by laying multiple copies of a shorter object end to end.
Tell and write time in hours and half-hours using analog and digital clocks; identify pennies and dimes by name and value.
Organize, represent, and interpret data with up to three categories.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

expectations.expectationDescription: Distinguish between defining attributes of shapes, such as being closed and three-sided.
Compose two-dimensional and three-dimensional shapes to create a composite shape.
Partition circles and rectangles into two and four equal shares, describing the shares using terms like halves and quarters.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will explore the properties of air and wind

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will identify observable and measurable properties of air.
Students will explain that the transfer of energy in the atmosphere causes air movement, which is felt as wind. They will identify that wind speed and direction can be measured.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will understand the presence of water in the atmosphere

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will explain that water exists in the atmosphere as water vapor.
Students will describe how clouds, fog, rain, ice, snow, sleet, or hail form when water vapor in the atmosphere cools.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will explore how energy changes affect weather

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will recognize that changes in energy affect various aspects of weather, including temperature, precipitation, and wind.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will investigate how forces change the motion of objects

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will explain that the motion of an object can increase, change direction, or stop depending on the applied force.
Students will identify that the change in motion of an object is related to the size of the force.
Students will recognize that some forces, like magnetism and gravity, can act without touching the object.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will understand how living things cause changes on Earth

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will explain that living things interact with and function within their physical environments. They will recognize that living things can cause noticeable or subtle, fast or slow changes in their environment.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will explore the concept of extinction

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will understand that some organisms become extinct when their basic needs are no longer met or the environment changes.

sections.sectionDescription: Identify observable and measurable properties of air.
Explain that the transfer of energy in the atmosphere causes air movement, which is felt as wind. Identify that wind speed and direction can be measured.
Explain that water exists in the atmosphere as water vapor.
Describe how clouds, fog, rain, ice, snow, sleet, or hail form when water vapor in the atmosphere cools.
Recognize that changes in energy affect various aspects of weather, including temperature, precipitation, and wind.
Explain that the motion of an object can increase, change direction, or stop depending on the applied force.

sections.sectionTitle: Impact of Force Size on Motion
sections.sectionDescription: Identify that the change in motion of an object is related to the size of the force.
Recognize that some forces, like magnetism and gravity, can act without touching the object.
Explain that living things interact with and function within their physical environments. Recognize that living things can cause noticeable or subtle, fast or slow changes in their environment.
Understand that some organisms become extinct when their basic needs are no longer met or the environment changes.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Learn about various computing devices, their hardware and software components, and troubleshooting techniques.

expectations.expectationDescription: Select and operate commonly used devices to perform a variety of tasks.
Select and use hardware and software necessary for accomplishing a task.
Use problem-solving strategies to troubleshoot a problem.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Explore networking, cybersecurity, and the Internet of Things (IoT) to understand digital communication and data exchange.

expectations.expectationDescription: Describe how information can be communicated electronically to gain a deeper understanding of how information is transmitted (e.g., email, social media).
Use computing devices that are connected to share and receive information from the global community.
Explain and demonstrate secure practices (e.g., creating strong passwords) to protect private information.
Identify and discuss examples of how devices can be used with good and bad intentions.
With guidance and support, explain how devices connect and exchange data over different environments to explore how information is shared.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Focus on data collection, storage, visualization, communication, and analysis to understand and manipulate data.

expectations.expectationDescription: Collect and organize data to store, retrieve and modify.
Manipulate data to perform various tasks.
Organize, analyze and present data in various formats.
Interpret and analyze data, graphs, models or charts.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Learn about algorithms, program development, and other computational concepts to solve problems and express ideas.

expectations.expectationDescription: Model a real-world process by constructing and following step-by-step instructions (i.e., algorithms) to complete tasks.
Construct a model that shows the way programs store and manipulate data by using numbers or other symbols to represent information.
Develop a program that uses sequencing and repetition (i.e., loops) to solve a problem or express ideas.
Break down (i.e., decompose) a series of steps and separate the necessary from the unnecessary steps to create a precise sequence of instructions to solve a problem or express an idea.
Plan and create an artifact to illustrate thoughts, ideas and problems in a sequential (step-by-step) manner (e.g., story map, storyboard, sequential graphic organizer).
Identify and fix (i.e., debug) a multi-step process that includes sequencing.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Explore basic concepts of AI, including perception, machine learning, and societal impacts, to understand how AI influences various fields.

expectations.expectationDescription: Tell where sensors are on computers, robots and intelligent appliances to relate their location with their function such as motion, pressure/touch, temperature, proximity, light, sound, moisture or gases.
Apply the use of intelligent agents to assist in basic research (look up answers to specific questions).
With guidance and support, create a simple decision tree (conditionals) to create a pathway for decisions.
Use a classifier that recognizes drawings and discuss how the program knows what they are drawing.
List possible attributions computers can use to distinguish humans from each other by comparing these attributions.
To determine how AI can help in daily life, group applications used into two categories: 'AI' and 'Not AI.'
Discuss AI and how it can be used for good or bad to discuss the ethical use of AI.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Study the effects of computing on culture, social interactions, and ethical issues to foster informed and responsible use of technology.

expectations.expectationDescription: Compare and contrast how the use of technology has changed to understand its impact on everyday life.
Describe the ways people use technologies in their daily work and personal lives to understand technology's impact on one's community.
Compare and contrast safe and responsible behaviors to those that are not when using information and technology.
Discuss appropriate and ethical uses of technology to guide informed decisions.
Compare and contrast appropriate and inappropriate behavior online, including cyberbullying, and the steps to keep yourself and others safe and out of harm's way.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Engage in observation, listening, and attending to details in artworks.

expectations.expectationDescription: Notice and point out details and respond to expressive features in artworks.
Distinguish the subject matter and artistic style of two or more visual artists.
Compare the form, materials and techniques in selected works of art using descriptive language.
Identify and compare the purposes for creating art objects from various cultures.
Identify and describe cultural symbols, image and contexts of works of art.
Identify and share the uses of visual art outside the classroom and provide examples.
Generate artmaking ideas from their daily experiences and the environment.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Focus on creation and realization of artworks using diverse artistic skills.

expectations.expectationDescription: Demonstrate increasing skill and craft in the use of art tools and materials with attention to their diverse qualities.

Create artworks based on imagination and observation of familiar objects and scenes.
Demonstrate flexibility in their creative processes and use of art materials.
Identify, select and use art and design elements and principles to express emotions and produce a variety of visual effects (e.g., nuances of surface, contour, pattern and tone).
Use visual art materials to express an idea that reflects their own social or cultural identity.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Engage in making connections, reconsidering, questioning, and self-assessing in relation to art.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use basic self-assessment strategies to improve their artworks.

Share their personal interpretations of the meanings conveyed in various works of art.
Describe how an artist uses the elements and principles of design to create expressive impact in a work of art.
Identify and articulate important historical and cultural contributions of selected visual artists.
Recognize and discuss that people have various opinions about art and value art for different reasons.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Represent and solve problems involving addition and subtraction.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use addition and subtraction within 100 to solve one- and two-step word problems involving situations of adding to, taking from, putting together, taking apart, and comparing, with unknowns in all positions, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.
Fluently add and subtract within 20 using mental strategies. By end of Grade 2, know from memory all sums of two one-digit numbers.

Determine whether a group of objects (up to 20) has an odd or even number of members, e.g., by pairing objects or counting them by 2s; write an equation to express an even number as a sum of two equal addends.
Use addition to find the total number of objects arranged in rectangular arrays with up to 5 rows and up to 5 columns; write an equation to express the total as a sum of equal addends.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Number and Operations in Base Ten
objectives.objectiveDescription: Understand and use place value and properties of operations to add and subtract.

expectations.expectationDescription: Understand that the three digits of a three-digit number represent amounts of hundreds, tens, and ones; e.g., 706 equals 7 hundreds, 0 tens, and 6 ones.
Count forward and backward within 1,000 by ones, tens, and hundreds starting at any number; skip-count by 5s starting at any multiple of 5.
Read and write numbers to 1,000 using base-ten numerals, number names, expanded form, and equivalent representations.
Compare two three-digit numbers based on meanings of the hundreds, tens, and ones digits, using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.
Fluently add and subtract within 100 using strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction.
Add up to four two-digit numbers using strategies based on place value and properties of operations.

Add and subtract within 1,000, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; record the strategy with a written numerical method and explain the reasoning used.
Mentally add 10 or 100 to a given number 100-900, and mentally subtract 10 or 100 from a given number 100-900.
Explain why addition and subtraction strategies work, using place value and the properties of operations.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Measure and estimate lengths in standard units. Relate addition and subtraction to length. Work with time and money. Represent and interpret data.

expectations.expectationDescription: Measure the length of an object by selecting and using appropriate tools such as rulers, yardsticks, meter sticks, and measuring tapes.
Measure the length of an object twice, using length units of different lengths for the two measurements; describe how the two measurements relate to the size of the unit chosen.
Estimate lengths using units of inches, feet, centimeters, and meters.
Measure to determine how much longer one object is than another, expressing the length difference in terms of a standard length unit.
Use addition and subtraction within 100 to solve word problems involving lengths that are given in the same whole number units.

Represent whole numbers as lengths from 0 on a number line diagram with equally spaced points corresponding to the numbers 0, 1, 2,..., and represent whole number sums and differences within 100 on a number line diagram.
Tell and write time from analog and digital clocks to the nearest five minutes, using a.m. and p.m.
Solve problems with money, including identifying nickels and quarters by name and value, finding the value of a collection of coins, and solving word problems by adding and subtracting within 100.

Generate measurement data by measuring lengths of several objects to the nearest whole unit or by making repeated measurements of the same object. Show the measurements by creating a line plot, where the horizontal scale is marked off in whole number units.

Organize, represent, and interpret data with up to four categories; complete picture graphs and bar graphs when single-unit scales are provided; solve simple put-together, take-apart, and compare problems in a graph.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

expectations.expectationDescription: Recognize and identify triangles, quadrilaterals, pentagons, and hexagons based on the number of sides or vertices. Recognize and identify cubes, rectangular prisms, cones, and cylinders.
Partition a rectangle into rows and columns of same-size squares and count to find the total number of them.

Partition circles and rectangles into two, three, or four equal shares; describe the shares using the words halves, thirds, or fourths and quarters, and use the phrases half of, third of, or fourth of and quarter of. Describe the whole as two halves, three thirds, or four fourths in real-world contexts. Recognize that equal shares of identical wholes need not have the same shape.

sections.sectionDescription: Use addition and subtraction within 100 to solve one- and two-step word problems involving situations of adding to, taking from, putting together, taking apart, and comparing.
Fluently add and subtract within 20 using mental strategies.
Determine whether a group of objects (up to 20) has an odd or even number of members.
Use addition to find the total number of objects arranged in rectangular arrays with up to 5 rows and up to 5 columns.
Understand that the three digits of a three-digit number represent amounts of hundreds, tens, and ones.

Add up to four two-digit numbers using strategies based on place value and properties of operations.

Explain why addition and subtraction strategies work, using place value and the properties of operations.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will explore the properties of Earth's nonliving resources

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will explain that soil is composed of pieces of rock, organic material, water, and air. They will identify measurable and observable characteristics of soil.
Students will differentiate between dirt and soil.
Students will identify that rocks have specific characteristics that allow them to be sorted and compared. They will understand that rocks form in different ways.
Students will recognize that air and water are also nonliving resources.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will understand the difference between renewable and nonrenewable energy resources

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will explain that renewable energy resources, such as wind, water, or solar energy, can be replenished within a short amount of time by natural processes.
Students will identify that nonrenewable energy is a finite resource, such as natural gas, coal, or oil, which cannot be replenished in a short amount of time.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will explore the concept of limited resources

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will explain that some of Earth's resources become limited due to overuse and/or contamination.
Students will identify ways to conserve resources, such as reducing resource use, decreasing waste and pollution, recycling, and reusing.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will understand the concept of matter

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will explain that matter takes up space and has mass.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will explore the different states of matter

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will identify the most recognizable states of matter: solids, liquids, and gases.
Students will explain that shape and compressibility are properties that can distinguish between the states of matter.
Students will understand that one way to change matter from one state to another is by heating or cooling.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will be introduced to different forms of energy

expectations.expectationDescription: Students will recognize that there are many different forms of energy, including heat, electrical energy, light, sound, and magnetic energy.
Students will understand that energy is the ability to cause motion or create change.
Students will identify that the forms of energy outlined at this grade level should be limited to familiar forms they can observe.

Differentiate between dirt and soil.
Identify that rocks have specific characteristics that allow them to be sorted and compared. Understand that rocks form in different ways.

outline.title: Air and Water as Nonliving Resources

sections.sectionDescription: Recognize that air and water are also nonliving resources.

Identify that nonrenewable energy is a finite resource, such as natural gas, coal, or oil, which cannot be replenished in a short amount of time.

Identify ways to conserve resources, such as reducing resource use, decreasing waste and pollution, recycling, and reusing.

Understand that one way to change matter from one state to another is by heating or cooling.
Recognize that there are many different forms of energy, including heat, electrical energy, light, sound, and magnetic energy.
Understand that energy is the ability to cause motion or create change.
Identify that the forms of energy outlined at this grade level should be limited to familiar forms they can observe.

sections.sectionDescription: Review the differences between renewable and nonrenewable energy resources.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Identify and use appropriate digital learning tools and resources to accomplish a defined task.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will learn how to select and utilize digital tools to plan, implement, and reflect upon a defined task.

expectations.expectationDescription: With guidance, identify and use digital learning tools or resources to support planning, implementing and reflecting upon a defined task.
Explain the use of selected digital learning tools and resources to support productivity and learning.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Use digital learning tools and resources to locate, evaluate and use information.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will develop skills in information literacy by using digital tools to locate, evaluate, and use information effectively.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify questions related to a topic of interest to broaden or narrow the topic as needed.
Use appropriate search techniques to locate needed information using digital learning tools and resources.
Use multiple criteria developed with guidance to differentiate between relevant and irrelevant information found with digital learning tools and resources.
Explain basic ideas of plagiarism and copyright.
Use digital citation tools to cite sources with appropriate guidance.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Use digital learning tools and resources to construct knowledge.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will learn to synthesize and create new knowledge by utilizing various digital resources.

expectations.expectationDescription: Gather, organize and summarize information from multiple digital learning tools and resources to build knowledge of a topic.
Interpret images, diagrams, maps, graphs, infographics, videos, animations, interactives, etc., in digital learning tools and resources to clarify and add to knowledge.
Organize observations and data collected during student explorations to determine if patterns are present.
Create artifacts using digital learning tools and resources to demonstrate knowledge.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Use digital learning tools and resources to communicate and disseminate information to multiple audiences.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will utilize digital tools to effectively communicate and share information with diverse audiences.

expectations.expectationDescription: With guidance, discuss and identify communication needs considering goals, audience and content.
With guidance, select media formats appropriate to content and audience.
Evaluate the features of digital learning tools and resources based on the characteristics of a specific audience.
Produce and publish information appropriate for a target audience using digital learning tools and resources.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Demonstrate an understanding of technologyâ€™s impact on the advancement of humanity â€“ economically, environmentally and ethically.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will explore how technology influences and shapes various aspects of society, including ethical considerations and community impacts.

expectations.expectationDescription: Demonstrate appropriate use of technology and explain the importance of responsible and ethical technology use.
Identify positive and negative impacts oneâ€™s use of personal technology and technology systems (e.g., agriculture, transportation, energy generation, water treatment) can have on oneâ€™s community.
Describe legal and responsible practices when utilizing technology.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Analyze the impact of communication and collaboration in both digital and physical environments.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will understand the dynamics of digital and physical interactions and their implications for effective collaboration.

expectations.expectationDescription: Create a plan and select collaboration and/or communication tools to complete a given task.
Exercise digital etiquette when communicating and collaborating.
Identify the positive and negative impact the use of technology can have on relationships, communities and self.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Explain how technology, society and the individual impact one another.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will explore the interrelationship between technology, society, and individual identity, considering both historical and future perspectives.

expectations.expectationDescription: Describe the advantages and disadvantages of technology (past, present, future) to understand the relationship between technology, society and the individual.
Demonstrate how technology innovations/inventions can have multiple applications.
Identify and discuss how the use of technology affects self and others in various ways.
Identify the components of oneâ€™s digital identity and oneâ€™s digital footprint.
Identify and discuss laws and rules that apply to digital content and information.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Define and describe technology, including its core concepts of systems, resources, requirements, processes, controls, optimization and trade-offs.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will gain a foundational understanding of technology and its various aspects, which are crucial to understanding how technological systems function.

expectations.expectationDescription: Demonstrate how applying human knowledge using tools and machines extends human capabilities to meet our needs and wants.
Give examples of how requirements for a product can limit the design possibilities for that product.
Describe a process as a series of actions and how it is used to produce a result.
Identify and describe examples of technology products and processes.
Explain how controls use information to cause systems to change, like a home thermostat turning on the heat based on the low temperature of a room.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Identify a problem and use an engineering design process to solve the problem.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will engage in the engineering design process to identify and solve problems, critically thinking about potential solutions and their implementation.

expectations.expectationDescription: Critique needs and opportunities for designing solutions.

Plan and implement a design process: identify a problem, think about ways to solve the problem, develop possible solutions, test and evaluate solution(s), present a possible solution, and redesign to improve the solution.
Generate, develop and communicate design ideas and decisions using appropriate terms and graphical representations.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Demonstrate that solutions to complex problems require collaboration, interdisciplinary understanding and systems thinking.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will learn the value of collaborative and interdisciplinary approaches to solving complex problems, emphasizing systems thinking.

expectations.expectationDescription: Design a product with multiple components and describe how the components interact to form a system.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Evaluate designs using functional, aesthetic and creative elements.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will apply criteria to evaluate technological products, considering both functional and aesthetic aspects to appreciate the creative elements involved.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use criteria developed with guidance to evaluate a new or improved product for its functional, aesthetic and creative elements.
Examine a familiar product or process and suggest improvements to its design.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Understanding how networks and the internet function, including the basics of cybersecurity and the Internet of Things.

expectations.expectationDescription: Describe how communication occurs when information is sent and received over physical or wireless paths to explain communication systems.

Create a chart or graph to inform a target audience about observations and data collected.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Understanding the principles of algorithmic thinking and the fundamentals of programming.

expectations.expectationDescription: Construct and reflect on errors in an algorithm to accomplish a given task.
Define and identify a variable, a placeholder for storing a value, to understand how it is used in a multi-step process (i.e., algorithm).
Create a program using sequences, events, loops and conditionals to solve a problem.
Decompose (i.e., break down) the steps needed or not needed (i.e., abstraction) into precise sequences of instructions to design an algorithm.
Use a design process to plan the development of a program that solves problems.
Using a given program known to contain errors, identify and debug errors to ensure it works.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use different sensors, analog and digital, and discuss the difference between them.

Give examples of bias to understand what it is and how it affects machine learning.

Locate AI systems that are designed to help everyone have equal access.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Represent and solve problems involving multiplication and division.

expectations.expectationDescription: Interpret products of whole numbers, e.g., interpret 5 x 7 as the total number of objects in 5 groups of 7 objects each. (Note: These standards are written with the convention that a x b means a groups of b objects each; however, because of the commutative property, students may also interpret 5 x 7 as the total number of objects in 7 groups of 5 objects each).

Interpret whole number quotients of whole numbers, e.g., interpret 56 Ã· 8 as the number of objects in each share when 56 objects are partitioned equally into 8 shares, or as a number of shares when 56 objects are partitioned into equal shares of 8 objects each. For example, describe a context in which a number of shares or a number of groups can be expressed as 56 Ã· 8.

Use multiplication and division within 100 to solve word problems in situations involving equal groups, arrays, and measurement quantities, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem. See Table 2, page 18. Drawings need not show details, but should show the mathematics in the problem. (This applies wherever drawings are mentioned in the Standards).

Determine the unknown whole number in a multiplication or division equation relating three whole numbers. For example, determine the unknown number that makes the equation true in each of the equations 8 Ã— = 48; 5 = Ã· 3; 6 Ã— 6 = .

Apply properties of operations as strategies to multiply and divide. For example, if 6 Ã— 4 = 24 is known, then 4 Ã— 6 = 24 is also known (Commutative Property of Multiplication); 3 Ã— 5 Ã— 2 can be found by 3 Ã— 5 = 15, then 15 Ã— 2 = 30, or by 5 Ã— 2 = 10, then 3 Ã— 10 = 30 (Associative Property of Multiplication); knowing that 8 Ã— 5 = 40 and 8 Ã— 2 = 16, one can find 8 Ã— 7 as 8 Ã— (5 + 2) = (8 Ã— 5) + (8 Ã— 2) = 40 + 16 = 56 (Distributive Property). Students need not use formal terms for these properties.
Understand division as an unknown-factor problem. For example, find 32 Ã· 8 by finding the number that makes 32 when multiplied by 8.

Fluently multiply and divide within 100, using strategies such as the relationship between multiplication and division, e.g., knowing that 8 Ã— 5 = 40, one knows 40 Ã· 5 = 8, or properties of operations. Limit to division without remainders. By the end of Grade 3, know from memory all products of two one-digit numbers.

Solve two-step word problems using the four operations. Represent these problems using equations with a letter or a symbol, which stands for the unknown quantity. Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies including rounding. This standard is limited to problems posed with whole numbers and having whole number answers. Students may use parentheses for clarification since algebraic order of operations is not expected.

Identify arithmetic patterns (including patterns in the addition table or multiplication table), and explain them using properties of operations. For example, observe that 4 times a number is always even, and explain why 4 times a number can be decomposed into two equal addends.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Number and Operations in Base Ten
objectives.objectiveDescription: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic. A range of strategies and algorithms may be used.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use place value understanding to round whole numbers to the nearest 10 or 100.
Fluently add and subtract within 1,000 using strategies and algorithms based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction.
Multiply one-digit whole numbers by multiples of 10 in the range 10-90, e.g., 9 Ã— 80, 5 Ã— 60 using strategies based on place value and properties of operations.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Develop understanding of fractions as numbers. Grade 3 expectations in this domain are limited to fractions with denominators 2, 3, 4, 6, and 8.

expectations.expectationDescription: Understand a fraction 1/b as the quantity formed by 1 part when a whole is partitioned into b equal parts; understand a fraction a/b as the quantity formed by a parts of size 1/b.
Understand a fraction as a number on the number line; represent fractions on a number line diagram.
Explain equivalence of fractions in special cases, and compare fractions by reasoning about their size.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Solve problems involving money, measurement, and estimation of intervals of time, liquid volumes, and masses of objects.

expectations.expectationDescription: Work with time and money.
Measure and estimate liquid volumes and masses of objects using standard units of grams, kilograms, and liters.

Create scaled picture graphs to represent a data set with several categories. Create scaled bar graphs to represent a data set with several categories. Solve two-step â€œhow many moreâ€ and â€œhow many lessâ€ problems using information presented in the scaled graphs.

Generate measurement data by measuring lengths using rulers marked with halves and fourths of an inch. Show the data by creating a line plot, where the horizontal scale is marked off in appropriate unitsâ€”whole numbers, halves, or quarters.
Recognize area as an attribute of plane figures and understand concepts of area measurement.

Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving perimeters of polygons, including finding the perimeter given the side lengths, finding an unknown side length, and exhibiting rectangles with the same perimeter and different areas or with the same area and different perimeters.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

expectations.expectationDescription: Draw and describe triangles, quadrilaterals (rhombuses, rectangles, and squares), and polygons (up to 8 sides) based on the number of sides and the presence or absence of square corners (right angles).
Partition shapes into parts with equal areas. Express the area of each part as a unit fraction of the whole.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Earthâ€™s surface has specific characteristics and landforms that can be identified.

expectations.expectationDescription: About 70 percent of the Earthâ€™s surface is covered with water and most of that is the ocean. Only a small portion of the Earthâ€™s water is freshwater, which is found in rivers, lakes, groundwater and glaciers.
Earthâ€™s surface can change due to erosion and deposition of soil, rock or sediment.
Catastrophic events such as flooding, volcanoes and earthquakes can create landforms.

objectives.objectiveDescription: The surface of Earth changes due to weathering.

expectations.expectationDescription: Rocks change shape, size and/or form due to water or glacial movement, freeze and thaw, wind, plant growth, acid rain, pollution and catastrophic events such as earthquakes, flooding, and volcanic activity.

objectives.objectiveDescription: The surface of Earth changes due to erosion and deposition.

expectations.expectationDescription: Liquid water, wind and ice physically remove and carry rock, soil and sediment (erosion) and deposit the material in a new location (deposition).
Gravitational force affects movements of water, rock and soil.

objectives.objectiveDescription: When objects break into smaller pieces, dissolve, or change state, the total amount of matter is conserved.

expectations.expectationDescription: When an object is broken into smaller pieces, when a solid is dissolved in a liquid or when matter changes state (solid, liquid, gas), the total amount of matter remains constant.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Energy can be transferred from one location to another or can be transformed from one form to another.

expectations.expectationDescription: Energy transfers from hot objects to cold objects as heat, resulting in a temperature change.
Electric circuits require a complete loop of conducting materials through which electrical energy can be transferred.
Electrical energy in circuits can be transformed to other forms of energy, including light, heat, sound and motion. Electricity and magnetism are closely related.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Changes in an organismâ€™s environment are sometimes beneficial to its survival and sometimes harmful.

expectations.expectationDescription: Ecosystems can change gradually or dramatically. When the environment changes, some plants and animals survive and reproduce and others die or move to new locations.

Ecosystems are based on interrelationships among and between biotic and abiotic factors. These include the diversity of other organisms present, the availability of food and other resources, and the physical attributes of the environment.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Fossils can be compared to one another and to present-day organisms according to their similarities and differences.

expectations.expectationDescription: The concept of biodiversity is expanded to include different classification schemes based upon shared internal and external characteristics of organisms.
Most species that have lived on Earth are extinct.
Fossils provide a point of comparison between the types of organisms that lived long ago and those existing today.

Catastrophic events such as flooding, volcanoes and earthquakes can create landforms.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Identify a problem and use an engineering design process to solve the problem.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will engage in the engineering design process to identify and solve problems, critically thinking about potential solutions and their implementation.

expectations.expectationDescription: Critique needs and opportunities for designing solutions.

Plan and implement a design process: identify a problem, think about ways to solve the problem, develop possible solutions, test and evaluate solution(s), present a possible solution, and redesign to improve the solution.
Generate, develop and communicate design ideas and decisions using appropriate terms and graphical representations.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Demonstrate that solutions to complex problems require collaboration, interdisciplinary understanding and systems thinking.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will learn the value of collaborative and interdisciplinary approaches to solving complex problems, emphasizing systems thinking.

expectations.expectationDescription: Design a product with multiple components and describe how the components interact to form a system.
Explore and document connections between technology and other fields of study.
Identify a product and describe how people from different disciplines combined their skills in the design and production of the product.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Evaluate designs using functional, aesthetic and creative elements.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will apply criteria to evaluate technological products, considering both functional and aesthetic aspects to appreciate the creative elements involved.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use criteria developed with guidance to evaluate a new or improved product for its functional, aesthetic and creative elements.
Examine a familiar product or process and suggest improvements to its design.

sections.sectionDescription: With guidance, identify and use digital learning tools or resources to support planning, implementing and reflecting upon a defined task.
Explain the use of selected digital learning tools and resources to support productivity and learning.
Identify questions related to a topic of interest to broaden or narrow the topic as needed.
Use appropriate search techniques to locate needed information using digital learning tools and resources.
Use multiple criteria developed with guidance to differentiate between relevant and irrelevant information found with digital learning tools and resources.
Explain basic ideas of plagiarism and copyright.
Use digital citation tools to cite sources with appropriate guidance.
Gather, organize and summarize information from multiple digital learning tools and resources to build knowledge of a topic.
Interpret images, diagrams, maps, graphs, infographics, videos, animations, interactives, etc., in digital learning tools and resources to clarify and add to knowledge.
Organize observations and data collected during student explorations to determine if patterns are present.
Create artifacts using digital learning tools and resources to demonstrate knowledge.
With guidance, discuss and identify communication needs considering goals, audience and content.
With guidance, select media formats appropriate to content and audience.
Evaluate the features of digital learning tools and resources based on the characteristics of a specific audience.
Produce and publish information appropriate for a target audience using digital learning tools and resources.
Demonstrate appropriate use of technology and explain the importance of responsible and ethical technology use.
Identify positive and negative impacts oneâ€™s use of personal technology and technology systems (e.g., agriculture, transportation, energy generation, water treatment) can have on oneâ€™s community.
Describe legal and responsible practices when utilizing technology.
Create a plan and select collaboration and/or communication tools to complete a given task.
Exercise digital etiquette when communicating and collaborating.
Identify the positive and negative impact the use of technology can have on relationships, communities and self.
Describe the advantages and disadvantages of technology (past, present, future) to understand the relationship between technology, society and the individual.
Demonstrate how technology innovations/inventions can have multiple applications.
Identify and discuss how the use of technology affects self and others in various ways.
Identify the components of oneâ€™s digital identity and oneâ€™s digital footprint.
Identify and discuss laws and rules that apply to digital content and information.
Demonstrate how applying human knowledge using tools and machines extends human capabilities to meet our needs and wants.
Give examples of how requirements for a product can limit the design possibilities for that product.
Describe a process as a series of actions and how it is used to produce a result.
Identify and describe examples of technology products and processes.
Explain how controls use information to cause systems to change, like a home thermostat turning on the heat based on the low temperature of a room.
Critique needs and opportunities for designing solutions.

Plan and implement a design process: identify a problem, think about ways to solve the problem, develop possible solutions, test and evaluate solution(s), present a possible solution, and redesign to improve the solution.
Generate, develop and communicate design ideas and decisions using appropriate terms and graphical representations.
Use criteria developed with guidance to evaluate a new or improved product for its functional, aesthetic and creative elements.
Examine a familiar product or process and suggest improvements to its design.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Understanding the components and troubleshooting of computing systems.

expectations.expectationDescription: Explore external components of a computing system and their function to understand and describe the role they play in a computer system.
Select and use digital learning tools/devices to support planning, implementing and reflecting upon a defined task.
Diagnose problems and select an appropriate solution from a list of problems and solutions to resolve hardware and software issues.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Learning about networking, cybersecurity, and the Internet of Things.

expectations.expectationDescription: Describe how information is broken down to be transmitted over a network to help students gain a better understanding of the internet and networks.
Describe network addresses, names and rules (i.e., protocols) to share or receive information from the global community.
Describe what information should be protected and the importance of a secure password to protect information.
Describe and explain safe usage of various online services such as web, email, video, gaming, cloud services and networked drives.
Explore how information is transferred to the internet from smart and intelligent devices to recognize how the internet and networks operate.
Describe how transferred information is tagged using identifiers to transmit information about the user so students begin to learn that no information on the internet is anonymous.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Understanding data collection, visualization, and inference.

expectations.expectationDescription: Gather and organize multiple quantitative data elements using a tool to perform various tasks.
Identify techniques and formats to store, process and retrieve different types of information.
Organize data into subsets to provide different views or commonalities and present insights gained using visual or other types of representations.
Utilize data to make predictions and discuss whether there is adequate data to make reliable predictions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Exploring algorithms, variables, control structures, and program development.

expectations.expectationDescription: Construct and refine an algorithm to accomplish a given task.
Identify and use a variable, a placeholder for storing a value, to understand how it works in a multi-step process.
Create a program using sequences, events, loops, and conditionals to solve a problem.
Decompose the steps needed or not needed into precise sequences of instructions to design an algorithm.
Use a design process to plan and develop a program that addresses a multi-step problem.
Using guided questions, work through a program to identify errors and discuss possible solutions to repair the program.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Understanding AI's role in perception, reasoning, machine learning, and societal impacts.

expectations.expectationDescription: Describe the difference between analog and digital signals to understand their uses.
Give examples of computer perception to understand how it is affected by the environment.
Create a classification system using a tree structure to understand binary solutions.
Describe how AI represents knowledge to make a reasonable answer.
Explain three different machine learning approaches to choose which may be best for a given situation.
Explain how machine learning can create a bias to understand how computers can be biased.
Describe tasks where AI outperforms human tasks and when it does not to describe how humans rely on AI.
Use AI systems that are designed to be inclusive and describe how they affect the humans who use them.
Give examples of bias to demonstrate how it can affect decision-making.
Give examples of bias to demonstrate how it can affect specific groups of people.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Explore how computing technologies impact various aspects of life including culture, social interactions, safety, law, and ethics.

expectations.expectationDescription: List examples of computing technologies that have changed the global community to express how those technologies influenced and are influenced by cultural practice.
Identify and anticipate diverse user needs to increase accessibility to all users.
Collaborate and consider diverse perspectives to improve digital artifacts.
Use public domain or Creative Commons media, and refrain from copying or using material created by others without permission.
Explain why information should be shared or kept private to protect student identity.
Communicate the importance of protecting your digital footprint.
Describe tradeoffs between allowing information to be public and keeping information private and secure.
Explain the effect of cyber bullying and who to tell if this is happening.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Observe, listen, attend to, discriminate

expectations.expectationDescription: Use sensory details and descriptive language to identify and describe universal themes, subject matter and ideas expressed across arts disciplines.
Notice and describe different visual effects resulting from artmaking techniques.
Compare and contrast art forms, techniques and functions and artistic styles from a variety of cultures and historical periods.
Identify and describe how artists from various cultural and ethnic groups have impacted Ohioâ€™s history.
Link ideas in and design of works of art to the emotions and moods expressed in them.
Identify and name the sources for artmaking ideas (e.g., self, environment and other people).

objectives.objectiveDescription: Generate, create, realize, use & master skills

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify, select and vary art materials, tools and processes to achieve desired results in their artwork.
Experiment with art materials by using them in unexpected and creative ways to express ideas and convey meaning.
Generate ideas and employ a variety of strategies to solve visual problems.
Demonstrate motivation, independence and persistence during studio practices to complete artworks.
Combine the elements and principles of art and design to create visually effective compositions in original works of art.
Demonstrate technical skill through the integration of common processes and topics from other subject areas.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Make connections, reconsider, question, self-assess

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify qualities that contribute to the design and meaning of their artworks and the works of others.
Develop and share their ideas, beliefs and values about art.
Recognize and describe the relationship of artworks to their social and cultural contexts.
Generate criteria for discussing and assessing works of art.
Refer to criteria and use art vocabulary when discussing and judging the quality of artworks.
Give and use constructive feedback to produce artworks that achieve learning goals.
