objectives.objectiveDescription: Use the four operations with whole numbers to solve problems.

expectations.expectationDescription: Interpret a multiplication equation as a comparison, e.g., interpret 35 = 5 Ã— 7 as a statement that 35 is 5 times as many as 7 and 7 times as many as 5. Represent verbal statements of multiplicative comparisons as multiplication equations.

Multiply or divide to solve word problems involving multiplicative comparison, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem, distinguishing multiplicative comparison from additive comparison.

Solve multistep word problems posed with whole numbers and having whole number answers using the four operations, including problems in which remainders must be interpreted. Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies including rounding. Gain familiarity with factors and multiples.

Find all factor pairs for a whole number in the range 1-100. Recognize that a whole number is a multiple of each of its factors. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1-100 is a multiple of a given one-digit number. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1-100 is prime or composite.
Generate and analyze patterns. Generate a number or shape pattern that follows a given rule. Identify apparent features of the pattern that were not explicit in the rule itself.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Number and Operations in Base Ten
objectives.objectiveDescription: Generalize place value understanding for multi-digit whole numbers less than or equal to 1,000,000.

expectations.expectationDescription: Recognize that in a multi-digit whole number, a digit in one place represents ten times what it represents in the place to its right by applying concepts of place value, multiplication, or division.

Read and write multi-digit whole numbers using standard form, word form, and expanded form. Compare two multi-digit numbers based on meanings of the digits in each place, using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.
Use place value understanding to round multi-digit whole numbers to any place through 1,000,000.

Perform multi-digit arithmetic with whole numbers less than or equal to 1,000,000. Fluently add and subtract multi-digit whole numbers using a standard algorithm. Multiply a whole number of up to four digits by a one-digit whole number, and multiply two two-digit numbers, using strategies based on place value and the properties of operations.

Find whole number quotients and remainders with up to four-digit dividends and one-digit divisors, using strategies based on place value, the properties of operations, and/or the relationship between multiplication and division.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Extend understanding of fraction equivalence and ordering limited to fractions with denominators 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100.

expectations.expectationDescription: Explain why a fraction a/b is equivalent to a fraction (n Ã— a) / (n Ã— b) by using visual fraction models, with attention to how the number and size of the parts differ even though the two fractions themselves are the same size. Use this principle to recognize and generate equivalent fractions.

Compare two fractions with different numerators and different denominators, e.g., by creating common denominators or numerators, or by comparing to a benchmark fraction such as 1/2. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two fractions refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with symbols >, =, or <, and justify the conclusions, e.g., by using a visual fraction model.
Understand a fraction a/b with a > 1 as a sum of fractions 1/b.
Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication to multiply a fraction by a whole number.
Understand decimal notation for fractions, and compare decimal fractions limited to fractions with denominators 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100.
Express a fraction with denominator 10 as an equivalent fraction with denominator 100, and use this technique to add two fractions with respective denominators 10 and 100.
Use decimal notation for fractions with denominators 10 or 100.
Compare two decimals to hundredths by reasoning about their size.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Solve problems involving measurement and conversion of measurements from a larger unit to a smaller unit.

expectations.expectationDescription: Know relative sizes of the metric measurement units within one system of units. Express a larger measurement unit in terms of a smaller unit. Record measurement conversions in a two-column table.

Solve real-world problems involving money, time, and metric measurement. Add, subtract, and multiply whole numbers to solve metric measurement problems involving distances, liquid volumes, and masses of objects.
Develop efficient strategies to determine the area and perimeter of rectangles in real-world situations and mathematical problems.
Display and interpret data in graphs (picture graphs, bar graphs, and line plots) to solve problems using numbers and operations for this grade.
Recognize angles as geometric shapes that are formed wherever two rays share a common endpoint, and understand concepts of angle measurement.
Measure angles in whole number degrees using a protractor. Sketch angles of specified measure.
Recognize angle measure as additive. Solve addition and subtraction problems to find unknown angles on a diagram in real-world and mathematical problems.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Draw and identify lines and angles, and classify shapes by properties of their lines and angles.

expectations.expectationDescription: Draw points, lines, line segments, rays, angles (right, acute, and obtuse), and perpendicular and parallel lines. Identify these in two-dimensional figures.
Classify two-dimensional figures based on the presence or absence of parallel or perpendicular lines or the presence or absence of angles of a specified size.

Find whole number quotients and remainders with up to four-digit dividends and one-digit divisors, using strategies based on place value, the properties of operations, and/or the relationship between multiplication and division.

sections.sectionDescription: Compare two fractions with different numerators and different denominators, e.g., by creating common denominators or numerators, or by comparing to a benchmark fraction such as 1/2. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two fractions refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with symbols >, =, or <, and justify the conclusions, e.g., by using a visual fraction model.

outline.title: Equivalent Fractions with Denominators of 10 and 100

sections.sectionDescription: Express a fraction with denominator 10 as an equivalent fraction with denominator 100, and use this technique to add two fractions with respective denominators 10 and 100.

Compare two decimals to hundredths by reasoning about their size.
Know relative sizes of the metric measurement units within one system of units. Express a larger measurement unit in terms of a smaller unit. Record measurement conversions in a two-column table.

Solve multistep word problems posed with whole numbers and having whole number answers using the four operations, including problems in which remainders must be interpreted. Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies including rounding.

Identify arithmetic patterns (including patterns in the addition table or multiplication table), and explain them using properties of operations. For example, observe that 4 times a number is always even, and explain why 4 times a number can be decomposed into two equal addends.
Assess overall understanding and proficiency in key mathematical concepts learned throughout the year.

objectives.objectiveDescription: The solar system includes the sun and all celestial bodies that orbit the sun. Each planet in the solar system has unique characteristics.

expectations.expectationDescription: The distance from the sun, size, composition, and movement of each planet are unique. Planets revolve around the sun in elliptical orbits. Some of the planets have moons and/or debris that orbit them. Comets, asteroids, and meteoroids orbit the sun.

objectives.objectiveDescription: The sun is one of many stars that exist in the universe.

expectations.expectationDescription: The sun appears to be the largest star in the sky because it is the closest star to Earth. Some stars are larger than the sun and some stars are smaller than the sun.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Most of the cycles and patterns of motion between the Earth and sun are predictable.

expectations.expectationDescription: Earthâ€™s revolution around the sun takes approximately 365 days. Earth completes one rotation on its axis in a 24-hour period, producing day and night. This rotation makes the sun, stars and moon appear to change position in the sky.

objectives.objectiveDescription: The amount of change in movement of an object is based on the mass of the object and the amount of force exerted.

expectations.expectationDescription: Movement can be measured by speed. The speed of an object is calculated by determining the distance traveled in a period of time.
Any change in speed or direction of an object requires a force and is affected by the mass of the object and the amount of force applied.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Light and sound are forms of energy that behave in predictable ways.

expectations.expectationDescription: Light travels and maintains its direction until it interacts with an object or moves from one medium to another and then it can be reflected, refracted or absorbed.
Sound is produced by vibrating objects and requires a medium through which to travel. The rate of vibration is related to the pitch of the sound.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Organisms perform a variety of roles in an ecosystem.

expectations.expectationDescription: Populations of organisms can be categorized by how they acquire energy.
Food webs can be used to identify the relationships among producers, consumers, and decomposers in an ecosystem.

objectives.objectiveDescription: All of the processes that take place within organisms require energy.

expectations.expectationDescription: For ecosystems, the major source of energy is sunlight. Energy entering ecosystems as sunlight is transferred and transformed by producers into energy that organisms use through the process of photosynthesis. That energy is used or stored by the producer and can be passed from organism to organism as illustrated in food webs.

sections.sectionDescription: Introduce students to the components of the solar system including the sun, planets, moons, comets, asteroids, and meteoroids.

sections.sectionTitle: Distance from the Sun and Size
sections.sectionDescription: Discuss the distance of each planet from the sun and compare their sizes.
Explore the composition of different planets and their movements in elliptical orbits.
Study the moons of various planets and the characteristics of comets, asteroids, and meteoroids.
Explain why the sun appears to be the largest star in the sky and compare its size to other stars.
Describe Earth's revolution around the sun and its rotation on its axis, leading to day and night.
Discuss the predictable cycles and patterns of motion between the Earth and the sun.
Introduce the concept of movement and how it is measured by speed.
Teach students how to calculate the speed of an object by determining the distance traveled over time.
Explain how any change in speed or direction of an object requires a force and is affected by the mass of the object.
Discuss how light travels and maintains its direction until it interacts with an object or changes medium.
Explore how light can be reflected, refracted, or absorbed when it interacts with different materials.
Discuss how sound is produced by vibrating objects and requires a medium to travel through.
Explain the relationship between the rate of vibration and the pitch of the sound.
Introduce the concept of ecosystems and the various roles organisms play within them.
Categorize populations of organisms by how they acquire energy.
Use food webs to identify the relationships among producers, consumers, and decomposers in an ecosystem.
Explain how energy enters ecosystems as sunlight and is transferred and transformed by producers through photosynthesis.
Discuss the process of photosynthesis and how energy is used or stored by producers.
Illustrate how energy is passed from organism to organism in an ecosystem through food webs.
Review the characteristics and movements of planets, moons, comets, asteroids, and meteoroids.
Review the concepts related to the sun and its comparison with other stars.
Review Earth's revolution and rotation, and how they create day and night cycles.
Review the concepts of speed, distance, force, and their effects on movement.
Review the behavior of light and sound, including reflection, refraction, absorption, and vibration.
Review the roles of organisms in ecosystems, energy acquisition, and the process of photosynthesis.
Students create models of the solar system to demonstrate their understanding of planetary orbits and characteristics.

outline.title: Project Week: Light and Sound Experiments

sections.sectionDescription: Students conduct experiments to explore the properties of light and sound.
Students build dioramas to illustrate different ecosystems and the relationships within them.
Students plan and outline their final science fair projects, incorporating various concepts learned throughout the year.
Students conduct research and begin developing their science fair projects.
Students run experiments and collect data for their science fair projects.
Students analyze the data collected from their experiments and prepare their findings.
Students create presentation boards and practice presenting their science fair projects.
Students present their final projects at the science fair.
Review key concepts learned throughout the year and reflect on personal growth and understanding.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Identify and use appropriate digital learning tools and resources to accomplish a defined task.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will learn how to select and utilize digital tools to plan, implement, and reflect upon a defined task.

expectations.expectationDescription: With guidance, identify and use digital learning tools or resources to support planning, implementing and reflecting upon a defined task.
Explain the use of selected digital learning tools and resources to support productivity and learning.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Use digital learning tools and resources to locate, evaluate and use information.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will develop skills in information literacy by using digital tools to locate, evaluate, and use information effectively.

expectations.expectationDescription: Identify questions related to a topic of interest to broaden or narrow the topic as needed.
Use appropriate search techniques to locate needed information using digital learning tools and resources.
Use multiple criteria developed with guidance to differentiate between relevant and irrelevant information found with digital learning tools and resources.
Explain basic ideas of plagiarism and copyright.
Use digital citation tools to cite sources with appropriate guidance.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Use digital learning tools and resources to construct knowledge.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will learn to synthesize and create new knowledge by utilizing various digital resources.

expectations.expectationDescription: Gather, organize and summarize information from multiple digital learning tools and resources to build knowledge of a topic.
Interpret images, diagrams, maps, graphs, infographics, videos, animations, interactives, etc., in digital learning tools and resources to clarify and add to knowledge.
Organize observations and data collected during student explorations to determine if patterns are present.
Create artifacts using digital learning tools and resources to demonstrate knowledge.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Use digital learning tools and resources to communicate and disseminate information to multiple audiences.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will utilize digital tools to effectively communicate and share information with diverse audiences.

expectations.expectationDescription: With guidance, discuss and identify communication needs considering goals, audience and content.
With guidance, select media formats appropriate to content and audience.
Evaluate the features of digital learning tools and resources based on the characteristics of a specific audience.
Produce and publish information appropriate for a target audience using digital learning tools and resources.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Demonstrate an understanding of technologyâ€™s impact on the advancement of humanity â€“ economically, environmentally and ethically.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will explore how technology influences and shapes various aspects of society, including ethical considerations and community impacts.

expectations.expectationDescription: Demonstrate appropriate use of technology and explain the importance of responsible and ethical technology use.
Identify positive and negative impacts oneâ€™s use of personal technology and technology systems (e.g., agriculture, transportation, energy generation, water treatment) can have on oneâ€™s community.
Describe legal and responsible practices when utilizing technology.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Analyze the impact of communication and collaboration in both digital and physical environments.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will understand the dynamics of digital and physical interactions and their implications for effective collaboration.

expectations.expectationDescription: Create a plan and select collaboration and/or communication tools to complete a given task.
Exercise digital etiquette when communicating and collaborating.
Identify the positive and negative impact the use of technology can have on relationships, communities and self.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Explain how technology, society and the individual impact one another.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will explore the interrelationship between technology, society, and individual identity, considering both historical and future perspectives.

expectations.expectationDescription: Describe the advantages and disadvantages of technology (past, present, future) to understand the relationship between technology, society and the individual.
Demonstrate how technology innovations/inventions can have multiple applications.
Identify and discuss how the use of technology affects self and others in various ways.
Identify the components of oneâ€™s digital identity and oneâ€™s digital footprint.
Identify and discuss laws and rules that apply to digital content and information.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Define and describe technology, including its core concepts of systems, resources, requirements, processes, controls, optimization and trade-offs.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will gain a foundational understanding of technology and its various aspects, which are crucial to understanding how technological systems function.

expectations.expectationDescription: Demonstrate how applying human knowledge using tools and machines extends human capabilities to meet our needs and wants.
Give examples of how requirements for a product can limit the design possibilities for that product.
Describe a process as a series of actions and how it is used to produce a result.
Identify and describe examples of technology products and processes.
Explain how controls use information to cause systems to change, like a home thermostat turning on the heat based on the low temperature of a room.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Identify a problem and use an engineering design process to solve the problem.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will engage in the engineering design process to identify and solve problems, critically thinking about potential solutions and their implementation.

expectations.expectationDescription: Critique needs and opportunities for designing solutions.

Plan and implement a design process: identify a problem, think about ways to solve the problem, develop possible solutions, test and evaluate solution(s), present a possible solution, and redesign to improve the solution.
Generate, develop and communicate design ideas and decisions using appropriate terms and graphical representations.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Demonstrate that solutions to complex problems require collaboration, interdisciplinary understanding and systems thinking.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will learn the value of collaborative and interdisciplinary approaches to solving complex problems, emphasizing systems thinking.

expectations.expectationDescription: Design a product with multiple components and describe how the components interact to form a system.
Explore and document connections between technology and other fields of study.
Identify a product and describe how people from different disciplines combined their skills in the design and production of the product.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Evaluate designs using functional, aesthetic and creative elements.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Students will apply criteria to evaluate technological products, considering both functional and aesthetic aspects to appreciate the creative elements involved.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use criteria developed with guidance to evaluate a new or improved product for its functional, aesthetic and creative elements.
Examine a familiar product or process and suggest improvements to its design.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Learn about the internal parts, hardware, software, and troubleshooting of computing systems.

expectations.expectationDescription: Explore the internal parts of the computing system and their function to understand and describe the role they play in a computer system.
Evaluate digital learning tools/devices to support planning, implementing and reflecting across curricular areas.
Diagnose problems and develop strategies to resolve technology issues.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Understanding networking, cybersecurity, and the Internet of Things (IoT).

expectations.expectationDescription: Model how information is broken down to be transmitted and then reassembled to help students gain a better understanding of the internet and networks.
Apply knowledge of network addresses, names and rules (i.e., protocols) to discuss real-world scenarios.
Demonstrate password creation techniques to develop and use a strong password used on personal accounts.
Explore and utilize safe online services such as web, email, video, gaming, cloud services and network attached storage devices.
Learn and model how information is broken down to be transmitted by smart devices to help students visualize how information transfers over the internet.

Explore the benefits of the IoT with regards to convenience, safety and health to gain an appreciation of the risks involved in using devices, including data theft, identity theft, tracking and other forms of criminality.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Learn about data collection, storage, visualization, communication, inference, and modeling.

expectations.expectationDescription: Gather and organize multiple quantitative data elements using a tool to perform various tasks.
Compare and contrast file formats to demonstrate the advantages and disadvantages of each.
Organize and present collected data using visual or other types of representations to highlight relationships and support a claim.
Utilize data to propose cause and effect relationships and predict outcomes.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Understanding algorithms, variables, data representation, control structures, modularity, and program development.

expectations.expectationDescription: Evaluate a multi-step process to diagram the proper steps to solve a problem.
Create a variable, a placeholder for storing a value, to understand how it is used in a multi-step process (i.e., algorithm).
Create a program using sequences, events, loops and conditionals to solve a problem.
Decompose (i.e., break down) the steps needed or not needed (i.e., abstraction) into precise sequences of instructions to design an algorithm.
With grade appropriate complexity, modify, remix or incorporate portions of an existing program into one's own work, to develop something new or add more advanced features.
Use a design process to plan and develop a program that includes multiple steps and end user preferences.
Using guided questions, work through a program to identify errors and discuss possible solutions to repair the program.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Learn about perception, representation & reasoning, machine learning, and the societal impacts of AI.

expectations.expectationDescription: Describe how sensor inputs are converted as analog or digital signals to describe their uses.
Demonstrate a limitation of computer perception to understand how computers interact with humans.
Create a classification system using a tree structure to demonstrate binary solutions.
Describe how AI representations support reasoning to answer questions.
Compare three different machine learning approaches to solve a problem.
Describe how algorithms and machine learning can exhibit biases to be aware of how humans introduce bias into algorithms and machine learning.
Describe tasks where AI outperforms human tasks and when it does not and propose possible ways to have AI perform more human tasks.
Describe ways that AI systems can be designed to support inclusivity.
Explore how data is influenced by bias and how it affects decision-making to defend arguments in AI.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Understanding the cultural, social, and ethical impacts of computing technologies.

expectations.expectationDescription: Explain how computing technologies have changed the global community and express how those technologies influence and are influenced by cultural practices.
Develop, test and refine digital artifacts to improve accessibility and usability.
Collaborate and consider diverse perspectives to improve digital artifacts.
Use public domain or Creative Commons media, and refrain from copying or using material created by others without permission.
Communicate the effects of sharing personal information on the safety of student identity to determine how to protect students.
Evaluate the need to keep personal information secure and protect the digital footprint.
Analyze different forms of cyberbullying and identify strategies to stop cyberbullying.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Observe, listen, attend to, discriminate

expectations.expectationDescription: Understand that the context of an art object has an effect on how that object is perceived.
Identify and communicate how historical and cultural contexts influence ideas that inform artists.
Investigate the role of cultural objects in our everyday environment.
Compare and contrast how form and style are influenced by social, environmental and political views in artworks.
Focus attention on selected artworks to identify and pose questions about aesthetic qualities (e.g., sensory, organizational, emotional) in the works.
Select and access contemporary digital tools and media arts to investigate ideas and inform artmaking.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Generate, create, realize, use & master skills

expectations.expectationDescription: Integrate observational and technical skills to strengthen artmaking.
Use digital tools to explore ideas, create and refine works of art during the artmaking process.
Experiment with various ideas and visual art media to solve a problem that addresses a contemporary social issue.
Select and use the elements and principles of art and design to communicate understanding of an interdisciplinary concept.
During collaborative artmaking experiences, demonstrate respect and support for peer ideas and creativity.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Make connections, reconsider, question, self-assess

objectives.objectiveDescription: Write and interpret numerical expressions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use parentheses in numerical expressions, and evaluate expressions with this symbol. Formal use of algebraic order of operations is not necessary.
Write simple expressions that record calculations with numbers, and interpret numerical expressions without evaluating them.
Analyze patterns and relationships.
Generate two numerical patterns using two given rules. Identify apparent relationships between corresponding terms.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Number and Operations in Base Ten
objectives.objectiveDescription: Understand the place value system.

expectations.expectationDescription: Recognize that in a multi-digit number, a digit in one place represents 10 times as much as it represents in the place to its right and 1/10 of what it represents in the place to its left.

Explain patterns in the number of zeros of the product when multiplying a number by powers of 10, and explain patterns in the placement of the decimal point when a decimal is multiplied or divided by a power of 10.
Read, write, and compare decimals to thousandths.
Use place value understanding to round decimals to any place, millions through hundredths.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Number and Operations in Base Ten (continued)
objectives.objectiveDescription: Perform operations with multi-digit whole numbers and with decimals to hundredths.

expectations.expectationDescription: Fluently multiply multi-digit whole numbers using a standard algorithm.
Find whole number quotients of whole numbers with up to four-digit dividends and two-digit divisors.
Solve real-world problems by adding, subtracting, multiplying, and dividing decimals.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use equivalent fractions as a strategy to add and subtract fractions.

expectations.expectationDescription: Add and subtract fractions with unlike denominators.
Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions referring to the same whole.
Interpret a fraction as division of the numerator by the denominator. Solve word problems involving division of whole numbers leading to answers in the form of fractions or mixed numbers.
Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division to multiply a fraction or whole number by a fraction.
Interpret multiplication as scaling.
Solve real-world problems involving multiplication of fractions and mixed numbers.
Apply and extend previous understandings of division to divide unit fractions by whole numbers and whole numbers by unit fractions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Convert like measurement units within a given measurement system.

expectations.expectationDescription: Know relative sizes of these U.S. customary measurement units and convert between them in solving multi-step, real-world problems.
Display and interpret data in graphs to solve problems.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Represent and interpret data. Understand concepts of volume and relate volume to multiplication and to addition.

expectations.expectationDescription: Recognize volume as an attribute of solid figures and understand concepts of volume measurement.
Measure volumes by counting unit cubes and relate volume to the operations of multiplication and addition.
Find the volume of a right rectangular prism with whole number side lengths and apply the formulas for rectangular prisms to find volumes.
Recognize volume as additive and find volumes of solid figures composed of two non-overlapping right rectangular prisms.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Graph points on the coordinate plane to solve real-world and mathematical problems. Classify two-dimensional figures into categories based on their properties.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use a pair of perpendicular number lines to define a coordinate system and graph points in the first quadrant of the coordinate plane.
Represent real-world and mathematical problems by graphing points and interpret coordinate values of points.
Identify and describe commonalities and differences between types of triangles based on angle measures and side lengths.
Identify and describe commonalities and differences between types of quadrilaterals based on angle measures, side lengths, and the presence or absence of parallel and perpendicular lines.

sections.sSID: OH.5.MATH.1, OH.5.MATH.2, OH.5.MATH.3, OH.5.MATH.4, OH.5.MATH.5, OH.5.MATH.6, OH.5.MATH.7
sections.sectionDescription: Review key concepts learned throughout the course and reflect on personal growth and understanding.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Minerals are naturally occurring, inorganic solids that have a defined chemical composition and observable, measurable properties, forming in specific environments.

expectations.expectationDescription: Minerals are naturally occurring, inorganic solids that have a defined chemical composition. Minerals have properties that can be observed and measured. Minerals form in specific environments.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Igneous, metamorphic and sedimentary rocks have unique characteristics.
objectives.objectiveDescription: These rock types are identifiable and classifiable by their unique characteristics, including mineral composition and formation processes.

expectations.expectationDescription: Most rocks are composed of one or more minerals, but some sedimentary rocks contain organic material, such as coal. The composition, types of mineral present, and mineral shape and size can identify the rock and interpret its formation, weathering, and erosion history.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Igneous, metamorphic and sedimentary rocks form in different ways.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Each rock type provides information about the environment of its formation based on its origin from magma, existing rock, or sediment.

expectations.expectationDescription: Magma or lava cools and crystallizes to form igneous rocks. Heat and pressure transform existing rock into metamorphic rocks. Sedimentary rock forms from weathered material that is compressed and lithifies.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Soil is unconsolidated material that contains organic matter and weathered rock.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Soil formation varies by environmental conditions and types of bedrock, forming distinguishable layers known as horizons.

expectations.expectationDescription: Soil formation occurs at different rates based on environmental conditions, types of existing bedrock, and weathering rates. Soil forms in layers known as horizons, distinguishable by measurable properties. Use the term 'soil' rather than 'dirt'.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Rocks, minerals and soils have common and practical uses.
objectives.objectiveDescription: These geologic resources are essential for manufacturing and are considered nonrenewable.

expectations.expectationDescription: Nearly all manufactured material requires some kind of geologic resource. Most geologic resources are considered nonrenewable, including rocks, minerals, and soil.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Matter is made up of small particles called atoms.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Matter is characterized by mass, volume, and density and consists of particles known as atoms.

expectations.expectationDescription: Matter has mass, volume and density and is made up of particles called atoms.
Elements are a class of substances composed of a single kind of atom.
Molecules are the combination of two or more atoms that are joined together chemically.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Changes of state are explained by a model of matter composed of particles in motion.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Temperature and heat influence the motion and position of particles during phase changes.

expectations.expectationDescription: Temperature is a measure of the average motion of particles in a substance.
Heat is a process of energy transfer rather than a type of energy. Energy transfer can result in a change in temperature or a phase change.
When substances undergo changes of state, atoms change their motion and position.

objectives.objectiveTitle: There are two categories of energy: kinetic and potential.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Energy manifests as kinetic energy through motion or as potential energy due to position.

expectations.expectationDescription: Objects and substances in motion have kinetic energy.
Objects and substances can have energy as a result of their position (potential energy).

objectives.objectiveTitle: An objectâ€™s motion can be described by its speed and direction.
objectives.objectiveDescription: The motion of an object is measurable and can be graphically represented over time.

expectations.expectationDescription: An objectâ€™s position and speed can be measured and graphed as a function of time.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Cells are the fundamental unit of life.
objectives.objectiveDescription: All living things are composed of cells, with varied functions across different types of cells.

expectations.expectationDescription: All living things are composed of cells. Different body tissues and organs are made of different kinds of cells. The ways cells function are similar in all living organisms.

objectives.objectiveTitle: All cells come from pre-existing cells.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Cell division is a fundamental process for growth, development, and repair in multicellular organisms.

expectations.expectationDescription: Cells repeatedly divide resulting in more cells and growth and repair in multicellular organisms.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Cells carry on specific functions that sustain life.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Cells perform essential biological functions necessary for the survival of organisms.

expectations.expectationDescription: Many basic functions of organisms occur in cells. Cells take in nutrients and energy to perform work, like making various molecules required by that cell or an organism.
Every cell is covered by a membrane that controls what can enter and leave the cell.
Within the cell are specialized parts for the transport of materials, energy capture and release, protein building, waste disposal, information feedback and movement.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Living systems at all levels of organization demonstrate the complementary nature of structure and function.
objectives.objectiveDescription: Organisms exhibit various levels of organization, from cells to whole systems, which are essential for life processes.

expectations.expectationDescription: The level of organization within organisms includes cells, tissues, organs, organ systems and whole organisms.
Whether the organism is single-celled or multicellular, all of its parts function as a whole to perform the tasks necessary for the survival of the organism.
Organisms have diverse body plans, symmetry and internal structures that contribute to their being able to survive in their environments.

sections.sectionDescription: Minerals are naturally occurring, inorganic solids that have a defined chemical composition. Minerals have properties that can be observed and measured. Minerals form in specific environments.

Most rocks are composed of one or more minerals, but some sedimentary rocks contain organic material, such as coal. The composition, types of mineral present, and mineral shape and size can identify the rock and interpret its formation, weathering, and erosion history.

Magma or lava cools and crystallizes to form igneous rocks. Heat and pressure transform existing rock into metamorphic rocks. Sedimentary rock forms from weathered material that is compressed and lithifies.

Soil formation occurs at different rates based on environmental conditions, types of existing bedrock, and weathering rates. Soil forms in layers known as horizons, distinguishable by measurable properties. Use the term 'soil' rather than 'dirt'.

sections.sectionTitle: Practical Uses of Rocks, Minerals, and Soils
sections.sectionDescription: Nearly all manufactured material requires some kind of geologic resource. Most geologic resources are considered nonrenewable, including rocks, minerals, and soil.
Matter has mass, volume and density and is made up of particles called atoms.
Elements are a class of substances composed of a single kind of atom.
Molecules are the combination of two or more atoms that are joined together chemically.
Temperature is a measure of the average motion of particles in a substance.
Heat is a process of energy transfer rather than a type of energy. Energy transfer can result in a change in temperature or a phase change.
When substances undergo changes of state, atoms change their motion and position.
Objects and substances in motion have kinetic energy.
Objects and substances can have energy as a result of their position (potential energy).
An objectâ€™s position and speed can be measured and graphed as a function of time.
All living things are composed of cells. Different body tissues and organs are made of different kinds of cells. The ways cells function are similar in all living organisms.
Cells repeatedly divide resulting in more cells and growth and repair in multicellular organisms.
Many basic functions of organisms occur in cells. Cells take in nutrients and energy to perform work, like making various molecules required by that cell or an organism.
Every cell is covered by a membrane that controls what can enter and leave the cell.
Within the cell are specialized parts for the transport of materials, energy capture and release, protein building, waste disposal, information feedback and movement.
The level of organization within organisms includes cells, tissues, organs, organ systems and whole organisms.
Whether the organism is single-celled or multicellular, all of its parts function as a whole to perform the tasks necessary for the survival of the organism.
Organisms have diverse body plans, symmetry and internal structures that contribute to their being able to survive in their environments.
Review the properties of minerals, the characteristics of different rock types, and their formation processes.
Review soil formation, layers, and the practical uses of rocks, minerals, and soils.
Review the properties of matter, including mass, volume, and density.
Review the changes of state, particle motion, and energy transfer.
Review the concepts of kinetic and potential energy.
Review how an objectâ€™s position and speed can be measured and graphed as a function of time.
Review the basic functions of cells, including nutrient intake, energy use, and waste disposal.
Review the levels of organization within organisms, from cells to whole organisms.

Students will model the rock cycle and explain the formation of different rock types.
Students will analyze soil samples to identify layers and discuss the factors influencing soil formation.
Students will explore the structure of atoms and elements and their properties.
Students will investigate phase changes and the effects of temperature and heat on particle motion.
Students will explore examples of kinetic and potential energy in real-world scenarios.
Students will create models of cells and demonstrate their functions and specialized parts.
Students will create models of different organism body plans, highlighting structure and function.

Celebrate the achievements and progress made throughout the course with a class celebration and sharing session.

Define and categorize the requirements of a design as either criteria or constraints.

Deconstruct a system into its component parts and describe how they interrelate.

objectives.objectiveDescription: The hydrologic cycle illustrates the changing states of water as it moves through the lithosphere, biosphere, hydrosphere and atmosphere.

expectations.expectationDescription: Thermal energy is transferred as water changes state throughout the cycle. The cycling of water in the atmosphere is an important part of weather patterns on Earth. The rate at which water flows through soil and rock is dependent upon the porosity and permeability of the soil or rock.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Thermal-energy transfers in the ocean and the atmosphere
objectives.objectiveDescription: Thermal-energy transfers in the ocean and the atmosphere contribute to the formation of currents, which influence global climate patterns.

expectations.expectationDescription: The sun is the major source of energy for wind, air and ocean currents and the hydrologic cycle. As thermal energy transfers occur in the atmosphere and ocean, currents form. Large bodies of water can influence weather and climate. The jet stream is an example of an atmospheric current and the Gulf Stream is an example of an oceanic current. Ocean currents are influenced by factors other than thermal energy, such as water density, mineral content (such as salinity), ocean floor topography and Earthâ€™s rotation. All of these factors delineate global climate patterns on Earth.

objectives.objectiveDescription: The atmosphere has different properties at different elevations and contains a mixture of gases that cycle through the lithosphere, biosphere, hydrosphere and atmosphere.

expectations.expectationDescription: The atmosphere is held to the Earth by the force of gravity. There are defined layers of the atmosphere that have specific properties, such as temperature, chemical composition and physical characteristics. Gases in the atmosphere include nitrogen, oxygen, water vapor, carbon dioxide and other trace gases. Biogeochemical cycles illustrate the movement of specific elements or molecules (such as carbon or nitrogen) through the lithosphere, biosphere, hydrosphere and atmosphere.

objectives.objectiveDescription: The relative patterns of motion and positions of Earth, moon and sun cause solar and lunar eclipses, tides and phases of the moon.

expectations.expectationDescription: The moonâ€™s orbit and its change of position relative to Earth and sun result in different parts of the moon being visible from Earth (phases of the moon).
A solar eclipse is when Earth moves into the shadow of the moon (during a new moon). A lunar eclipse is when the moon moves into the shadow of Earth (during a full moon).

Gravitational force between Earth and the moon causes daily oceanic tides. When the gravitational forces from the sun and moon align (at new and full moons) spring tides occur. When the gravitational forces of the sun and moon are perpendicular (at first and last quarter moons), neap tides occur.

objectives.objectiveDescription: The relative positions of Earth and the sun cause patterns we call seasons.

expectations.expectationDescription: Earthâ€™s axis is tilted at an angle of 23.5Â°. This tilt along with Earthâ€™s revolution around the sun, affects the amount of direct sunlight that the earth receives in a single day and throughout the year. The average daily temperature is related to the amount of direct sunlight received.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Elements can be organized by properties.

expectations.expectationDescription: Elements can be classified as metals, non-metals, and metalloids, and can be organized by similar properties such as color, solubility, hardness, density, conductivity, melting point and boiling point, viscosity, and malleability.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Conservation of matter in chemical reactions
objectives.objectiveDescription: Matter can be separated or changed, but in a closed system, the number and types of atoms remains constant.

expectations.expectationDescription: When substances interact and form new substances the properties of the new substances may be very different from those of the original substances, but the amount of mass does not change.
Physically combining two or more substances forms a mixture, which can be separated through physical processes.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Energy can be transformed or transferred but is never lost.

expectations.expectationDescription: When energy is transferred from one system to another, the quantity of energy before transfer equals the quantity of energy after transfer. When energy is transformed from one form to another, the total amount of energy remains the same.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Energy can be transferred through a variety of ways.

expectations.expectationDescription: Mechanical energy can be transferred when objects push or pull on each other over a distance.
Mechanical and electromagnetic waves transfer energy when they interact with matter.
Thermal energy can be transferred through radiation, convection and conduction.
An electrical circuit transfers energy from a source to a device.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Energy and matter flow in ecosystems
objectives.objectiveDescription: Energy flows and matter is transferred continuously from one organism to another and between organisms and their physical environments.

expectations.expectationDescription: Plants use the energy in light to make sugars out of carbon dioxide and water (photosynthesis). These materials can be used or stored for later use.

Organisms that eat plants break down plant structures to release the energy and produce the materials they need to survive. The organism may then be consumed by other organisms for materials and energy.
Energy can transform from one form to another in living things. Animals get energy from oxidizing food, releasing some of its energy as heat.
The total amount of matter and energy remains constant, even though its form and location change.

objectives.objectiveDescription: In any particular biome, the number, growth and survival of organisms and populations depend on biotic and abiotic factors.

expectations.expectationDescription: The variety of physical (abiotic) conditions that exists on Earth gives rise to diverse environments (biomes) and allows for the existence of a wide variety of organisms (biodiversity).
Biomes are regional ecosystems characterized by distinct types of organisms that have developed under specific soil and climatic conditions.

Ecosystems are dynamic in nature; the number and types of species fluctuate over time. Disruptions, deliberate or inadvertent, to the physical (abiotic) or biological (biotic) components of an ecosystem impact the composition of an ecosystem.

sections.sectionDescription: Understand how thermal energy is transferred as water changes state throughout the hydrologic cycle.
Study the cycling of water in the atmosphere and its role in weather patterns on Earth.

sections.sectionTitle: Water Flow Through Soil and Rock
sections.sectionDescription: Learn how porosity and permeability of soil and rock affect the rate at which water flows through them.
Explore how thermal energy transfers in the ocean contribute to the formation of ocean currents.
Study the formation and influence of the jet stream as an atmospheric current.
Investigate how ocean currents, water density, salinity, ocean floor topography, and Earth's rotation influence global climate patterns.
Examine the defined layers of the atmosphere and their specific properties.
Learn about the mixture of gases in the atmosphere and their cycling through different spheres.
Understand how the moonâ€™s orbit and its position relative to Earth and sun result in different phases of the moon.
Study solar and lunar eclipses and their causes.
Explore how gravitational forces between Earth and the moon cause oceanic tides and the difference between spring and neap tides.
Learn how Earth's axial tilt and revolution around the sun affect seasonal patterns.
Understand how elements are classified as metals, non-metals, and metalloids and organized by their properties.
Study how matter is conserved during chemical reactions and the formation of new substances.
Learn about mixtures and how they can be separated through physical processes.
Understand that energy can be transferred and transformed, but the total amount of energy remains constant.
Explore how mechanical energy is transferred when objects push or pull on each other over a distance.
Learn how mechanical and electromagnetic waves transfer energy when they interact with matter.
Understand how thermal energy can be transferred through radiation, convection, and conduction.
Study how electrical circuits transfer energy from a source to a device.
Understand how plants use light energy to make sugars through photosynthesis.
Learn how organisms break down plant structures to release energy and produce materials they need to survive.
Explore how animals get energy from oxidizing food and releasing energy as heat.
Understand how the total amount of matter and energy remains constant in ecosystems, even though its form and location change.
Study the variety of physical conditions that give rise to diverse environments and biodiversity.
Learn about regional ecosystems characterized by distinct types of organisms developed under specific soil and climatic conditions.
Understand how ecosystems are dynamic in nature and how species fluctuate over time.
Study the impact of disruptions to the physical or biological components of an ecosystem.
Review the processes and importance of the hydrologic cycle.

sections.sectionTitle: Energy Transfers in Oceans and Atmosphere
sections.sectionDescription: Review how thermal energy transfers influence global climate patterns.
Review the properties and composition of the atmosphere.

outline.title: Review of Celestial Motions and Phenomena

sections.sectionDescription: Review the causes and effects of celestial motions and phenomena.
Review how Earth's tilt and revolution around the sun cause seasonal patterns.

outline.title: Review of Energy and Matter in Ecosystems

sections.sectionDescription: Review the flow of energy and matter in ecosystems and their conservation.
Begin planning for a final project that incorporates learned concepts from all topics.
Present final projects to the class, demonstrating understanding of scientific concepts.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Identify and use appropriate digital learning tools and resources to accomplish a defined task

expectations.expectationDescription: Develop criteria for selecting digital learning tools and resources to accomplish a defined task.
Select and use digital learning tools or resources to support planning, implementing and reflecting upon a defined task.
Evaluate the use of digital learning tools and resources to support learning and productivity.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Use digital learning tools and resources to locate, evaluate and use information.

expectations.expectationDescription: Use advanced search techniques to locate needed information using digital learning tools and resources.
Use multiple criteria to evaluate the validity of information found with digital learning tools and resource.
Apply principles of copyright, use digital citation tools and use strategies to avoid plagiarism

objectives.objectiveTitle: Use digital learning tools and resources to construct knowledge.

expectations.expectationDescription: Analyze and integrate textual, visual and quantitative information (e.g., images, diagrams, maps, graphs, infographics, videos, animations, interactives) from multiple digital learning tools and resources.
Analyze data collected or retrieved from a variety of digital learning tools and resources to determine if patterns or trends are present.
Create artifacts using digital learning tools and resources to demonstrate knowledge.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Use digital learning tools and resources to communicate and disseminate information to multiple audiences

expectations.expectationDescription: Use digital learning tools and resources to identify communication needs considering goals, audience and content.
Select and use a variety of media formats to communicate information to a target audience.
Discuss and identify ways to communicate and disseminate information so that users with varied needs can access information.
Evaluate the effectiveness of a digital tool to communicate information with multiple audiences.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Demonstrate an understanding of technologyâ€™s impact on the advancement of humanity â€“ economically, environmentally and ethically.

expectations.expectationDescription: Advocate and exhibit ethical, legal and responsible practices when utilizing technology.
Explore the advantages and disadvantages of widespread use, accessibility and reliance on technology in oneâ€™s world.
Review and demonstrate ethical considerations and legal requirements involved in the creation and use of digital technologies.
Analyze an environmental concern and investigate technology solutions to that problem.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Analyze the impact of communication and collaboration in both digital and physical environments.

expectations.expectationDescription: Critique specific instances of how technology has impacted access to information, communications and collaboration.
Explain the positive and negative impact the use of technology can have on personal, professional and community relationships.
Investigate how social media impacts society and the digital identities of individuals and organizations.
Apply appropriate interactions and digital etiquette in varying contexts, reflecting upon potential impacts in both digital and physical environments.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Explain how technology, society and the individual impact one another.

expectations.expectationDescription: Discuss and define how issues (e.g., economic, political, scientific and cultural) are influenced by the development and use of technology.
Explain how new technology development is driven by factors such as commercialization, creative/inventive thinking and cultural/historical influence.
Analyze how technological innovations and inventions can have multiple applications, both intended and unintended.
Describe the impact of an individualâ€™s wants, values and interests on the development of new technologies.
Manage components of oneâ€™s digital identity and oneâ€™s digital footprint.
Evaluate current and past revisions to laws, rules and policies as society responds to technological advancements.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Define and describe technology, including its core concepts of systems, resources, requirements, processes, controls, optimization and trade-offs.

expectations.expectationDescription: Explore and document how technology can impact efficiency.
Analyze how tools, materials and processes are used to alter the natural and human-designed worlds.
Define and categorize the requirements of a design as either criteria or constraints.
Explain how optimization is the process of making a product as fully functional and effective as possible.
Describe how trade-offs involve a choice of one quality over another.
Give examples of how trade-offs must occur when optimizing a design in order to maintain design requirements.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Identify a problem and use an engineering design process to solve the problem.

expectations.expectationDescription: Apply a complete design process to solve an identified individual or community problem: research, develop, test, evaluate and present several possible solutions, and redesign to improve the solution.
Describe how invention is a process of turning ideas and imagination into devices and systems.
Explain how innovation is the process of modifying an existing system or system element(s) to improve it.
Consider multiple factors, including criteria and constraints, (e.g., research, cost, time, materials, feedback, safety) to justify decisions when developing products and systems to solve problems.
Identify and explain why effective designs develop from non-linear, flexible application of a design process.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Demonstrate that solutions to complex problems require collaboration, interdisciplinary understanding and systems thinking.

expectations.expectationDescription: Collaborate to solve a problem as an interdisciplinary team modeling different roles and functions.
Explain ways that invention and innovation within one field can transfer into other fields of technology.
Evaluate the effectiveness of the groupâ€™s collaboration during the engineering design process and the contribution of the varying roles.
Give examples of how changes in one part of a system can impact other parts of that system.
Deconstruct a system into its component parts and describe how they interrelate.

objectives.objectiveTitle: Evaluate designs using functional, aesthetic and creative elements.

expectations.expectationDescription: Examine the progression of a product to identify how the functional, aesthetic and creative elements were applied.
Analyze environments or products that are examples of the application of the principles of universal or inclusive design.
Apply the design principle â€œform follows functionâ€ to develop a product.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Learn about computing devices, hardware and software, and troubleshooting techniques.

expectations.expectationDescription: Develop and implement a process to evaluate existing computing devices capabilities based on personal interaction with the device.
Evaluate hardware and software combinations used to accomplish a task.
Use a systematic process to identify and evaluate the source of a routine computing problem. Select the best solution to solve the computing problem and communicate the solution to others.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Understand the hardware, protocols, cybersecurity, and IoT within networks and the internet.

expectations.expectationDescription: Explain the role of hardware components and diagram the infrastructure of networks and the internet (including cloud servers).
Explain the protocols (i.e., rules) and why they are used to transmit data across networks and the internet.
Identify and apply introductory methods of encryption to model the secure transmission of information.
Describe the types of malware to show how malware affects information.
Identify cybersecurity concerns and measures needed to protect electronic information.
Explain the positive and negative impacts of IoT as it applies to daily life and create ways to mitigate the negative impacts on society.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Focus on data collection, storage, visualization, and analysis for practical insights.

expectations.expectationDescription: Compare and contrast digital data collection tools to make them more useful and reliable.
Evaluate various file formats to understand data storage capabilities.
Create a logical file structure to organize data to support individual and collaborative work.
Communicate relations between data sets to interpret results.
Create a spreadsheet utilizing formulas, functions and graphs to represent and analyze data.
Create and analyze models and simulations to accurately hypothesize a real-world situation.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Develop skills in algorithms, programming, and problem-solving within software development.

expectations.expectationDescription: Select and modify pseudocode for a multi-step process to solve a problem.
Use test cases to trace variable values to determine the result.
Use and apply decisions and loops in a program to solve a problem.
Decompose problems into parts to facilitate the design, implementation and review of increasingly complex programs.
Write code that utilizes algorithms, variables and control structures to solve problems or as a creative expression.
Test, trace and debug to refine code.
Identify procedures that utilize parameters.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Explore concepts of AI such as perception, machine learning, and societal impacts.

expectations.expectationDescription: Give examples of how intelligent agents combine information from multiple sensors to react to an input.
Describe how edge detectors can be composed to form more complex feature detectors, e.g., for letters or shapes.
Illustrate the concept of feature extraction from images by simulating an edge detector.
Compare several algorithms that could be used to solve a specific type of reasoning problem.
Model how unsupervised learning finds patterns in unlabeled data to identify how machine learning takes place.
Create a dataset for training a decision tree classifier or predictor to explore the impact that different feature encodings have on the decision tree.
Curate a dataset to train a language-processing algorithm to create a program that incorporates voice commands.
Identify the components of a chatbot and explain how each component contributes to the chatbotâ€™s human-like responses.
Identify and explain the effect training data has on the accuracy of an artificial intelligence system to uncover bias in training data.
Identify and explain the problems of classification in the supervised artificial intelligence context to create data sets that are inclusive and accurate.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Investigate how computing influences culture, society, and various professional fields.

expectations.expectationDescription: Compare current technologies from the present to the past to evaluate the effect on people's everyday activities.
Evaluate various technologies to identify issues of bias and accessibility.
Identify and explore careers related to the field of computer science.
Explain how computing impacts innovation in other fields.
Analyze and present beneficial and harmful effects of electronic communications to understand their impacts on interpersonal, global, economic, political, business and cultural interactions.
Describe tradeoffs between allowing information to be public and keeping information private and secure to inform decision-making.
Identify the social and economic implications of privacy in the context of safety, law or ethics to understand how privacy impacts these areas.
Evaluate the development of new technologies in communication, entertainment and business to understand the impact.
Provide appropriate credit when using resources or artifacts that are not our own.
Explain the connection between the longevity of data on the internet, personal online identity and personal privacy.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Observe, listen, attend to, discriminate

expectations.expectationDescription: Explore how personal experiences, interest, cultural heritage and gender influence an artistâ€™s style and choice of subject matter.
Identify professions that use artistic skills and problem-solving.
Identify sources of visual culture in society and the media and discuss how the messages they convey affect personal and consumer choices.
Observe a variety of artworks noticing details, themes and ideas and group them into patterns and categories.
Examine designed objects and identify the processes and decisions made to produce them with attention to purpose, aesthetics, social issues and cultural and personal meaning.
Connect various art forms to their social, cultural or political purposes and include regional examples.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Generate, create, realize, use & master skills

expectations.expectationDescription: Improve craftsmanship and refine ideas in response to feedback.
Manipulate materials, tools and technology in conventional and unconventional ways to create a work of art.
Represent depth and volume in their two-dimensional works of art.
Apply art and design principles in the construction of three-dimensional artworks.
Create a work of art in collaboration with others to address a social or cultural issue.
Demonstrate understanding of visual literacy, illustration and graphic communication.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Make connections, reconsider, question, self-assess

expectations.expectationDescription: Speculate about an artistâ€™s intentions and message in a work using relevant references to the work.
Compare and contrast diverse viewpoints about works of art.
Interpret selected artworks and synthesize their interpretations with the interpretations of others.
Classify and categorize examples of artworks from various eras and cultures.
Describe how experiences in galleries, museums and other cultural institutions can stimulate the imagination and enrich peopleâ€™s lives.
Develop and use criteria to guide reflection and assessment of selected personal artworks.
Assess oneâ€™s own work and working process and the work of others in relation to criteria and standards.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Analyze proportional relationships and use them to solve real-world and mathematical problems.

expectations.expectationDescription: Compute unit rates associated with ratios of fractions, including ratios of lengths, areas, and other quantities measured in like or different units.
Recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities.
Use proportional relationships to solve multistep ratio and percent problems.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Apply and extend previous understandings of operations with fractions to add, subtract, multiply, and divide rational numbers.

expectations.expectationDescription: Apply and extend previous understandings of addition and subtraction to add and subtract rational numbers; represent addition and subtraction on a horizontal or vertical number line diagram.
Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division and of fractions to multiply and divide rational numbers.
Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving the four operations with rational numbers.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions and solve real-life and mathematical problems using numerical and algebraic expressions and equations.

expectations.expectationDescription: Apply properties of operations as strategies to add, subtract, factor, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients.

In a problem context, understand that rewriting an expression in an equivalent form can reveal and explain properties of the quantities represented by the expression and can reveal how those quantities are related.
Solve multi-step real-life and mathematical problems posed with positive and negative rational numbers in any form (whole numbers, fractions, and decimals), using tools strategically.
Use variables to represent quantities in a real-world or mathematical problem, and construct simple equations and inequalities to solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Draw, construct, and describe geometrical figures and describe the relationships between them.

expectations.expectationDescription: Solve problems involving similar figures with right triangles, other triangles, and special quadrilaterals.
Draw geometric figures with given conditions.
Describe the two-dimensional figures that result from slicing three-dimensional figures.
Work with circles.
Use facts about supplementary, complementary, vertical, and adjacent angles in a multi-step problem to write and solve simple equations for an unknown angle in a figure.
Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving area, volume, and surface area of two- and three-dimensional objects.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Use sampling to draw conclusions about a population and broaden understanding of statistical problem solving.

expectations.expectationDescription: Understand that statistics can be used to gain information about a population by examining a sample of the population.
Broaden statistical reasoning by using the GAISE model.
Describe and analyze distributions.
Understand that the probability of a chance event is a number between 0 and 1 that expresses the likelihood of the event occurring.

Approximate the probability of a chance event by collecting data on the chance process that produces it and observing its long-run relative frequency, and predict the approximate relative frequency given the probability.
Develop a probability model and use it to find probabilities of events.
Find probabilities of compound events using organized lists, tables, tree diagrams, and simulations.

Compute unit rates associated with ratios of fractions, including ratios of lengths, areas, and other quantities measured in like or different units.
Recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities.
Use proportional relationships to solve multistep ratio and percent problems.
Apply and extend previous understandings of addition and subtraction to add and subtract rational numbers; represent addition and subtraction on a horizontal or vertical number line diagram.
Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division and of fractions to multiply and divide rational numbers.
Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving the four operations with rational numbers.
Apply properties of operations as strategies to add, subtract, factor, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients.

In a problem context, understand that rewriting an expression in an equivalent form can reveal and explain properties of the quantities represented by the expression and can reveal how those quantities are related.
Solve multi-step real-life and mathematical problems posed with positive and negative rational numbers in any form (whole numbers, fractions, and decimals), using tools strategically.
Use variables to represent quantities in a real-world or mathematical problem, and construct simple equations and inequalities to solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.
Solve problems involving similar figures with right triangles, other triangles, and special quadrilaterals.
Draw geometric figures with given conditions.
Review all concepts and complete final projects.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Earthâ€™s lithosphere consists of major and minor tectonic plates that move relative to each other.

expectations.expectationDescription: Historical data such as fossil distribution and paleomagnetism contributed to the theory of plate tectonics.
Convection currents in the asthenosphere cause movements of the lithospheric plates.
There are three main types of plate boundaries: divergent, convergent, and transform.

objectives.objectiveDescription: A combination of constructive and destructive geologic processes formed Earthâ€™s surface.

expectations.expectationDescription: Earthâ€™s surface is formed from various geologic processes including plate tectonics.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Evidence of the dynamic changes of Earthâ€™s surface through time is found in the geologic record.

expectations.expectationDescription: The geologic record helps identify past environmental and climate conditions.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Objects can experience a force due to an external field such as magnetic, electrostatic, or gravitational fields.

expectations.expectationDescription: Magnetic, electrical, and gravitational forces can act at a distance.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Forces can act to change the motion of objects.

expectations.expectationDescription: The motion of an object is always measured with respect to a reference point.
Forces can be added; the net force on an object is the sum of all the forces acting on it.
If there is a nonzero net force acting on an object, its speed and/or direction will change.
Kinetic friction and drag are forces that act opposite to the motion of objects.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Diversity of species, a result of variation of traits, occurs through the process of evolution and extinction over many generations.

expectations.expectationDescription: Fossils provide important evidence of how life and environmental conditions have changed.
Changes in environmental conditions can affect the survival and reproductive success of species.
Extinction occurs when the environment changes and organisms do not have the traits necessary to survive and reproduce.

objectives.objectiveDescription: Every organism alive today comes from a long line of ancestors who reproduced successfully every generation.

expectations.expectationDescription: Reproduction involves the transfer of genetic information from one generation to the next.

objectives.objectiveDescription: The characteristics of an organism are a result of inherited traits received from parent(s).

expectations.expectationDescription: Expression of traits is determined by genes and environmental factors.
Genetic information is transmitted between parent and offspring during reproduction.
